PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain electors of Queensland points out to the Senate that the 1990-91 Federal Budget stipulates that from January next year Family Allowance payments will be subject to an assets test. Family Allowance will be withdrawn if net assets excluding the family home and debt exceed $300,000. Furthermore, the parental assets test threshold for Family Allowance Supplement, Austudy and Assistance for Isolated Children has been severely slashed in the 1990-91 Federal Budget.

Considering the economic crisis facing rural communities in Australia, assets tests of such a nature are not viable because the assets are incapable of generating enough income to sustain families and send children away for schooling.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to exempt the family farm from the assets test for Austudy, Family Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Farm Exemption
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:

That the Government is planning to introduce an assets test on Family Allowance at a level of $500,000. It will maintain the current assets tests on Family Allowance Supplement (FAS), Austudy and Isolated Children's Allowance which are discriminating against farming families particularly during the present rural crisis.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Australian Government to exempt the family farm of registered primary producers who are living and working on their own farm from inclusion in the assets tests for Austudy, Family Allowance, Isolated Children's Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Video Cassettes
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, having great concern over the effect that increasing availability of pornographic material is having in hastening the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to:

1. Dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which contain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc. or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism;
2. Resist moves to have Federal Funds granted to subsidise the production and export of X-rated videos; and
3. Implement the decision of all State Attorneys-General to have the distribution of X-rated videos from the Australian Capital Territory outlawed.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children, from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That, because the United Nations' Convention on the Rights of the Child would allow Governments to deprive parents of their rights, we request that the Parliament delay ratification for at least a year, to allow full open public debate and then a binding referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate.
(c) control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest.
(d) increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray, on behalf of Senator Richardson) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to provide for the matching of data in relation to certain assistance and tax.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray)-by leave-agreed to:
That the order of the Senate of 6 November 1990, relating to the introduction of Bills into the Senate after 16 November 1990, not apply to this Bill.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill would give effect to the wide-ranging data-matching measures announced in this year's Budget.
The agencies involved in this exercise are the Departments of Social Security, Veterans' Affairs, Community Services and Health, Employment Education and Training, and the Australian Taxation Office.

At present there are two major areas of potential abuse of the assistance and taxation systems. These arise when people provide inconsistent information on their income and family structure to two different government agencies. It is possible, for example, for a person receiving family allowance to fail to inform the Department of Employment, Education and Training and thereby receive AUSTUDY in respect of the same child, although the payment of one of those payments should preclude payment of the other.
Similarly, a person may be evading a tax liability by failing to disclose income to the Taxation Office, although information on that income may be held in another government agency's data base.
We expect that by matching data it will be possible to detect where a person has provided inconsistent information to one or more agencies and is thereby receiving incorrect payments.

The ability to cross-check data in this way builds on provisions in the social security legislation introduced earlier this session requiring claimants for or recipients of pensions and other benefits to provide their tax file numbers to the Department of Social Security.
The advantages of matching data on income, family structure and tax file numbers are enormous. This facility will virtually eliminate a major cause of social security and taxation fraud.

I would like to emphasise that privacy considerations have been a primary concern when drafting this legislation. Data would be transferred physically-not by on-line computer connection. The program would therefore not create a new data base made up of the individual agency data bases. Furthermore, time limits would be imposed on the completion of any data-matching exercise and on any action to be taken arising from discrepancies disclosed by the exercise. At the end of three months all material produced in the data-matching program would have to have been followed up by the agencies or it would be destroyed.
An obligation of confidentiality would be placed on all staff dealing with the information.

Set out in the Schedule to the Bill are the Privacy Commissioner's guidelines for the conduct of the data-matching authorised by the Bill. These are designed to ensure that there is appropriate and proper protection for individual privacy in the conduct of such data-matching.

These guidelines have been prepared in consultation with, and have been approved by, the Privacy Commissioner. They have been specifically developed for this particular form of data-matching. The Government proposes to develop data-matching guidelines of general application following a period of public consultation and comment which has already been started by the Privacy Commissioner. It is proposed that these general guidelines would be enacted as a schedule to the Privacy Act.

The present guidelines contained in this Bill are not necessarily indicative of the form and content of the proposed general guidelines. If the general guidelines are seen as less protective than the guidelines in the Bill the legislation to introduce the general guidelines would provide that the present guidelines are to be retained for the purpose of the data-matching activity authorised by this Bill. The Privacy Commissioner has been consulted on these guidelines and agrees with this course of action.
There would also be a restriction on the frequency with which data-matching can be carried out-the Bill specifies a maximum of nine occasions in one year.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRAINING GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) REGULATIONS INDUSTRY TRAINING AGENTS' GUIDELINES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motions for Disallowance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Training Guarantee (Administration) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 323 and made under the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990, be disallowed; and
That the Industry Training Agents' Guidelines No. 1, ITA 1 of 1990, made under the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990, be disallowed.

These motions are to disallow the regulations under the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990 and the Industry Training Agents' Guidelines. It has become necessary to move these motions of disallowance because, although on 18 October, in what we thought was good time, the Australian Democrats gave notice of this motion in the hope that there would be some alteration of those guidelines and perhaps a revision and presentation of guidelines which could assist the administration of the training guarantee scheme, that has not happened.

The negotiations with the Government and the Opposition have not produced guidelines which we consider to be worth supporting. The Australian Democrats originally proposed to continue to support the establishment of registered industry training agents (RITAs). However, instead of being simple and effective the scheme which has been presented to us now, we believe, is costly, over-bureaucratic and difficult to administer. Initially, the Opposition joined with us in sharing those thoughts and it was hoped that the Government would act to improve that scheme. But it is now apparent that the Opposition, as well as the Government, has no real interest in training and no real interest in examining the many problems that were raised with regard to these proposed regulations and guidelines. Instead of simplifying and improving the RITA scheme, once again the Government and the Opposition have combined to allow a scheme that is in fact complex, artificial and difficult to apply.

At the moment it is not open to us or the Opposition parties to disallow only part of these instruments, and we have been forced to move a motion to disallow them in toto. It was, however, open to the Government to improve these regulations, whether by supplement or re-introduction, with the changes to be effective immediately and with no delay in the operation of the registered industry training agents scheme. As I understand it, we have a compromise between the two older parties which is in fact a matter of political expediency. It fails to correct the major flaws in both instruments, and the certain effect is that training dollars will be wasted on costly bureaucracy.

At this point I think it is worth referring to the documentation supplied to us on this matter. It is symptomatic of this whole muddled exercise that the explanatory statement that was tabled along with the guidelines was in fact tabled with a page missing. We were supposed to accept that, but we did not accept it. We took it as an example of the lack of planning, proper draftsmanship and proper attitude towards this whole process by those responsible for it. Other examples of how inefficient and ineffective this whole process has been were highlighted just the other day when the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, on the basis of two sets of major defects affecting personal liberties, also gave notice of a motion to disallow. According to that notice of motion, the guidelines fail to provide for any review where registration of an agent is cancelled. The Democrats agree with the Committee's assessment that the guidelines also fail to grant the power to deregister as required by the legislation.

The circumstances leading to deregistration should also be spelt out clearly. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee also noted in its criticism of the guidelines that they fail to provide appropriate safeguards when empowering officials to enter premises and copy records. These significant concerns are in fact just a fragment of the problems with these RITA provisions.

As we understand it, the concept of registered industry training agents was to enable employers to have their training plans verified before costs are incurred, rather than relying on a retrospective tax audit. That is the concept that we supported. Five months after the commencement of the training guarantee scheme, the operation of registered industry training agents is a matter of some urgency for many employers, including those who have not taken a strong interest in training in the past. These proposed guidelines violate the need, under the Act, to keep the scheme simple. Instead of helping employers to comply with their training obligations, these guidelines limit access by employers and confuse them even more. The guidelines need to be clear and simple and to provide employers with sufficient access to properly qualified registered industry training agents; instead they are clumsy and bureaucratic.

A complicated grading approach jeopardises access to many significant industry and professional bodies-regardless of their quality or suitability as registered industry training agents. The Democrats support the use of categories in the proposed regulations and guidelines. We support the use of those categories to indicate the types of bodies that are intended to apply. However, we cannot accept the use of what we consider to be arbitrary figures to exclude bodies from eligibility purely on the basis of their size, regardless of the quality of advice that those bodies could offer. The new training scheme is essentially a taxation mechanism. It is designed to kick-start training in mainly small and medium sized firms. It will not live up to its design unless it is simplified. The present complications only encourage small to medium employers to give up in disgust and pay the tax anyway.

The agreement that I understand has been reached between the Government and the Opposition contains only one real concession, and that is the inclusion of higher education and technical and further education (TAFE) institutions as a recognised category of RITA applicant. Ironically, the Government has backflipped on this point. In order to qualify, all other categories-including the tripartite industry training bodies-must be competent and committed to training in a nominated area. But for some reason the universities and TAFE colleges do not need the same industry specific training qualifications and experience. That seems to me to be nonsense.

If the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, thinks he can shrug his shoulders at industry and explain that this was a concession to get RITA through, he can forget about pinning that on the Democrats because originally the Democrats suggested this category on the basis of solid representation from training bodies. I will return to the reasons for their inclusion later, but I state our position now: if these institutions wish to apply, provided they qualify as everyone else needs to and demonstrate their commitment and understanding of training, of course they should be successfully registered. We never argued, and it was never intended, that tertiary institutions would be given automatic status. I think it is a major flaw that this is the only real change that has been offered to address the many faults that we have identified.

The Government has agreed to clarify category E of the guidelines in a private letter to the Opposition. Category E provides for others to be eligible where no relevant body in a higher category has applied. Even if that other body has not been registered, that then discounts a number of other people from applying. Apparently, this matter of applying really means that others will be considered where coverage by bodies in higher categories is inadequate. If that is what it means, we need to see that interpretation spelt out. The Democrats proposed that here was a case for the Government to amend the guidelines. A new interpretation in a private letter is totally ineffective. At the very least the letter should be tabled as an undertaking on interpretation. It is just not sufficient to have private letters wandering about outside the Parliament as some indication of how things ought to be interpreted, especially on a thing such as this which has the capacity to discount, or refuse registration to, a number of people or bodies.

Another fault in the proposed guidelines is the fact that the provision for fees charged by registered industry training agents must be amended and explained in a note. Regulation No. 4 provides for a flat fee of $200 for the issue of a training advisory certificate. This sounds simple but, in fact, it brings with it a great number of problems. The Government has agreed to amend this regulation next year to allow RITAs to charge when a certificate is refused. I fail to see why it has to be next year. The Democrats have already received legal advice that this is already possible.

Our advice is that the $200 refers only to the actual issuing of a certificate. RITAs would be free to charge separately for expenses, whether or not a certificate is issued-for example, for program advice, planning, discussions with the employer, travel and accommodation. In fact, the Australian Taxation Office's booklet says that this advice will be available. At page 23 of its booklet the Australian Taxation Office says:

In addition, Registered Industry Training Agents will be working to help employers organise their training effort by giving advice on how they can best do this and by providing other training services.

At the moment these guidelines make allowance only for a payment of a flat fee of $200 for the issue of a training advisory certificate. We were told that any other charges would require legislative amendment; that it would not be possible; that it was a bit too hard; that it would be done next year. In fact, the Australian Taxation Office seems to think that something else is going on. If this were organised properly, the employer could claim these expenses as incidental expenditure under section 25 of the Act.

Another complaint that I think should be registered about this fee is that, instead of a mandatory charge of $200, organisations, including professional associations, have indicated to us that as RITAs themselves they would like to issue certificates without charge, or at least at a reduced charge, to members. It seems to be a fairly obvious sort of service that industry associations and professional associations should be able to offer. But the prescribed fee is a flat $200. We have indicated that the prescribed fee should therefore be a maximum amount or, given the separate recovery expenses, reduced to a nominal amount. Contrary to the Government's advice, legislative amendment is not necessary to alter the fees regulation. Apart from the need to provide the $200 as a maximum amount, at the very least it is necessary to clarify what is covered by the issue of a certificate and the capacity to charge for expenses incurred. These regulations repeat the complicated double definition of `certificate' that is given in the legislation. Sections 43 and 44 refer to certificates issued by the training advisory body, which advises whether training is or is not eligible. Certificates issued by industry training agents are only affirmative. This double definition is quite troublesome to employers trying to interpret what is going on here, what they are able to achieve, so they can demonstrate that their training program is in fact eligible under the Act.

Apart from this commitment on fees, the Government has promised a review of RITAs after 12 months. Of course, this is no excuse for providing poorly drafted guidelines now, but it seems that was an excuse which was adopted by the Minister: get the thing running. See what happens after 12 months and fix it up later. I cannot see why the concerns of industry were not taken into account now.

In this appalling document, a complex grading system imposes unrealistic and unworkable limits on eligible bodies. Many significant industry, professional and trade associations will not be recognised within their own categories because of arbitrary limits on size, regardless of their quality and suitability. These significant industry and professional trade associations which cannot qualify under these limits on size include the sole or major associations in the areas of computing, television, carpet manufacturing, bookbinding, glass packaging, sugar milling and goldmining. There are major activities in our economy which are excluded by this attempt to limit which groups can provide advice to participants-employers-within their industries.

There are professional associations without the specified numbers that are automatically relegated to a final fall-back category-that is, if nobody else has applied further up to provide advice in that area. Such professional associations include the law societies in the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and Tasmania, acupuncturists-there are only two associations in Australia-actuaries, consulting surveyors, aerial surveyors and independent schools. These bodies, regardless of their quality, speciality and convenience to employers, are relegated to the fall-back category, and they may miss out altogether on becoming registered industry training agents and being able to provide relevant quality advice. They may not be able to do that if some other group has applied to become a training agent.

If categories are provided, it is reasonable to expect that industry, trade and professional groups that are normally recognised as such should fit within them. It is ludicrous that employers in smaller and sunrise industries will have to see their own organisation for specialist advice-which will still be available, of course-and then go on to a larger and remote group for certification, to prove that that advice has been worth while. Hopefully they can stay within their State. It is possible and imaginable that this final certification process may not even need to take place outside the State. As a Tasmanian, I thoroughly object to that. It could lead to the delay or possible approval of programs of doubtful relevance and increased costs to all concerned. So much for productivity. We talk about productivity on the one hand and then we come up with this mumbo jumbo on the other.

Under the category for industry associations, industries with branches in different States or Territories must have sufficient numbers in each State or Territory where a RITA is required. We see immediately that Tasmania would suffer a penalty in that respect. Industry associations without the numbers in each State can be considered in the secondary fallback category only if they represent part of an industry. Whole industries and branches rather than sectors are automatically relegated to a final fall-back category.

Professional associations without specified numbers do not have a secondary category and fall within the `others' category. I am sure that they are not comfortable with that at all. Professional associations which should be able to provide advice on training to their members-they represent members or qualified persons-should not be defined in terms of employers, but that is how they are defined in these guidelines. Technically one could argue that they may not even be able to become registered industry training associations, even though their main mandate is to provide advice to members.

The improper use of arbitrary figures is particularly bad in the case of trade associations. The Australian Democrats would, if given the opportunity, remove the arbitrary figures from categories of eligible bodies, and would rely on what is already within the guidelines: that all applicants, except those in the new category, must satisfy fairly stringent criteria concerning their training qualifications and experience in a nominated industry. We think that is fair enough. In fact, a capacity to give quality advice should be the primary criteria for determining whether a person or group should be able to become a registered industry training agent.

At the moment, clauses 7.1, 7.2 and 8.1 of these regulations require applicants to maintain a knowledge of the industry, including its training needs and its infrastructure. That aspect is perfectly acceptable to us. In fact, it should be emphasised that it has the capacity to select agents who are most capable of delivering the goods.

The other criteria that are applied through arbitrary numbers and the definition of categories are most unsatisfactory and defeat the purpose of the Act. According to the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Government's reason for imposing size limits was that the National Training Board (NTB) was concerned about having to deal with an unwieldy number of training agents. If that is the case, perhaps the Minister should table such advice from the National Training Board. If it has those concerns, we should have tangible evidence that those concerns are held or we should dismiss that, otherwise we would be subject to regulation by innuendo.

Under simplified guidelines one final fall back category could contain an additional hoop of whether there is already adequate coverage. This would be sufficient. Another possible clause could require smaller units to operate through larger organisations or vice versa and thus reduce the overall number of RITAs, without arbitrary limits on size.

If this has all been a bit too difficult to incorporate in revised guidelines in the time since 18 October, then I suggest that perhaps some training in drafting is required and certainly training in consultation for the Government is required. In the period since 18 October, the Australian Democrats have received in- numerable pieces of correspondence congratulating us on our sensibility in tackling these inadequate guidelines. I will quote from one letter I received, which states:
I am pleased to note the importance placed upon and your continued support of efficient and authoritative advice provided by an effective industry training agent scheme.
I agree that such a scheme must not be overly bureaucratic or costly and one which ensures that it facilitates the spending of training dollars effectively.

As I said, we had innumerable pieces of correspondence following the same sort of trend. In the Sunday Age of 18 November the Executive Director of the Australian Institute of Management, Mr Peter Sheldrake, said:
The intention behind the scheme has been very good, but it hadn't been thought through in all its implications.

There was some discussion of the scheme, but basically they (the Government) came through with a scheme and got it implemented without enough discussion of ways in which that kind of approach could have been enhanced to better achieve their objectives.

As I suggested, I think the amount of correspondence we received on it and the amount of agreement that we had with our position through the media validates our stand and also indicates to the Government that further and more thorough consultation would have been most beneficial.

If that is not bad enough, the schedule to the guidelines, which lists the details to be submitted by RITA applicants, currently contains intrusive and irrelevant questions, and even that requires modification. In particular, Nos 14, 17 and 22 should be deleted. No. 14 requires unnecessary information about an applicant's income; No. 17 is already covered by clause 8.1 in the main body; and No. 22 concerns advertising as a RITA, which is really the business of the agent and has nothing to do with the administrators of the scheme.

As I stated earlier, if they wish to apply and provided they qualify, higher education and technical and further education institutions should really be registered as RITAs-not automatically, but if they qualify. It is interesting to note that, initially, professional bodies were left out and according to some industry groups perhaps should still be excluded.

Public education and training institutions currently do the vast bulk of training that is on offer in Australia anyway and are generally well qualified to assess whether a training program has structure, objectives and designated outcomes for the purposes of this Act. The institutions' involvement in industry training includes all pre-service education for the professions, a significant amount of postgraduate and in-service training and upgrading of industry skills, and they have a knowledge of all in-service work for apprentices.

It was suggested by some critics of this inclusion that institutions should concentrate their resources on the delivery of training, rather than certifying industry proposals. This shows how little those critics know of the process of training.

A summary-I do not propose in four minutes to offer an expose of what training is all about-is that usually training needs are assessed, a program is devised to meet those needs, and then that program is conducted. Part of that conduct is that the program's evaluation informs of the degree to which the training needs have been met.

Institutions do not just deliver training classes; they develop programs and, therefore, are eminently suited to evaluate proposed programs-it is part of what they do; that is their expertise. It would not be a diminution of the resources they have available to present training classes; it would be part of the very fabric of the institution.

I think that illustrates the lack of knowledge that such critics have of the actual training process, which is not just a process of winding up a class and delivering it; it is a coordinated and involved process which involves the things that I have just indicated.

Industry groups have stated that they will use these people in institutions to certify their training anyway because that is where they believe the expertise to judge the relevance of a training program resides. In a primary role, such institutions acting as RITAs would ensure access for employers in regional and isolated areas. They also provide an avenue for those who do not have or desire access to an industry association.

Many industry associations and some industry training advisory bodies also provide training and this role is expected to increase under the training levy scheme. Some industry groups have indicated that training provision and certification will be conducted from separate offices and that TAFE institutions are ideally suited to prevent any risk of conflict of interest.

The Government's explanation for giving tertiary institutions automatic RITA status is to minimise the bureaucracy in line with the Act's objectives and to lessen the workload on the National Training Board. Given the complexity of the complete guidelines we have here, that is a lame excuse.

The Government has limited the role of RITAs to certification only. This is an administratively simple task, and with proper supervision the number of RITAs is surely not a problem. The total number of RITAs has no bearing on the resources applied or the quality of service provided by each RITA. Costs to recipients of certificates are similarly unaffected.

In attempting to bring some sense to these guidelines, the achievements so far of the Australian Democrats have included the insertion of a minimum arm's length or conflict of interest provision. We have at least got to the stage where there is a standard form or certificate set by the NTB. Under our preferred guidelines, RITAs would forward a copy of each certificate to the NTB.

At the moment, the way the information is being forwarded leaves a lot to be desired. It could be possible that a RITA in Broome could be wrongly issuing certificates across Australia and this could go undetected until a summary is received or until there is a random audit. We believe it is possible--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting listening to the Australian Democrats this morning giving reasons for wanting the guidelines disallowed. Everything Senator Bell has said indicates why they should not have supported the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1990 in the first place. The reasons he has given this morning, and the problems he has outlined with the guidelines, flow from the Bill. They are the reasons why we opposed the Bill when it was debated in this chamber some five or six months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: We pointed out at the time that we were not opposed to the concept of training and education. Far from it, we totally supported it. But the speakers for the Opposition, myself included, pointed out at great length that the Government and the Democrats were bringing into effect an Act which was to come into being and come into operation on 1 July 1990 with no guidelines in existence for us to examine.

The Australian Democrats senator speaking this morning has indicated that it is now clear to them-it was clear to us at the time-that there had not been adequate consultation and there had not been adequate discussion and analysis of what the Government was trying to do to put it into effect properly. That has been borne out. The newspaper article that Senator Bell referred to claiming credit for their own position now, in fact, is really saying, `You shouldn't rush in with legislation and put it into effect until you know what you are doing.'.

He went on to say that we are agreeing with the Government. That is not the case. Sometimes there is a position in between. What the Democrats do not seem to have appreciated is that to disallow these guidelines at this stage leaves the Act in operation as from 1 July this year, with the Australian Taxation Office the sole arbiter of what should happen and how it operates. That can only be the worst possible option. The guidelines that we have are defective, as our speakers in other discussions have indicated, many of them as outlined by the Democrats, and I shall briefly refer to some of them. But if we do not have any guidelines, the Tax Office is totally unfettered by any regulations in its administration of this Act. Where does that leave the businesses that are already floundering around trying to operate with something that has been in existence for some months?

Certainly, the Government has agreed to a minor amendment that we have asked for. It has not in any way met all the objections that we outlined in May when the Bill was debated. That was why we wanted it defeated at that time, because we could foresee what is happening now. Somehow, that was not to be, because the Democrats were too determined to be with the Government at that time with no regard for the consequences later if the guidelines did turn out to be as bad as, in fact, they are.

We have identified numerous problems which would arise as a consequence of the legislation-we pointed them out at the time, and I shall briefly refer to them-not to mention, of course, the enormous impost this is placing on businesses at a time when they are suffering mightily. We hear daily of businesses going bankrupt because they are not able to continue in business in the present economic climate. But for those that are trying to struggle on, this has been imposed upon them as well. How does the Government think businesses have got enough money to be spending on this right now, at a time when they are putting people out of work? They are putting people off their jobs. Would it not be better to keep them in employment than to add this additional burden to businesses right now? It really is an additional form of payroll tax, and there are many people who are busily shedding jobs to take themselves below the guidelines.

We dealt with-and it has been referred to I think this morning-the onus of proof on an appeal, which rests with the employer, and the difficulties faced by employers meeting the requirements of the Bill. We referred at the time to such jobs as housemaid, and on-the-job training. We referred also to the exemption of the Commonwealth Government from prosecution for non-compliance, and the double standard that it was prepared to put in print and into legislation.

There was no allowance made for the situation of firms that run personnel services whose payrolls are artificially high because of the system whereby they receive the total wages from their clients, and then pay them on to their employees, who are employees only in the sense that they are being introduced to work. For a personnel firm of that kind the actual income is really quite modest, but it appears that it is particularly high. No allowance has been made for that.

There are only limited exemptions for charitable non-profit organisations. There is the prescriptive nature of the legislation which disregards totally the merits of on-the-job training which, in most instances, is the most beneficial training that one can get. Of course, as has already been mentioned by the Australian Democrats, there are the imprecise definitions. We pointed this out at the time.

I can only assume this morning that, if the guidelines had been available at the time that the Bill was debated, the Democrats would have voted against it, because they have already said this morning that what they see is wrong with it. What a pity it is that they could not see more clearly what would be the consequence of their rush to vote with the Government and bring this legislation into effect.

We suggested at the time that it would be better to refer this legislation to a standing committee so it could go through it and analyse all the problems that were raised, and the letters that we have all received dealing with the questions that flow from it. But, no, the Democrats would not even agree to defer it for a few months to allow these problems to be worked out and to allow the consultation that they now call for and complain was not held. We could have had a Bill that operates to the benefit of employees. We could have had a Bill with guidelines which let employers know what they are required to do. We could have had a Bill with guidelines that let the Taxation Office know what was expected of it. It is a great tragedy that we come to this situation.

I have referred to the fact that we have had discussions with the Minister. He has not agreed to what we believe should be included. I will be introducing a private member's Bill to change the regulations and bring into being some regulations which will make this work in a much better way. The Democrats then will have their opportunity to see that the things that they have talked about this morning can be rectified.

The Government has said that it will introduce additional guidelines as soon as possible to include the eligibility category of higher education and technical and further education institutions. I seek to incorporate in Hansard the draft of the guidelines which the Minister has indicated will be brought into effect so that people at least will know what will come into effect as soon as it has been properly gazetted.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has said that it will introduce legislation during the 1991 autumn session to redress the registration fee anomaly which currently prevents the registered industry training agents from charging a service fee when a training program is evaluated but deemed not eligible for certification. It has, as the Democrats have referred to, undertaken to review the guidelines after 12 months of operation. I would hope that they would be looked at much sooner than that because the problems are, I believe, quite critical.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a need to recognise the continuing deficiencies in the guidelines and the schedule which I, too, believe is sloppily drafted and does not answer the questions. We rang the Tax Office yesterday on a matter which I would have thought was quite simple. The response we got was, `That's a good question'. Here we are, talking about a matter where a Bill came into this place in May and into operation in July, and still in December we are being told that things are `a good question'. How much better it would have been, when we debated the Bill, to have sent it to a committee and got some of these things sorted out at the time. But, no, that was not to be because the Democrats wanted to rush on at that time and would not listen to any form of reason.

We are concerned at the fact that under the guidelines employer groups do not fit properly within their own defined categories. I refer particularly to category D which outlines eligibility of the professional and trade groups. It effectively precludes several significant organisations, such as the law societies of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and the Northern Territory from applying under that category because of the arbitrary limits imposed. I have a letter from the President of the Law Society of the ACT which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard. It is written to the Minister and is dated 12 October 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I have a look at that before we grant leave to incorporate it?

—Certainly. Admittedly, the organisations that I have referred to can still become registered industry training agents under category E, but only where no other body has already successfully applied and been registered. To give an example of the sort of problem which is likely to arise, if the ACT Law Society, which has fewer than 200 employers, wishes to be registered as a training agent for its members in Canberra, it will be able to do so only under category E if there is not already a training agent registered under one of the other categories. Of course, registered under the other categories will be the relevant law society body in each of the other States. Where does that leave us? If the Law Council of Australia has already registered as a training agent for all its member States, the ACT Law Society will not be able to register under category E.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that the only way that this would be possible would be for the ACT Law Society to request that, if and when a national body registers, it specifically ask that it not be registered in respect of the ACT. There is very good reason why each State law society or council or whatever would want and need to do its own training. The same applies here, but it is not to be. The Australian Labor Party is so hung up in numbers; large unions-these days big is beautiful with the Labor Party. The little groups such as the Law Society of the ACT and the Northern Territory clearly count for nothing. But we could not get an answer on that when we inquired about it. There was correspondence between the shadow Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister. I have a letter signed by Mr Dawkins, undated but received by hand on 23 November in Mr Howard's office. He gives a clarification of part of the definition of category E. It reads somewhat differently from what he says is the explanation and the definition. I seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard also, so what the Minister said will be on record.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —And for the earlier one.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is also granted with respect to the letter for which leave was sought earlier.

INTERJECT.PARA: THE LAW SOCIETY OF THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY
I write to draw your attention to one of the effects of the proposed guidelines for the registration of industry training agents (ITA) under the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act.

The guidelines being proposed by your Department will, I understand, make provision for professional associations to become registered ITA's if inter alia they provide ``coverage for a significant number of employers''. For a State or Territory, significant coverage will be coverage for a minimum of 200 employers.

The effect of the proposed requirement for 200 employers would be to prevent this Society being registered as an ITA, and prevent the 140 employers in the legal profession in the ACT from being able to have their training programmes approved by their own professional body. This professional association or Society is to a large extent responsible for the entry standards to the profession and by statute regulates the professional standards and performance of solicitors in the ACT. It has 100% coverage of the practising profession and is the only professional association in the ACT able to judge whether proposed training programmes for legal employees meet the requirements of the Training Guarantee Scheme. Yet the proposed guidelines would prevent the Society from exercising its logical role and function in training.

In order to overcome the numbers problem in the smaller States and Territories, this Society suggests that significant coverage could be expressed as a percentage. If a professional association covered, say, 75%, of employers it would have significant coverage.
The expression of significant coverage as a percentage would avoid the unintentional discrimination against the smaller States &Territories which is inherent in the present proposal.
Minister for Employment, Education and Training
Shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, Employment and Training

Your office has requested clarification of the wording of 6.6 of the Guidelines, Category E: General representative; in particular reasons for the wording, ``in relation to which no person included in Category A, B, C or D has Applied for registration as an agent'' whereas Category C says ``in relation to training that are not adequately met by an agent in Category A or Category B''.

Under the guidelines, the National Training Board will be unable to refuse registration to any applicant who meets the requirements of clauses 6 and 7. If a particular organisation does not meet the criteria in Category A, B, C or D it must be considered under Category E. It would fail to gain registration only if some applicant offered similar coverage and fell into Category A, B, C or D. If an organisation applied under Category A, B, C or D, but failed to meet the requirements of clause 7 the applicant would not meet the eligibility criteria to be registered, and any applicant in Category E, offering similar coverage and meeting the requirements of clause 7, would be registered.
In effect this means that if an industry is covered by an organisation applying within Category A, B, C or D no registrations will be considered under Category E.

TALK.START.PARA: — I thank the Senate. We hope that the Minister will address the discrepancy by removing the limits. That is the simple way of dealing with smaller organisations. The arbitrary representation limits will be a particular problem, not just in the two Territories that I have referred to but also perhaps in Tasmania, where some organisations that would want to operate as Tasmanian training agents would not have the required number of employers and would then be gobbled up by some other organisation. No doubt you, Mr Acting Deputy President, are very keenly interested in this matter. Hopefully, you will be able to bring some influence to bear.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unclear from the guidelines how the national training board will arbitrate in the event of clashes between organisations as I have referred to. That, too, is not clearly dealt with. Where there are two or more bodies which actually meet the criteria laid down, who will decide, and on what basis, which one of them is to be preferred as a training agent above the other applicants, who will then of course be forced to be subservient to it? I hope that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) will provide some answers to these problems when he deals with this matter this morning.

The Government should closely and critically monitor the operation of the agents over the next 12 months; we certainly will. We will be taking a close interest because of the number of people who have raised difficult issues with us. This is the same matter that we dealt with at the time that the Bill was passed. The problems have been foreseen and review will be required.

It is with very serious misgivings that we vote against the disallowance motion. I reiterate that we are not doing so because we support the Government's position. I think I have made it very clear from what I said this morning that we do not support the Government's position. Deficiencies in the guidelines reflect precisely what we expected they would because of what the Government was not able to tell us in answer to the questions we put during the committee stage of the debate on the Bill when it was before us previously.

But to allow this Bill, which came into effect on July 1 1990 because the Australian Democrats also wanted it in effect on July 1 1990, to continue with no guidelines, absolutely unfettered, with the Australian Taxation Office doing what it will with the employers, not being able to give answers and the like, is by far the worst proposition. It is perfectly clear that there have to be many changes to the regulations that we have. As I said, we will be doing our best to bring in a Bill to see that this comes about. However, in our view it is better that there be some guidelines, hopelessly deficient as they are, than for there be none at all at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disappointing that the Australian Democrats have moved to disallow the guidelines and related regulations for the registration of industry training agents. As a Government, we believe that the Democrats' action is precipitous. It is also contrary to the views of industry, employers and others with a close interest in the registered industry training agents, known as RITAs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990 provides for employers to seek certificates from RITAs, thus allowing employers to establish the eligibility of their training programs and types of expenditure before it is incurred. The certificates are then binding on the Commissioner of Taxation for that year and the following year. The legislation provides for the registration of industry training agents by the national training board. Since under the legislation the agents cannot be registered in the absence of guidelines, and since the guidelines are under threat of disallowance, it has not been appropriate for the national training board to proceed with the necessary administrative steps to ensure that the RITAs are put in place. This has meant that there have been delays, and further delays are unacceptable as businesses will not be able to take advantage of the RITA services in the initial year of the training guarantee, when the services would be most valuable.

We believe that the guidelines and the regulations, as they now stand, take account of advice provided by the national training board as required under the Act and that they reflect wide consultation with industry and other concerned groups, including the Democrats. Given the extensive nature of the consultations and the time constraints in getting the RITAs established, the Government does not consider it appropriate to further delay the regulations and guidelines at this late stage. We do, however, give some undertakings, and both Senator Bell and Senator Reid have reflected on those in their contributions this morning.

We acknowledge the constructive comments that have come from members of parliament. We also acknowledge the cooperation of the Opposition since the guidelines and regulations were tabled in the Parliament on 18 October. As a consequence, we are prepared to give certain undertakings concerning further provisions and review of the current instruments if those instruments are not disallowed here this morning, and it looks as though they will not be.

Senator Reid mentioned some undertakings that have been given and draft guidelines No. 2, which she tabled. For the sake of completeness, I seek leave to table the letter from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, to the Opposition which accompanied those guidelines setting out the context in which they should be assessed.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In referring to a point made by Senator Bell in respect of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I indicate that the Minister has responded to the Committee's correspondence and has undertaken to adopt amendments which go to three points raised by that Committee. The first point is the removal of the requirement for a registered industry training agent to answer questions to ensure consistency with section 98 of the Act. The second point which will be picked up by amendment will go to the provision of procedures including appointment of authorised officers and proof of identity concerning access to premises and records of a registered industry training agent in a manner consistent with section 98 of the Act. The third point to be picked up is the need for express powers for the training advisory body to cancel registration where a registered industry training agent is of unsound mind or is undergoing imprisonment.
—Minister, did you want to incorporate the letter you referred to earlier?
—I seek leave to incorporate the letter of 22 November that I have already tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

Minister for Employment, Education and Training

CANBERRA ACT 2600

Following our discussion concerning Industry Training Agents Guidelines, I have thought further about the question of the registration of higher education and technical and further education institutions.
