TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I go to the point of registration of universities and technical and further education (TAFE) institutions. As the Minister has confirmed with the Opposition, the Government is prepared to include public higher education and technical and further education institutions among the categories eligible for registration. Both the Minister and industry have a view that the responsibility for initiation and certification of training rests properly with industry. Therefore, it is doubtful that employers will seek certification from TAFEs and universities.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of concern, the Government is prepared to table new guidelines as soon as practicable to allow these institutions to be registered. In doing that, we are mindful of the fact that some State Ministers hold differing views about the appropriateness of registration of TAFE institutions as RITAs. For this reason the new guidelines will stipulate that the State or Territory Minister must agree in writing to an application for registration by a TAFE institution. The additional guidelines will be subject to formal consultations with the national training board, which the Minister is required to do under the Act.

In terms of RITA fees, the regulations currently provide for a fee only where a certificate is given by a RITA signifying that an employer's training program meets the eligibility requirements of the Act. The Government agrees that this may give rise to some problems as it will not permit RITAs to charge a service fee for considering an application where a certificate is refused. We are also further advised that the legislation does not permit the charging of a fee for this purpose and it will be necessary to amend the Act. Such amendment will be made in the autumn sittings. As has been mentioned, we are also giving an undertaking to review the guidelines after 12 months of operation.

A number of other criticisms have been raised about the guidelines. Senator Bell was concerned that categories in section 6 at pages 4 and 5 will unduly exclude persons who are appropriate to register as industry training agents. We have canvassed this point this morning but I have advice that no-one is prevented from seeking registration as an industry training agent. A person applying will be registered if that person is in one of the categories in section 6 and goes on to meet the criteria in section 7. Thus, the national training board cannot prevent any person from applying and must register a person who meets the requirements of sections 6 and 7.

It is worth while restating that particular organisations which do not meet the criteria in categories A, B, C or D must be considered under category E. This is spelled out in the correspondence to the Opposition. An organisation would fail to gain registration only if an applicant offered similar coverage and fell into categories A, B, C or D. If an organisation applied under categories A, B, C or D but failed to meet the requirements of section 7, the applicant would not meet the eligibility criteria to be registered. Any applicant in category E, offering similar coverage and meeting the requirements of section 7, would be registered. I am sure honourable senators can understand that. In effect, this means that if an industry is covered by an organisation applying within categories A, B, C or D, no registrations will be considered under category E.

Senator Bell has also objected to the guidelines setting out the information required from an applicant before registration as an agent. I ask the Senate to note that the schedule took account of advice from the national training board as well as the Government's view that the information provided by applicants should be adequate for the board to carry out its registration and monitoring functions.

I refer to the regulations on which there has been some comment. The Government recognises that an amendment to the Act would be required to permit persons to be charged for registering as industry training agents. The Government intends to produce such an amendment in the autumn session. I also ask the Senate to note that the fee of $200 per certificate reflects consultations with the national training board and industry.

As I have indicated, I think that the Government has agreed to suitable changes to the instruments to be introduced as soon as practicable. We have also given undertakings as to the guidelines, regulations and amendments to the Act. In the light of this, and given the very strong concerns to have the training agents in place as soon as possible, I trust that the Senate will reject this disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I was listening with considerable interest, hoping to find some indication that there would be a recognition of what we are on about here, but it was not forthcoming. If this motion of disallowance were successful today, it is not true that we would then have the Act and its operation with the Australian Taxation Office being the sole arbiter. This certainly could happen but the Government would still have the opportunity to introduce additional guidelines. It has taken five months to get this far. As Senator Reid has quite rightly pointed out, there has not been a great deal of urgency attached to what has been offered today.

SPEECH.PARA: I take exception to the inference in the speech by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) that there is some degree of blame to be attached to the Australian Democrats for the delay so far. The documents were tabled on 18 October and the requisite number of sitting days has passed. The discussion is happening today-no sooner, and no later as a result of anything that the Democrats have done. We introduced a notice of motion on the eighteenth to give the Government the opportunity to further discuss and to further amend. Of course, the Government has done that. We have evidence that there has been some modification to the Government's original proposal. If it can modify one or two things, it can modify half a dozen others.

We are hoping to disallow these guidelines-not guidelines per se; these particular ones-which the Opposition has agreed are manifestly inadequate, totally confusing and not helping the argument at all. They do not help employers to determine their obligation under the Act, how they satisfy that obligation and how they present to their employees a proper training program. As Senator Reid has quite rightly said, the Australian Taxation Office is not too sure about it anyway. We would hope that the Government could accept the mandate, the responsibility, to present guidelines which simplify the matter.

But no, we have this mumbo jumbo and-I am disappointed with the Opposition for the position it has taken on this matter-we are told that it is better to have a useless tool than to have nothing. We would have nothing at all if, in his petulance, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, lived up to the indication he gave to us initially that if we made a fuss, we should forget it; the Government would not bother with RITAs at all. If that petulance is an indication of the Government's true attitude and lack of commitment to training, I feel very sorry for the future of this country. On the other hand, if the Government is truly interested in devising a set of guidelines which will assist employers, it still has the opportunity to bring in guidelines that work. I reject the assertion that it would leave the Tax Office as the sole arbiter. It is in the Government's hands to address the problems which have been identified by both Senator Reid and me this morning. It is certainly not a responsibility which I will accept. I will not accept the responsibility for the Government's inability to come up with a set of guidelines to achieve the Government's aim.

I say again that the Government has demonstrated that it is willing to modify these guidelines to some extent to ensure that they get the tacit support of the Opposition so that they can stumble through this chamber. The Government has been able to modify as much as it thinks is necessary-in other words, as much as it thinks it will get away with-without addressing the real concerns of industry that have been expressed to us over this matter. It has done no more than is necessary to allow these guidelines to stumble through this chamber and, by default, arrive on the doorstep of the employers who need succinct, clear and useful guidelines.

We will see a lot of disappointed employers who, I have already warned, will probably take a lead from the Minister and say, `We cannot be bothered. We will not try very hard-we will pay the tax anyway'. Those employers, who may have been interested in training, quite rightly will be exasperated and totally unsatisfied with the Government's attitude when they are confronted with this mumbo jumbo.

We were just informed by the Minister that the Government reacted very rapidly to the views of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. The Government obviously was concerned about the power of that committee to embarrass it. The fact that little regard is being paid to our concerns shows that this Government is really only interested in what it can get away with. It did not think it could get away with ignoring the concerns brought to its attention by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee but it did think it could afford to ignore our concerns if it just cooked up a cosy deal with the Opposition. I am really disappointed that the Opposition has not shown a lot of backbone here. The fact is that we could insist that these regulations are inadequate and the Government could accept the responsibility for introducing amended additional guidelines which would make them work.

There has been some sort of explanation offered to Senator Reid's concern about the sorts of problems that are associated with a small professional association, such as the Australian Capital Territory Law Association. I did not understand the Minister's explanation and I am sure it did not address the concern expressed by Senator Reid. That concern is shared by some several hundred groups; it is shared by nearly all the employer groups in Tasmania which would not qualify under the arbitrary numbers that have been trotted out by the preparers of this scheme so as somehow to limit the numbers of registered industry training agents who would be applying.

In Tasmania, of course, there are very few employers or employer groups which would qualify under the numbers scheme. The number of groups in Tasmania which would qualify under category E-and this has been pointed out by Senator Reid in respect of the Australian Capital Territory-would be drastically reduced because of the numbers which have already applied for nationwide coverage. Any body in Australia which applied for and was successfully granted coverage to represent a profession would usurp the right of a Tasmanian body, which might also have applied, to represent its employers. That problem could easily be dismissed by the removal of the numbers themselves.

The real criterion is the ability of the registered industry training agent to deliver quality advice within the industry area in which that agent proposes to operate, and that is covered by stages 7.1, 7.2 and 8.1. If we concentrate on that area and remove this numbers criterion, we would have regulations which might be capable of working. But that seems to escape the Minister. There seems to be no understanding at all of how these things would operate.

I say again that I am most disappointed that the Opposition could not show some strength and join the Democrats. Our motion is to disallow the proposed guidelines and regulations. Without further ado, I think we should see what happens when the question is put.
Question put:
That the motions (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 5 December 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. Senator McLean has moved an amendment to clause 12. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we were discussing this proposed amendment last night Senators Crane and Walters passed comment about it. I would like to respond to some of their comments. I remind the Committee that this is a critical amendment--
—Mr Chairman, on a point of order: when the debate adjourned last night, I was half-way through my comments. Will I have the opportunity to finish those comments in due course?
—Certainly.

—I remind the Committee that the amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats is probably the one that has attracted the most public reaction. The clause that we intend to amend would place the obligation on unions to move towards a membership figure of 20,000. I commented previously that the Democrats saw that as creating a bad psyche out there in the electorate and that we believed that a lower target figure would evoke a more positive response in the community at large, and even within the union movement itself.

SPEECH.PARA: If I could draw an analogy, this is a little like selecting a gear on a bicycle. The series of options is open and it is a question of which gear will have the greatest effect. The Government is simply proposing a gear of 20,000. We believe that that has some negative aspects to it and that it would be more effective to aim lower, but perhaps in a quicker timeframe.

In regard to comments made by Senator Crane last night, with respect, I believe that he misunderstood what we are intending. Frankly, I do not believe that the figure is of any great consequence other than to induce a response. Senator Crane elaborated on the membership of a range of unions. He said that some unions have memberships in the order of so many thousand and so on. I do not believe that that is of any consequence. In the final analysis, I do not think that we can predict the outcome of this. As I said earlier, I believe that there will be a number of unions with a few hundred members and a number of unions with a few hundred thousand members. The configuration at the moment is of no consequence at all. It ignores the fact that many unions are in the process of moving towards amalgamation anyway by themselves, without this induction process. To cite a range of unions being at the moment of particular membership configurations contributes nothing and suggests to me some misunderstanding of the process.

Senator Walters talked about big unions, bashed the unions, and generally went off in an emotional tirade about the union movement at large. In my time here I have been greatly impressed by Senator Walters in many respects. I admire her tenacity, she is courageous, she is incredibly persistent and she believes in certain things and pursues them. That makes for a very formidable adversary. But on occasions she is also illogical and on occasions she in fact distorts and selects-and that perhaps makes her even more of an adversary because, when one gets the combination of the admirable qualities with illogicality and distortion, it makes for a pretty formidable challenge but does not contribute very positively to the debate about improved legislation. She did not make a positive contribution. She just went off on an emotional tirade. We saw once again the closed-mindedness and the bias that are so frequently apparent in her contributions. I admire Senator Walters's tenacity and courage and those other positive attributes, but I had no respect for her contribution to the debate last night. I am simply drawing attention to the fact that Senator Crane has missed the point. We are simply suggesting that this amendment will achieve greater effect rather than less effect than the figure proposed by the Government.

I shall return to the question that Senator Cook posed at the close of the debate last night, and we were seeking clarification as to whether or not the Opposition will support this amendment. In comments made by Senator Crane, he suggested that the Opposition would not support it. The effect of that will leave the Government with 20,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to state the Opposition's position in relation to clause 12. Clause 12 is really the most critical clause of this Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. It creates this new process of amalgamation, the object of which we debated at great length in the second reading debate. It will increase the minimum numbers for union membership from the present figure of 1,000 to a figure of 20,000. That is an enormous increase in the minimum size of union membership from the 1,000 presently provided in the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to a figure of 20,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats, to our great surprise-and I will deal shortly with why we are surprised-have moved that the figure, instead of being 20,000, should be 10,000. Senator McLean has now made it clear that, if that amendment does not succeed, he would then support the 20,000 figure. So the Opposition was even more surprised at the view of the Democrats that they would be supporting the Government's figure of 20,000, and I shall deal with that shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are figures of consequence.

—Well, Senator McLean does not think it has got any consequences, but we differ greatly from him. I would think that the Government also differs greatly from him because it sees the significance of a figure of 20,000, and so do we. It is only the Democrats who fail to understand what this is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's position is that we are opposed to any change in the present provision of 1,000 in the legislation. We dealt in the second reading debate with the reasons why we are opposed to this, and I am not going to repeat all their arguments in the committee stage because I think they were fully thrashed out in the second reading debate, and also because so far in this committee debate many of them have been repeated. So we are essentially opposed to this clause.

However, because we do see the considerable significance in these numbers and if we are going to fail in relation to our principal position, then we would prefer 10,000 to 20,000. We are seeking to achieve that as a second best position, although we are opposed to it. The Government has said it will support that amendment of 10,000, and therefore the Opposition will support it only in the sense that it is better than 20,000. However, we will maintain our opposition to the figure of 10,000 by voting against the amended clause. That is the Opposition's position. It is a perfectly logical position, and I hope Senator McLean can understand it.

What we find difficult to understand about the Democrats position is that the 1,000 minimum figure was inserted in the original Act by the motion of Senator McLean on behalf of the Democrats when the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 was before this Senate only two years ago. On 29 September 1988, in the committee stage of that Bill-we have already referred to this before-Senator McLean moved to leave out the figure of 3,000, which was the Government's proposal in that Bill, and to insert the figure of 1,000. The Opposition supported this amendment and it was successful. So that is how the figure of 1,000 for union minimum membership appears in the present Act.

The figure of 1,000 was the recommendation of the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. The Democrats were very upset-and so were we for that matter-that the Government had tinkered around with the Hancock recommendations by making it 3,000. So, we supported Senator McLean's amendment to reduce it to 1,000. In the debate Senator McLean said:

. . . we offer no objection to the process of amalgamation. However, we think it is important that we proceed slowly and responsibly and in a way which accommodates the needs of presently small unions.
He went on to say in support of the figure of 1,000:
This figure would provide the opportunity to meet the needs of smaller unions, who could amalgamate rather than rely upon special circumstances, exemptions in the legislation.
He also went on to say:
Small unions have experimented with amalgamation unsuccessfully, some of them finding that very large unions cannot represent the interests of a small specialised group as well as they would like.
Finally he said:

We therefore feel that the figure of 3,000 is likely to lead to ideological family of unionists whereas a requirement for a minimum of 1,000 members is more likely to be specifically based and therefore to produce the type of union structure that is able to operate more functionally in the workplace.

That is what the views of the Democrats and Senator McLean were only two years ago. I wonder what has changed. Senator McLean is making very clear in this amendment, and what I just read out about what he said in support of his amendment in 1988, that in fact the minimum numbers of the union are vitally important in this whole question of amalgamation. The whole case two years ago, as I have just read out, was that these are vital questions, and there was a very vital difference, in the Democrats view, between 3,000 and 1,000.

Here today he is arguing, as he did yesterday, that numbers do not mean anything. The numbers meant a lot to the Democrats two years ago. They meant a lot to Senator McLean, who was then and still is their spokesman. Senator McLean has persuaded the Opposition, as he did two years ago, and we are still of the view that the numbers are very important indeed. Anyway, we do not need to have Senator McLean's authority, whatever it amounts to, in view of the total inconsistencies of the Democrats and their attitude to this vital legislation, and we would not want to rely too heavily on their arguments.

The fact is that the numbers mean a great deal because it is this figure-and the failure of unions to meet the figure of 20,000, or 10,000 or indeed 1,000 at the moment-which triggers the process of amalgamation through the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It is the unions that do not meet the minimum membership figure by their own efforts at amalgamation, or disinclination for amalgamation, or whatever. If the unions do not meet those targets in the legislation, the unions themselves have the weight put on them well and truly, and they have to show special circumstances.

We will come to a debate later about what `special circumstances' could mean. I understand the Democrats have caved in completely to the Government on that one, because it had a proposed amendment which it put to the Opposition. I do not mind talking about these things because Senator McLean was only too ready to expose discussions that he had with the Opposition, and he misrepresented in many ways what those discussions were. I can tell the Committee that Senator McLean had considerable amendments proposed on this question of what would be special circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are speaking to the next amendment now.

—I am speaking about the way in which Senator McLean has behaved in this whole matter. He has now dropped all these amendments; they will not get his support any more even though the Democrats proposed them to the Opposition and we said we would support them because we are very concerned about the pressure that was to put on unions to conform with the Government's policy toward amalgamations on a large scale and the reduction in the number of unions to 20.

SPEECH.PARA: It is ridiculous to say that these figures mean nothing. They are vital to the operation of the Government's policy. The fact that the Government has a figure of 20,000 here is very significant. We are opposed to that figure; we are opposed to a figure of 10,000, a figure of 5,000 or a figure of 3,000. We believe that the figure should remain as it is, and even then it may be a bit high. When the Opposition comes to propose its own policy in this area in the form of legislation we may have a lower figure, but that is a debate for another day. At the moment we believe that the figure of 1,000 should remain as it is. There is a process in the present Bill for amalgamation based on that figure and the Opposition believes that that is good enough, as indeed the Democrats clearly believed two years ago. The Democrats felt then, as Senator McLean said, that the whole process should proceed slowly and responsibly. That is the view that we adopt in relation to this clause, and I have explained the position we will take in relation to the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before continuing from where I was in my remarks last night, I wish to pick up a couple of points which have come through in the debate this morning. I will not go over the ground that Senator Durack has covered, but I find it quite incredible that Senator McLean comes into this place today and tries to be reasonable and rational after the tirade he delivered last night. He accused Senator Walters of being a nice person but irrational, but I will leave it to Senator Walters to deal with that.

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly want to deal with his comments that I had misunderstood the situation. If I have a misunderstanding about the situation, I pose the question: what does Senator McLean have when he has an amendment before this chamber to alter the figure to 10,000 and yet continually says that the number is of no consequence? I find that totally irrational. Of course the number is of some consequence. The fact that a number is there and that it is a large number means that enormous pressure will be placed on the smaller unions to amalgamate. That pressure will continue regardless of whether amalgamation is for the benefit of members of a particular union.

Having said that, I will deal with the things I was going to deal with last night. Senator Sherry in an interjection threw down a challenge to us to provide examples of where thuggery had occurred. I have decided to take up that challenge because I think it is very important in this debate. I will give three examples. The first is dealt with in an article in the West Australian of 30 November 1990. The article was written by Shaun Menegola. Although I will quote only the paragraphs from that article which are applicable to this debate, the article is here for any honourable senator who wishes to read it. It is headed `Unionist admits assault in toilet' and reads:
Transport Workers' Union official James McGiveron has admitted assaulting former Perth radio personality Barry Martin in the toilet of a North Bridge restaurant last July.
Mr Singleton, who was representing Mr McGiveron, was reported in the article as saying:

. . . the incident stemmed from Martin's involvement in a union election campaign for a man standing against long-time TWU secretary John O'Connor. Accounts from the campaign had wrongly been sent to the TWU and to the WA Trotting Club.

My second example concerns the situation in Western Australia in relation to the amalgamation of the Professional Divers Association of Australia and the Seamens Union of Australia. It concerns one Gary Ihnen, who is the Federal Secretary of the Professional Divers Association. He has been making phone calls to union members threatening to blow off their kneecaps if they do not concede to the demands made of them. My third example concerns a situation in which I was involved, the dispute in 1982 regarding the use of wide combs. It concerns Bob White and his family, who are shearing contractors in the town of Blayney in New South Wales. In order to protect Bob White and his family, the police in Blayney had to put them into the gaol because of the threats to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us not forget the burning down of shearing sheds.

—Yes, there were a number of other incidents. However, when we have these challenges, it is important to recognise such occurrences. They have gone on in the past, they are going on now and they will continue to go on.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to a couple of other points. Firstly, I will deal with the Minister's suggestion about the formation of a food union in the future. If that food union were to involve the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) and its current activities-which I will deal with in a moment-I suggest that we would all starve. However, the Minister might starve before I do. In his comments last night the Minister said that I had an obsession about the meat industry. I make no secret of being obsessed about that industry in its current situation. I respect a number of unions and some of their activities and responsibilities, but I hope that nobody in this place respects the AMIEU or its current behaviour. I will quickly run through a couple of the figures. Nearly $100m worth of export earnings has been lost since the dispute started and the number of meat export works in Victoria has reduced from about 19 five years ago to the present 12.

In all of this it is the workers, the producers, our customers and our current account which are affected. If I have an obsession about this industry across the board, I will continue to have that obsession. In the current situation in our meat export industry, with the efforts being made, for example, through the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks to get some sanity into world trade, I find it absolutely incredible that we are handing markets to those competitors that we are trying to get to reduce their protection. It is an absolutely ludicrous situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman: I frankly do not see the relevance to this amendment of Senator Crane's comments.
—I am listening very closely to what Senator Crane is saying and I presume that he is concluding his remarks.

—I was commenting on some remarks that were made in this chamber last night before I spoke. I have virtually finished doing that, so I will move on. My obsession about a union-or anybody else-who breaks the law to meet its own ends will continue. I do not care whether it is the AMIEU or anybody else. That has been well and truly documented and is on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the comment in the debate last night by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) that discussions had been held with the union movement and employer organisations about this matter. I would like to bring to the attention of the Committee another press article, this time in the Australian Financial Review of 26 November 1990, headed `Government reported to ILO'. That action was taken by the Confederation of Australian Industry, which has long been recognised by the current Government as being the peak employer organisation in this country.

The Confederation has made it quite clear that it does not accept or like this particular legislation and does not believe that it will deliver the types of benefits which it is claimed it will. Also, I must report that from my own discussions with employer organisations-I do not claim to have talked to every one of them-not one has lobbied me to support the numbers that we are now talking about in this legislation, nor the preference clauses which it introduces.

I would like to conclude my comments in this debate at this point by saying that I find it quite irrational-in fact, I find it unbelievable-that we have a situation where Senator McLean, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, proposes to move from the figure of 1,000 to 10,000 and at the same time argues in the debate that it has no consequence. I find that absolutely incredible. Of course it has a consequence. It will mean that, as I outlined in a particular case in Western Australia, enormous pressure will be put on unions in an area where they are behaving quite rationally and responsibly now and are in fact doing a good job. It will mean that the power of the union movement and the Australian Council of Trade Unions will be put in fewer hands. In the longer term that will lead to more industrial disruption in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) a question which he may well have answered at the committee stage. I apologise to the Committee for not being here for some of the time it considered the legislation last night, but I needed to attend an Amnesty International meeting. I ask the Minister: what number of current registered organisations will be affected by the clause as it stands; what number of registered organisations will be affected by the clause should the Australian Democrats' amendment succeed; and what are the names of those organisations?
—Is he going to give an answer?
—I will answer the question in a minute, if I may. The names of the organisations make quite a long list.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has asked a very important question in relation to this clause. Clause 12 is really the key part of the legislation which we are debating because it is the clause which amends the principal Act to substitute the number 20,000 for the present 1,000 as the minimum allowable size for a trade union. This will affect an enormous number of existing trade unions. Senator Harradine has asked a very relevant question and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) could not answer it.
—Don't be stupid, the Minister will answer it in a minute.
—He was given the opportunity to answer it and he could not do so. I will deal with you in a minute, Senator McLean.
—Order! Will you please address your remarks through the Chair, Senator Chapman.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I will deal with Senator McLean in a minute. This legislation in general, but most importantly this clause which seeks to establish the Government's policy of mega-unions, has its origins in the document entitled Future Strategies for the Trade Union Movement published in May 1987 and another document entitled Australia Reconstructed which was also published in that year. It is simply a recipe for further increasing and entrenching the power of trade unions within our industrial relations system. These changes are not about improving productivity or improving the conduct of industrial relations; they are simply designed to create, in line with the desires of this Government's Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) masters, mega-unions with a minimum membership of 20,000. This represents an increase of some 2,000 per cent on the current minimum allowable size for trade unions-a massive increase which will not be more conducive to the development and maintenance of effective industrial relations processes in any industry. The Government's rationale for larger and fewer unions is fatally flawed.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, this clause will not, by seeking to enforce a minimum size of 20,000 members, ensure the rational development of a more appropriate trade union structure which is what is required as we move into the twenty-first century. Currently, there are about 300 or so registered trade unions and the Government, and particularly its ACTU masters, want to see this number reduced to 20 mega-unions-a cut of some 93 per cent. Presently, only 45 unions have a membership in excess of 20,000. Of course, that again highlights the importance of Senator Harradine's question as to how many existing unions will be affected by the passage of this clause.

What will happen after 28 February is that, in accordance with this legislation, unions registering after that date will be required to have a membership of 20,000. Currently, registered smaller unions will be allowed a further two years, after which if they fail to reach this magical figure of 20,000 they will have to show cause why they should be allowed to stay registered. Why should the onus of proof be on an existing organisation-a small union-to justify its continued existence and survival?

That is the point which we raise against Senator McLean's claim last night that numbers are of little consequence. Senator McLean says that these numbers which are being laid down in this legislation are merely targets to be achieved and are of little real consequence. The reality is that this legislation lays down these figures not as targets, but as minimum numbers that must be achieved. If they are not achieved the onus of proof is on the existing small union to show cause why it should continue to exist. It is a most difficult process for that small union to go through to justify its continued existence beyond two years hence and, of course, a quite unjustifiable imposition to put on such a small union. So the Democrats should clearly recognise that this figure is not a target; it is a mandatory requirement which it will be very difficult to avoid.

We need to recognise that, contrary to what this clause will provide, size is absolutely no guarantee to establishing the internal efficiency of any union. I believe it would be nothing more than committing national suicide to encourage and create an umbrella and cumbersome conglomerate of unions which could fall into the hands and control of a small group and be subject to the sort of union thuggery which Senator Crane gave evidence of a few moments ago. He gave several examples, from the many that have been evident over a number of years, of the application of union thuggery by a small controlling group.

The Liberal and National parties wholeheartedly support the restructuring of unions, but we want to see that done on the basis of enterprise unions and enterprise agreements. That is the fundamental basis of the coalition's approach to industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if unions don't want that?

—The unions will have a choice under our industrial relations structure; or at least, more importantly, the individual members of the union will. That is where our focus lies. Union members will have a choice as to what sort of industrial relations structure they want to apply in their workplace.
—And if they don't want yours?

—They can remain with the present system and that is clearly spelled out in our industrial relations policy. As the Minister, you ought to know that. If you have not had a close look at our policy I suggest that you do so.
—Your policy--
—Order! I ask both the Minister and Senator Chapman to address their remarks through the Chair.

—I suggest that the Minister have a close look at our industrial relations policy. He might learn something from it and be ready to apply some of its principles. The other difficulty the Opposition has with this clause is that to establish any minimum size for a trade union, including the one imposed in the existing legislation, let alone the proposal under this amending Bill for a minimum size of 20,000, clearly violates the fundamental principle of freedom of association and is a direct contravention of convention No. 87 of the International Labour Organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: So we see that in putting up this legislation-especially clause 12-the Government is simply tightening the anti-competitive, monopolistic stranglehold of the trade unions in our community. The Government is endorsing the concept that big is beautiful and it seems to have forgotten that big is also most unwieldy and unresponsive to individual needs and requirements and, by definition, concentrates power in the hands of a very few.

Mega-unions that do not have to compete for membership will have no necessity to bend over backwards to look after and effectively service their members. Amalgamations of unions into 20 or so mega-unions will not lessen demarcation disputes. The only way to do this is through an enterprise based structure, as I mentioned a few moments ago. The minimum size requirements initiated by this legislation will actively prevent enterprise based unions from coming into existence. So there are a number of serious defects and serious consequences for Australia if this clause, which the Government has put up, is passed. As I said, it would prevent forever the emergence of enterprise based unions.

The Business Council of Australia study called Enterprise-based Bargaining Units-A Better Way of Working argues very strongly that there should be fewer unions within enterprises or industry, and we strongly support that view. It also provides significant evidence, particularly on the basis of a survey which it has conducted, that amalgamations of small unions, as this clause will require, will not in any significant way reduce the number of major unions among its member enterprises. In other words, the amalgamation of unions which will be forced by this legislation will not reduce in any significant way the number of unions in any particular workplace with which an employer has to deal and, therefore, will not necessarily lead to fewer demarcation disputes.

The Australian Chamber of Manufactures has shown that minimum sizes seem more likely to reduce the number of federally registered industry focused unions than they are to reduce the number of federally registered craft unions. In other words, this clause will compound the difficulties that we already have because of the craft structure of our unions, rather than having an industry or, as we would prefer to see, an enterprise based structure for our unions.

Furthermore, the amalgamations that will be required to meet the 20,000 minimum will not solve the problem of multiple coverage in workplaces. Again I refer to the Business Council survey, which showed that the 12 top unions which have membership in Business Council members' workplaces would only be reduced to nine under the amalgamation proposals required through the passage of this clause. For example, the recent rubber workers and storemen and packers amalgamation would reduce the number of unions in only 4 per cent of plants. A more significant amalgamation, such as that proposed by the Australian Workers Union and the Federated Ironworkers Union, would reduce the number of unions in just 16 per cent of the plants. So much more is needed than the approach which has been initiated in this legislation by the Government, at the command and with the support of the ACTU, if we are going to achieve amalgamations that are linked to productivity instead of amalgamations linked to the development of union power as an end in itself. This is why the Opposition opposes clause 12, in particular, of the legislation.

We are also opposed to the amendment that has been put up by Senator McLean, which seeks to substitute a figure of 10,000 for that of 20,000 proposed by the Government. As I said a few moments ago, Senator McLean, in his remarks yesterday, was of the view that numbers did not really matter at all. I have already explained to the Committee why the numbers that we put in this legislation do matter. More importantly than that perhaps, Senator McLean really did not justify, either in the arguments in his speech yesterday in moving his amendment, or in the earlier second reading debate, the reasons why the Democrats were putting up this amendment and why this amendment was so much better than the Government's approach.

One can only conclude from Senator McLean's remarks on both occasions that either he has severe amnesia or he has been pushed by the new members of the Democrats who came in at the last election and who are causing his Party to lurch even further to the Left to support the Government's approach to industrial relations, whereas only two years ago they would not have a bar of it in relation to minimum union size. Senator McLean put the view that amalgamations of unions should be encouraged and accelerated and, through his amendment, believed that this should be achieved through a preferred minimum size of 10,000 members compared with the Government's proposed 20,000. Again, he does not really seem too fussed about size, because he does not see the significance of the legislation in imposing this minimum size.

I remind the Committee that Senator McLean, as the industrial relations spokesman for the Australian Democrats, two years ago moved an amendment to the Industrial Relations Bill, an amendment which reduced the minimum union membership requirement from the Government's then proposed 3,000 to just 1,000, and an amendment which this Opposition supported. Although, as I have said, we believe there should not be any minimum size requirements on unions, we supported that as the lesser of two evils compared with the Government's 3,000 at that time. I remind the Committee that in moving that amendment Senator McLean said:

. . . the Australian Democrats saw these amendments as constructive and responsible in that we have been approached by a considerable number of small unions who argue that they are unable to find, and will remain unable to find even within the three-year period allowed for adjustment, compatible unions with which to amalgamate successfully.

We draw attention to the fact that our revised suggested figure of 1,000 as the minimum required limit for employer and employee organisations is simply in line with the recommendations of the Hancock Committee of review . . . we are not convinced that in the interim 15 months there has arisen a need for the Government or the ACTU to argue the non-acceptability of 1,000.

Of course, that was the original proposal earlier of the Government itself in its 1987 Industrial Relations Bill. The Democrats, who only two years ago saw 1,000 as an acceptable minimum size, now believe 10 times that is an acceptable minimum size-quite illogically.

TALK.START.PARA: —So that I persist with accuracy, I will cite the most recent Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) categorisation of federally registered unions published in June 1989, which were: unions with membership under 1,000, 38; between 1,000 and 3,000, 25; between 3,000 and 5,000, 15; and between 5,000 and 10,000, 12, making a total of 90. They represent 14.27 per cent of the total union membership in Australia. According to this series, 90 unions covered 14.27 per cent of the total union membership. Those figures are at variance with the figures I have given to Senator Harradine, but the number of unions with membership between 10,000 and 20,000 is 13, according to the ABS series.

—I thank the Minister. I do not intend to canvass my views on this subject, because they have been stated in this chamber over a number of years, and I am sure that the Committee will be very grateful for that. I simply indicate that I will be opposing the clause. I believe that the proposition by the Australian Democrats is second best and I will be supporting that proposition but, when the clause is then put, I will be opposing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to some of the comments that have been made by members of the Opposition. They have quoted from my speech back in 1988 when we were considering what is now the principal Act. There is logic to the Opposition's argument-it is the logic of divide and conquer.
—It is the logic of freedom of association.

—I will come to freedom of association in a moment. That is the fundamental logic. If we accept that as the starting point, everything flows logically from it, as has been said by the Opposition. I just happen to reject that as the starting proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Opposition are suggesting that one should lock into a position and never move from it. They are saying that the position we advocated when the principal Act was debated in 1988 is the position we should be in forever. That is rubbish, and they know it is rubbish. We live in a changing world, and we are prepared to acknowledge that.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you have not justified it.

—I am just coming to it. One of the things that those opposite did ignore, and have ignored in our position in relation to industrial relations all the way along, is that we, like them, have been very concerned about individuals and small unions. The next amendment is all about attending to exemption-strengthening the exemption provisions.
—You have gone to water on that.
—We have not gone to water. Those opposite do not know what the situation is. They are trying to crystal ball.
—You are the one who complained about lack of consultation.
—Order!

—The situation is that the Australian Democrats have always attempted to strengthen the exemption provisions. We were lobbied very heavily three years ago in relation to exemption provisions and we accommodated the needs of that lobby at the time. In our opinion, there is clearly less concern out there now. We have been lobbied far less intensively, but we still have addressed ourselves in the next amendment in an attempt to strengthen the exemption provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has chosen to ignore the fact that we have always identified with it in that process-the protection of the individual. In addressing the next amendment, I will reinforce our position in that respect. Frankly, we are not prepared to adopt the bias and the closed mindedness of the Opposition. We have to be open-minded and we have to have an open door. We have done both, and had both those things. The outcome of it is a series of amendments, and this is one of them.

There is concern amongst small unions that they may be forced into what has probably been appropriately described as `shotgun weddings', and we share that concern, but it is resolved best by strengthening and clarifying the exemption process. It is resolved best through the ballot box by the members saying that they favour, or do not favour, a particular amalgamation.

I do not believe that this legislation in large detracts from that process of democracy; in fact, it strengthens it. If honourable senators look at the restated objects of the Act and read the Bill as a whole, they will see that there is a clear intention on the part of the Government to communicate to the Industrial Relations Commission and those responsible in this process that the democratic process must be preserved.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish!
—It is not rubbish. Senator Walters has not read the Bill and she is closed minded and she is enunciating bias. I suppose that will be her situation for the whole time she is in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: We support the process of amalgamation. It has been a recommendation of five major reports to this Parliament over a decade. It is a question of how it is achieved. In the process of achieving it, protecting the interests of small unions is paramount in our minds, as is protecting the interests of individuals. We stick by the point that a precise figure really is only a choice of a gear by which to get there.

For Senator Chapman to stand there and make all of these crystal balling predictions about what the outcome will be frankly is just sheer hypothesis. Nobody knows what the outcome will be, because nobody knows how effective the process will be, nobody knows how adequate the exemption provisions will be, and nobody can anticipate what the members of those organisations will state in the ballot box. This is just rubbish that has been projected by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean has very obviously changed his attitude in a period of two years. It is not just a change of attitude in the margin; it is a change of attitude from a membership of 1,000 to 10,000. It is a complete reversal of attitude.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take a couple of minutes of the Committee's time to remind it of a statement that was made by Joe Thompson, a former Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will be good.
—Senator Burns should just listen. Joe Thompson said:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst on the surface a proposal to reduce the number of unions seems sensible and appropriate, a closer look reveals the potential for unions organized largely on political lines and no likely reduction in demarcation and membership disputes. The net result could well be to give the ACTU greater power to pursue whatever political objectives its Executive decided upon-and an increased potential for large-scale disputes based on such objectives.
He went on as follows:

A recent ballot for amalgamation of the membership of the Building Workers' Industrial Union (BWIU) and the Federated Engine Drivers' and Firemen's Association (FEDFA) narrowly overturned the proposal.

The name planned for the union was `The Construction, Mining and Energy Workers' Union.' Foundation of such a union would have opened the way for a national union crossing the whole broad spectrum of industry, including not only building and construction, but mining and extraction, power generation, and coal loaders as well as the operation of all types of cranes, including overhead cranes and all forms of mobile equipment. It was intended that, following the amalgamation of the BWIU and the FEDFA, there would then be an amalgamation with the Miners' Federation and the Timber Workers' Union. In short, one union would have had the potential to institute stoppages extending far beyond the building industry.

This would have meant that the whole nation could have been halted by an executive decision to close down our power stations; or our coal exports could have been halted by closing off all our coal-loaders. These are only some of the things which could have occurred with an amalgamation of this type.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, it has nothing to do with this Bill. This Bill has an objective of industry unions to prevent that sort of thing. Read the Bill.

—I have read the Bill. The Bill says that we are going to move to a minimum membership of 20,000 for registration. The Australian Democrats have moved for 10,000, and they call this democracy at work. We have, as the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has just said, 92 unions with under 1,000 members. The Democrats are forcing those unions, despite what Senator McLean says, to amalgamate unless they can satisfy special circumstances. The clause says:

SPEECH.PARA: If, on exercising the power conferred by subsection (1), a Presidential Member is not satisfied that special circumstances exist that justify the continued registration of a small organisation . . . in the public interest, the Presidential Member must cancel the registration of that organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who hasn't read the Bill now, Senator?

—The Democrats have not read the Bill, because they say, `This is democracy at work. We are not forcing those small unions to amalgamate; we are saying that they have to put up a very good case, and if a presidential member says it is not good enough they will be deregistered'. That is the Democrats' and the Australian Labor Party's type of democracy; it just does not happen to be our description of democracy. We say that true democracy in Australia is complete freedom to associate or not to associate. That is our description of democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: Our description of democracy is that there should be no numbers. If a group of employees wants to form a union and negotiate with their employer, as occurred at Mudginberri, then the Government should not say to its inspectors, `Don't cross the picket line that the union has set up. Don't send that man broke'. But the Government did just that. The Government sent Mr Pandarvis broke because its inspectors would not cross the picket line, and the union deliberately took action against its own members.

The union deliberately undermined the agreement that the employees made with their boss-an agreement that benefited the employees, an agreement that benefited the boss, an agreement that would have benefited Australia because the company had exports worth millions of dollars. The whole thing was thrown in the rubbish tin and Mudginberri went broke. The employees were thrown out of their jobs because the Government supported the union in this dreadful situation.

Now we have the Democrats saying, `That must not exist in this country. That cannot exist. We will not tolerate small unions making agreements with employers'. If they want to be a small union, this Bill says they have to have special circumstances to do it and, if the presidential member does not think those special circumstances that they have put up are good enough, the union will be deregistered. That is wonderful democracy, but not our democracy. That is the democracy of the Australian Democrats and the democracy of the Labor Party, and I can assure them that we will have none of it.
Amendment agreed to.
Question put:
That the clause, as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 14, page 6, after proposed subsection 193 (4) insert the following subsection:
``(4a) Where a designated Presidential Member proposes to consider the matter mentioned in subsection (1) in relation to a small organisation (stage 1), the Presidential Member:
(a) must fix a time and place for hearing submissions from the organisation about that matter; and
(b) must ensure that all organisations are promptly notified of the time and place of the hearing; and
(c) may inform any other person likely to be interested of the time and place of the hearing,''.
(6) Clause 14, page 7, after proposed subsection 193a (4), insert the following subsection:
``(4a) where a designated Presidential Member proposes to consider the matter mentioned in subsection (1) in relation to a small organisation (stage 2), the Presidential Member:
(a) must fix a time and place for hearing submissions from the organisation about that matter; and
(b) must ensure that all organisations are promptly notified of the time and place of the hearing; and
(c) may inform any other person likely to be interested of the time and place of the hearing.''.

These amendments focus on the area of concern which we touched on in our debate on the last amendment, namely, the exemption provisions. The Opposition is full of the argument that unions will be railroaded into a process of amalgamation, that there will be no escaping this and the terror of it all, when a great deal of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill is directed at the question of exemption.

A great deal of the Australian Democrats' concern in the debate that was referred to by the Opposition, namely, the debate leading up to the principal Act, and a great deal of the dialogue and discussion which we had with both the Opposition but particularly the Government prior to this Bill coming into the chamber, focused on the process of exemption-gaining exemption and strengthening the exemption provisions. We acknowledge that in this process of amalgamation there needs to be acknowledgment of and provision for exemption. The amendment is directed towards the process of ensuring that those applying for exemption can do so publicly, and that all those that are and should be involved in the process are notified and are able to participate in arguing the case for exemption.

Senator Durack said that in an earlier discussion between the Opposition and the Democrats we had a more comprehensive amendment. The amendment he referred to attempted to come to grips with defining special circumstances-a very difficult area indeed. We have had long discussions with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and officers of the Department as to how we could strengthen the exemption provisions.

There is an interesting contradiction in the Opposition's logic. In the discussions which we had with the Opposition as to how it would approach this legislation, the shadow Minister for industrial relations, Mr Howard-I asked him whether I could quote this publicly and he said yes; so I am not disclosing a confidence-said:
We will support any amendment which weakens the bill and oppose any amendment which strengthens it.

In other words, anything which supports the principle of divide and conquer in relation to unions the Opposition will identify with. I anticipate that Senator Durack will stand up and say that the Democrats had a great amendment but we pulled it off. The Opposition would have supported it because it believed it would have weakened the legislation. I am sorry that the Opposition does not have that opportunity now because we have called upon the Minister to facilitate the process of clarification.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been bought off again.

—We have not been bought. That is just emotional language. It has nothing to do with what has happened. It is called consultation. It is called dialogue. It is called responsibility when we, as the party which will determine the outcome of this legislation, have had dialogue and consultation with the Government on how to improve the legislation, how to strengthen the exemption provisions and how to clarify what is meant by `special circumstances'. That is responsible action on our part.

SPEECH.PARA: We attempted to have dialogue with the Opposition. We were having it until we were told that the Opposition's bottom line position was that it would support any amendment which weakened the legislation and would oppose any amendment which strengthened it. We walked away from that dialogue; we walked away from that rubbish. If the Opposition is ever in government, it will have to adopt an entirely different logic from that.

In moving this amendment, which is intended to strengthen and clarify the processes of exemption, the Minister has undertaken to have incorporated in Hansard a clarifying statement which will have standing. That has come from the dialogue and the constructive, responsible discussion that we have had with the Government. To us it is a very acceptable outcome. It is an outcome which is preferable to having an amendment which the Opposition would have said that it would have supported because it believed it would have weakened the legislation. It has the same effect. It is less constraining upon those responsible for administering and effecting this very important process of exemption. It places fewer constraints but it adds clarification and support to the process. We believe that it is a most appropriate way of building upon, extending upon, the intention of this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman--
—You have a long statement to make.

—I do, because what Senator McLean has said is correct. He has sought strenuously to clarify the particulars of an exemption provision. The best way of doing that is for me to put down a formal statement, recognising always that that statement under the Acts Interpretation Act is adducible as evidence in determining the meaning of the provision in the Act and can, therefore, be used in any proceedings where there is any doubt as to the intention of this provision.

SPEECH.PARA: The benefit of having a statement, rather than a detailed set of amendments, is that in a statement one can be more discursive about examples and instances than one can be when one is actually formally amending an Act and making law. The purpose of this statement is to provide that foundation. I acknowledge that it is my intention for it to be useable under the Acts Interpretation Act and to be adduced in any proceeding brought before the Industrial Relations Commission. The words that I am to say are words that I think have a significant bearing on the amendment that Senator McLean has put. Mr Chairman, I shall proceed with the statement at a later hour.
