SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday during the debate on matters of public interest I brought to the attention of the Senate some of the very major environmental and heritage matters which are significant in far north Queensland. I did say last week that I would, at some future time, continue to look at some of the things that are of quite major significance to far north Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last break I had the opportunity of touring far north Queensland with Mr Fred Chaney, the Liberal Party shadow spokesman on the environment, and we looked at a number of these issues. After doing a lot of work in the environment areas of far north Queensland north of Cairns we then went out to the southern Atherton Tableland area around the town of Ravenshoe. I was very pleased to be able to introduce Fred Chaney to the people of Ravenshoe so that he could hear at first hand the problems that they are suffering.

I will not elaborate on our visit with the Ravenshoe townsfolk as this will be a subject of my continuing inquiries into all aspects of World Heritage listing as it has affected the town of Ravenshoe. I will continue with that until the matter is resolved satisfactorily. I simply take the opportunity again of emphasising the hurt that is being suffered by those people-hurt that can be resolved by courageous decisions of government. I again call upon the Government to look into the matters affecting the people of Ravenshoe-as I have done many times before-and ask them to come up with some solution, some decision, on the matters which have been mentioned.

I cannot help be impressed and have great admiration for the research into the environment which is being carried on as an integral part of the Tully Falls-Millstream Falls hydro-electricity project. Over $5m has been spent on researching delicate environmental issues and I am impressed at the depth and expense of the research being conducted by the Queensland Electricity Commission into that project.

If the project does eventually come to fruition it will be a marvellous thing for safe, clean and inexpensive energy for north Queensland. More importantly, it will provide a permanent source of power to north Queensland in times when the existing grid from coal-fired stations in the south of Queensland might be cut by fire, flood, cyclone or other calamity beyond the control of man. The situation of electricity in north Queensland at the moment could be precarious if some natural disaster interrupted the supply from the south.

I was fascinated at the research being done into a little animal called the rooting rat, which is a little fellow who, after two weeks of sexual frenzy in the rainforest-and what a glorious place to do it-dies as a result of exhaustion. He is quite a unique fellow and an enormous amount of research has gone into this.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a terrible way to go.

—It is probably a good way to go if one has to go at some time. The research that has been done into that little fellow is quite interesting. I was equally impressed by the research that has gone into the yellow tailed flying possum which inhabits some of the wet sclerophyll land adjoining the rainforest areas of the Tully Falls-Millstream Falls project area.

SPEECH.PARA: Of the 660,000 hectares of World Heritage listed rainforest in this particular area, the Tully Falls-Millstream project, if it comes to completion, will affect no more than 135 hectares of that land. It should also be pointed out that the Queensland Electricity Commission has purchased about 440 hectares of rainforest from a private landowner. This land will not be touched by the QEC but instead it will be incorporated into the adjacent State forest and will more than compensate for the small area of rainforest that will be inundated by the Tully Falls-Millstream Falls hydro project if it does go ahead.

Every effort is being made to ensure that the flora and fauna which inhabit the smaller areas which might be inundated are not endangered. The research by environmentalists in the area has revealed that many plants and animals previously thought to be unique and rare are, in fact, not quite as unique or rare as they once were thought to be, but they are, of course, treasures which Australia must preserve at all costs. Apparently plants and animals get rare classifications if there is only a small number found, but I understand that while there are quite a lot of these animals and plants there, they have not been recorded over the years and the research which the Queensland Electricity Commission is doing has, as I say, taken out of that rare and unique category many of these plants and animals, which are treasures and which must be preserved but which are not quite as rare as once was thought to be the case.

The research being conducted by the QEC into the environment is being conducted in such a sensitive way as to demand universal respect and admiration. I might mention that at the bottom of the range in the Tully River Valley a test drill hole has been dug into the side of the mountain. The work is completed, but I cannot help be amazed at the lengths to which the QEC has gone to return the test hole site to its original condition. This involved lifting bitumen roads, completely clearing the site and replanting vegetation. I think that is indicative of the lengths to which the QEC is going to protect the environment and to do everything so correctly.

I was pleased also to learn that one of the greatest tourist destinations of north Queensland, the Tully River white water rafting activities, will continue to have a place in the Tully River Valley following the implementation of the Tully Falls-Millstream Falls hydro project. Water will continue to be released into the river which will provide a continued and guaranteed source of water down the rapids which will delight overseas and Australian enthusiasts alike for many years to come.

Our discussions with environmentalists in the Tully-Mission Beach area were fruitful and informative. There appears to be a new realisation amongst Australians that most people are indeed very concerned about the environment and conservation and are determined to protect it. But this realisation is being tempered by the realisation that in these difficult economic times sensible decisions must be made on all matters which take into account a very broad understanding of the Australian land mass and its limitations.

Mr Chaney and I were, during our visit, able to inspect one of the less memorable examples of the way blatant and unlawful destruction of mangrove environments can happen and we were able to talk to the people of the Cardwell area who were trying to pick up the pieces of an initially bad decision and make something out of it which will benefit the little seaside community of Cardwell. Certain work was done in the mangrove areas without permits by a company which has since gone into liquidation. Perhaps not surprisingly, the company was being funded by one of Victoria's more notorious financial institutions, which has also collapsed. But the damage has been done and it is now a question of what can be achieved to resolve it. A huge hole exists in the area. It was intended to be a marina- a marina which the people of Cardwell believe is vital to achieve the potential that Cardwell offers as a tourist destination. The town is situated on the edge of the Hinchinbrook Channel and is a perfect stepping stone to the fabulous tropical islands, including Hinchinbrook Island, the Palm Islands, the Brook Islands and Gould Island.

One cannot help also being impressed by the depth of genuine feeling shown by conservationists in the North Queensland Conservation Council with whom Mr Chaney and I met in Townsville and had long discussions.

We were very impressed with the broad range of issues with which members were concerned, both at local, State, Federal and international level. The Council is to be commended for the diverse range of activities that it conducts on the very small budget that it has. I also mention the very good work being done by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, which work I was able to speak about last week in the Senate when talking to its report. At that time I was also able to defend that Authority against attacks by the Democrats on the work that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority does. It is a magnificent organisation. It does a lot of good work and I was rather surprised that the Democrats should have taken the opportunity last week to attack its work.

I will not speak about the Authority as I did that last week, except to say that it is good to see that a very productive working relationship exists between the Authority based in Townsville, the Australian Institute of Marine Science which is at Cape Ferguson just south of Townsville, and the James Cook University of North Queensland at Townsville, all three of which conduct world class research into matters pertaining to the Great Barrier Reef and the environment around it. It certainly gives me a great deal of confidence about the preservation of our natural treasures when I see the work that these authorities are doing. As I said in my maiden speech, the Great Barrier Reef is perhaps our greatest piece of natural heritage and it must never be put in jeopardy by the decisions of man.

In the short four day trip through tropical north Queensland I was very pleased to be able to show Mr Chaney all of those major items in Australia's heritage and it certainly gave to me a new meaning and emphasis on the description of Australia being a lucky country. In these difficult times of economic recession, soaring unemployment and doom and gloom everywhere, it does us good to visit and appreciate the magnificent treasures that we have in far north Queensland, to experience them first hand and to live with them.

I conclude by talking about something not quite so positive, and that is the rallies that took place today on the front lawns of Parliament House and discussions which we have been having during the day on the problems that Australian horticulturists are experiencing at this time. They are in crisis mode. Many of them are in a situation where they will have to walk off their farms. This has all occurred through what they see as unfair trade regulations and rules, and I agree with that.

I think the Australian producers of horticultural crops and many other agricultural crops are the most efficient and the most innovative in the world. They are some of the hardest working. But they are being brought to their knees by imports of the same food crops that they are growing. These imports are being brought in at a subsidised level. They are being brought in from countries which have much less regulation than we do. One of the real problems that they face is the high infrastructure costs in Australia, and also there are the things that we have promised to do in relation to micro-economic reform. But it is all really a little too late. It has to be done urgently.

Regrettably, the Government does not seem to be capable of moving along quickly. There are things like interest rates; the problems in the waterfront; the problems in transportation; the problems I suggest with quarantine measures, where the Government brings the quarantine service into the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to talk about things, when one would have thought they might have been quite separate entities. All of these things are causing an enormous lot of trouble to these people. I wish them well in their campaign. I know that they have achieved a lot of publicity from what has happened today and it will bring the realisation to Australians of the real problems in their industry.

Again, I urge honourable senators to consider the plight of these people and to do what they can, particularly government senators, to ensure that something is done immediately to overcome what can be quite disastrous results to the people who have for many years struggled to build their farms and to feed and clothe their families when all that looks like falling to nothing. Mr Deputy President, I bring those matters to the attention of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, the motion on Tibet, passed unanimously earlier today, is, I believe, an important statement of the Senate's views on a very troubled part of our region. I would like to take some of the Senate's time now to outline its significance. Before turning to the text of the motion I would like particularly to thank the Government, the Opposition and Senators Vallentine and Harradine for supporting the motion. Its passage is a very good example of the consultation and cooperation which is often a welcome feature of the Senate's work but which generally goes unreported because it is not a circus and it does not entertain in the way conflict does. I would also like to thank Lynn Russell and Jonathan Cebon of the Australia-Tibet Council for their initiative and assistance. A particularly pleasing aspect of the motion is that it was passed during a visit to Canberra by a Tibetan delegation organised by the Australia-Tibet Council. I should note that the wording of the first draft of the motion was changed a little to achieve a consensus of the chamber. Some of us, not only in the Australian Democrats, would have liked some stronger sentiments to be expressed; nevertheless, the motion is a strong one and the motion that was passed delivers an unequivocal message.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past few months we have been reminded constantly, and quite rightly so, of the enormity of a certain naked act of aggression committed by a certain brutal dictatorial regime on 2 August this year. The annexation of Tibet by China in October 1950 was precisely such an act. Since then hundreds of thousands of Tibetans are thought to have died as China has attempted in vain to suppress the centuries old culture of one of the most peaceful peoples on earth. Military campaigns, massacres, tortures, severe restrictions on freedom of expression and movement and a trans-migration program aimed at boosting the Chinese population have all failed to extinguish the Tibetan spirit.

As today's motion notes in its third point the United Nations General Assembly passed three resolutions on Tibet between 1959 and 1965, all of which remain relevant today in their entirety. Resolution 1723 of 1961 is particularly relevant in its call for the cessation of practices which deprive the Tibetan people of their fundamental human rights and freedoms, including their right to self-determination. The issue of self-determination is also enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, in article 21 which calls for free elections under universal and equal suffrage.

It could be argued that after 40 years of Chinese rule the incorporation of Tibet into the People's Republic is irreversible. In fact, it is the desire of the Tibetan people for self-determination which has proved truly irreversible. The Tibetans have clearly demonstrated that they are an independent people. More oppression by China will lead to more bloodshed, more hostility and a spiral into further decay and conflict. There is no alternative but to recognise the aspirations and the identity of the Tibetan people and to ensure that they are given cultural and political expression.

Conflicts such as that in Tibet are being played out in one form or another in many parts of the world where the boundaries of states clash with the identity of peoples living within them. I could name many countries where movements for greater political autonomy are simmering or growing. Too often the response of the state under challenge is to use repressive measures in an attempt to crush those aspirations. This approach, apart from being immoral and unjust, which of course it is, is also demonstrably unsuccessful. One has only to look at our northern neighbours, in particular East Timor, Irian Jaya and Bougainville, to understand that military force simply does not work. Political resolutions must be sought to one of the foremost political challenges of the next decade and beyond. It is for this reason that the Democrats applaud the Senate's call for the Chinese Government to recognise the fundamental rights and freedoms of the Tibetan people and to negotiate without pre-conditions for the Dalai Lama and his representatives to reduce the tensions in Tibet.
In the hope that this motion will be of some small assistance to the Tibetan people in their quest for justice, freedom and self-determination, I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in relation to the matters of public interest I rise to address two things that have occurred in this Chamber in the last few days. These have caused me great concern and I want to express that concern in this place. The first one occurred the other day in relation to the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I want to say, in terms of the opinion of politicians that exists out in the public area which is not exactly very high, that when we have a situation arise in this place where a Prime Ministerial statement is given and is not incorporated or included or read into what is the official minutes of this place, I just find that quite disgraceful. First of all I want to express my displeasure and disgust at the action taken by the Australian Democrats in not allowing the statement to be incorporated. I think it is a total slight on the parliamentary system and will not do any of us any good. I think the action that members of the Democrats took was disgraceful. I believe it was quite reasonable to have the statement incorporated so that we could have more time for the debate. I believe that that would have been quite reasonable as I said.

SPEECH.PARA: I now want to deal with the next aspect of it. I believe that the action that was taken by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) was not proper or acceptable. Having been refused leave to incorporate, not to in fact have read the statement then, in the situation in which he was put, was just a case of spitting the dummy. Once again I want to emphasise the point that as far as I am concerned, and I am sure as far as people on this side of the chamber are concerned, I do not accept that as proper and acceptable behaviour from a Leader of the Government in the Senate. I would hope that there would be a personal commitment made into the future in this place by all people who sit in here that they will never allow that to happen again.

I think it is an absolute slight on the Prime Minister of this country. As I said before, it is not a case of which party that Prime Minister comes from. It is a case of the principle that he is the Prime Minister of Australia. We have what I believe is a totally unforgivable position. It will do us, as representatives from the various areas or the States that we come from, absolutely no good whatsoever.

The next point I want to come to in terms of what I wanted to raise concerns some of the debate about the Iraqi situation. I want to dissociate myself-and I emphasise dissociate myself-from the proposition that was put before us the other night in this place by Senator Vallentine. I do not deny her right to come in here and make a particular point. I guess the best words that I can pick in relation to this are the words used in the point of order raised by Senator McKiernan. He is sitting across the chamber. I will quote his words, because despite the fact that he made a few less complimentary comments to me last night, I think he summed up the situation absolutely perfectly. The honourable senator stated:
. . . The honourable senator is here in this chamber offering Saddam Hussein a reward for invading a country and holding hostages.

Once again, in terms of the current situation that we face, I must express my total dissociation from the proposition that was put forward by Senator Vallentine. As far as Iraq is concerned, I believe we have a situation whereby, for the first time since the United Nations was formed, we are seeing effective action taken. We are standing up to international thuggery.

I would liken it to the situation in a schoolyard where you have the big bully. He comes in and takes the ice cream from the little child, or the kid, or the smaller one, or the weaker one. But before he is punished for taking the ice cream, the headmaster tells him to eat it. As I said, I want to dissociate myself from that particular aspect. I suggest it is absolutely essential at this time when we are looking for lasting world peace, that one of the conditions that must be associated with part of the discussions that are going to be conducted is total withdrawal from all lands that have been taken over.

The third point I wanted to get to in this matter of public interest today relates partly to what Senator Macdonald had to say about the breakfast we attended this morning and the very peaceful, lawful demonstration. I emphasise the word `lawful' because I think it is very important, and I am going to contrast that in a moment with another situation which exists in this country at this time. I mention the efforts that those people were making as far as fair trade is concerned. It is very important that we address in this place the nub of the problem.

One example that I looked at this morning is the importation into this country of Turkish apricots. People were not saying that Turkish apricots should not come into this country; they were saying that they should be delivered in a fair and proper way. They showed me an example of how they had been packaged and sold to the Australian community in plastic bags. People can hardly see through those plastic bags so they cannot see the product inside. Marked on the outside of those plastic bags were the words `produce of Australia'. The argument that was being used by the people who were presenting that example was that the plastic bag that they were in was a product of Australia. That might well be true, but I believe it certainly is a classic example of misleading labelling.

I know Senator Tate made some comments, and I did not hear them totally, on how that particular problem is being addressed. But I believe that there are a number of instances of Australian industry-good Australian, non-assisted, professional industry-being disadvantaged by others rorting the system or by misrepresentation. I think it is very important that we in this place do all we can to make sure that those unfair distortions which exist internally in this country are addressed.

We hear much about blaming what is going on overseas on the Australian problem. It is true, and I accept it, that there are many instances whereby the activities that are occurring overseas do impact on us. We can continue with our General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) talks and our international negotiations to try to put pressure on the various countries that are involved in these activities, but at the same time there is a lot that can be done in this country to get rid of some of the rorts, the distortions and the disadvantages which occur and actually come down on our producers of wealth. I think it is very important that more emphasis be placed by government on that aspect of the equation within the Australian economy. In saying that, I am not saying that we should put less effort into international negotiations, into GATT and into the efforts of the Cairns Group of which we all know Australia is a leader. I am saying that we should double or treble our efforts to address some of the problems which exist in this country.

I want to contrast the activities of the concerned farmers or producers who are here today with what is still going on in the Australian meat industry. Senator Cook, in the debate on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill last night, accused me of having an obsession with this dispute. As I said in that debate, while we continue to see blackmail, thuggery, all types of activities with a complete lack of recognition of the processes of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and complete defiance of its directions, I will continue to have obsessions about it. I want to highlight, in a collective manner, some of the damage that is currently being done to us by this dispute.

The first point I highlight is that the losses now are getting close to $100m in terms of export meats at a time when Australia's current account and her overall financial situation is in serious disarray.

I also want to highlight, if I could, the situation that in Victoria alone-and I emphasise that this dispute does not only impact on Victoria because it impacts on other States and is currently on the agenda in Western Australia-in the last five years we have seen the closure of over half of our export meatworks. This is a very serious situation for Australia. It impacts, first of all, on the producers who produce the stock. This is because of the access that they have through these export works at peak times. I emphasise the point that with livestock there is only one time that you can turn them off and that is when they are ready. You cannot hold them for two or three weeks longer or a month longer. You cannot sell them a little bit earlier because then they are not suitable in terms of quality for the marketplace. So the producer only has one choice, one chance.

I want to mention the impact that this has had on the workers who have been involved and the loss of wages and time and the frustration. I have already emphasised the impact that it has on our current account. But the other point which is missed in this debate and which has not been raised in relation to what is going on, is the impact it has on our customers. Here we are spending many, many dollars-in fact probably millions of dollars over the years-in the GATT negotiations, in the efforts through the Cairns Group, and on deputations in international travel. Here we are handing markets to the various people whom we are trying to convince to in fact lower their barriers, lower their subsidies, lower their support. It is no wonder they have little respect for us. Any suggestion that we have not done our overseas reputation any damage is absolute nonsense. We have only to go into some of the markets in Asia and find from those people who purchase the goods from us, who have not been able to receive them from Australia, that in fact it has done us damage. They have gone elsewhere.

I want to contrast what we saw out on the lawns today of a perfectly legitimate protest or demonstration to highlight the problems which exist in our horticultural industries with what has been going on in relation to this meat dispute. In recent times we have had from this inquiry a commitment made by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) and the Australian Council of Trade Unions that they would not take industrial action. This was ignored by the AMIEU. We had a commitment, once again entered into before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, just over 2 1/2 weeks ago. It was not honoured.

We had the Australian Industrial Relations Commission hearing just over one week ago. An agreement was reached there that, in the postponing of that particular case, they would not go on strike because the advocates from the AMIEU were overseas on the international junket. We have the situation where they got back and the hearing started yesterday. What did we see this morning? They are back on strike again in Victoria.

The situation is absolutely and totally intolerable. It is hurting this country badly. It is hurting producers badly. It is a situation that cannot be allowed to continue. I hope that the honourable gentlemen sitting on the other side take note of my remarks. I feel very sad for this country. I feel very sad for the producers. I feel very sad for law and order in this place when we can just watch the damage that can be done to one of our most important export industries. In fact we have a situation in this country where many sheep are being shot and buried in pits. They could be sold overseas, helping our overall economic situation and certainly taking a lot of the pain of the current rural downturn away from the producers so affected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating here today the Ministers of State Amendment Bill 1990 which amends the Ministers of State Act 1952. The purpose of the Bill is in fact a requirement under section 66 of the Constitution which prescribes a maximum amount of money for the payment of Ministers. It is an amendment to the Act which sets this sum and is required from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: The sum appropriated is simply to meet the cost of salaries. It does not set the amount of individual salaries to the Ministers. In, fact the salary of Ministers is determined by the Remuneration Tribunal and honourable senators will be aware that there were certain recommendations made by the Remuneration Tribunal in 1990 in respect of both Ministers and senators and members which were rejected by the Government and, subsequently, increases were agreed to which were substantially less than recommended by the Tribunal. People would debate whether that is a very wise move and I am sure it is something which will come up in years to come.

The Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) said that the Government made a submission to the Tribunal in accordance with recent determinations for other groups within the Commonwealth sector and it was consistent with wage fixing principles. I just make the point that the Opposition would hope that is the case and the Government submission was made in accordance with the guidelines and not in accordance with some deal that was concocted in a dark corner of someone's office.

This increase takes into account-I think this should be made quite clear because I noticed a quite misleading newspaper report to the contrary-the fact that expenses of office allowances previously included in Ministers' entitlements have been included within their salaries. The effect of these changes, as outlined in the Bill, is to increase the total sum paid in ministerial salaries by $556,000 in the financial year 1990-91, and $657,000 in the financial year 1991-92. Hence my earlier remarks that this should not be misread. There was in fact not that sort of an increase in salaries for Ministers but the incorporation of expenses of office within the ministerial salaries.

To put the expenses of office into perspective, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of those expenses which have now been included within the ministerial salary. I checked this with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) prior to Question Time and he was in agreement with that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

Note: If after 30 June 1990 but before 1 July 1991, the SES Band 1 annual salary is increased (otherwise than by the second stage increase under the Structural Efficiency Principle), the Members of Parliament annual salary is increased by the same proportion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I noticed, as I have just mentioned, that when this proposal was made to incorporate Ministers' expenses of office within their salaries the Minister in the other place said that this was consistent with the structural efficiency principle aim of simplification of salary structures, and so on. I wonder, if one is to be consistent, whether consideration should not be given to incorporating the electoral allowances of ordinary senators and members in this Parliament in their salaries. It seems to me that there is an awful inconsistency when the Government includes the expenses of office of Ministers in their salaries but does not include the electoral allowances of senators and members in their salaries. Mr Deputy President, the Opposition does not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Parer who, on behalf of the Opposition, supports the Ministers of State Amendment Bill. It is, as he said, fundamentally a routine matter. It does cover the question to which he referred about removal of expenses of office to salary, which I think is merely the correction of an anomaly or an historical accident, and it is appropriate that that be done. I have some sympathy with what he said about electorate allowances. It is a distinction that no longer makes any sense at all since the tax system has been quite properly changed. I think we have to give some consideration to the continuation of that. It is not covered by this Bill, but I think it is a proper matter to consider. I thank the Opposition for its support of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every now and then a Bill emerges which the Opposition not only does not oppose but which it welcomes warmly. The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill is one such Bill. The Opposition welcomes the Bill warmly, partly because the Opposition drew attention to the anomaly which is being corrected by the Bill. In fact, I was the person who became aware of the anomaly which applied to a particular Australian citizen. The anomaly resulted in discrimination which, in fact, was gender based. To put it in very brief terms, an Australian citizen, Geraldine Room, was born of an Australian mother married to a person at that time not an Australian citizen-a very distinguished professor at Sydney University. Professor Room was an English citizen. He served with the Australian Imperial Force. To compound the troubles, he was on sabbatical leave in Seattle or somewhere on the west coast of America when the girl was born at a relevant time in 1948 or 1949.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of some anomalies in the Act, had it been the other way round-had it been an Australian father and a nonAustralian mother-the girl would have had Australian citizenship. But being the daughter of an Australian woman and a non-Australian man she discovered later in life that she was denied citizenship. I want to compliment several Ministers for Immigration. I took the problem firstly to the Hon. Mick Young, who understood the issue and said he thought it should be corrected. That would have been in 1983. The only sadness is that it has taken some seven years since then. We had various arguments from officers-the floodgates argument, the thin end of the wedge argument, the large number of people who might claim exemptions argument-and in the end it required a government decision that the anomaly would be corrected. This Bill sets out to correct the anomaly.

There has been a little difficulty with the drafting because Geraldine Room, not unnaturally, wants the capacity to register her children. She believed she was an Australian citizen. She was brought up in Australia. She travelled on an Australian passport until it was discovered that this anomaly existed. She wants her children to be Australian. The Bill, as finally drafted, will allow all those things to happen.

Successive Ministers for Immigration have been cooperative. The view of the Opposition is that the Bill should be supported enthusiastically, that we should give credit to the Government, credit to the Ministers and wish the Bill the speediest passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware of the origin of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill when I was asked to respond on behalf of the Government to it but I accept Senator Peter Baume's word absolutely that that is the case. I congratulate him on the initiative that he took in this matter and in seeing come to fruition one initiative which he has taken. I was happy, broadly of course, to support the legislation anyway because it does remove a historic discrimination which was inappropriate when it was introduced and it is even more inappropriate in contemporary circumstances. Many Bills like this are minor in the national context but they are not minor to the individuals who are affected and it is desirable that individuals and individual members of parliament have the opportunity to take these initiatives when matters arising from their constituency activities point out defects in the law. To see those come to fruition is a plus.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to the individuals. In this circumstance we had an individual who met the fundamental precondition of an Australian citizen, that is she had a commitment to Australia and she wanted to be an Australian citizen for properly valid reasons. It is entirely appropriate that we create circumstances where that person and others similarly placed should be able to become citizens. Other minor anomalies are corrected by the Bill and I welcome the Opposition's support of it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is supporting the ICSID Implementation Bill the purpose of which is to put in place the legislative framework for Australia to ratify the Convention on the Settlement of Investment Disputes between States and Nationals of Other States. This convention came into force on 14 October 1966 and it was signed by Australia on 24 March 1975. There are presently 91 member state parties including most of Australia's major trading partners. The purpose of the convention is to set up a mechanism for the resolution of disputes arising out of international investment and to provide facilities for arbitration or conciliation of investment disputes between states and nationals of other states. It establishes the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes known by its acronym ICSID at the headquarters of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in Washington DC. The centre consists of an administrative council and a secretariat and maintains a panel of conciliators and a panel of arbitrators.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a formula in article 17 for the contracting states to finance the Centre to the extent, if any, that its expenditure cannot be met out of charges for the use of its facilities and other receipts. Its jurisdiction extends to any legal dispute arising directly out of an investment between a contracting state or any constituent subdivision or agency of a contracting state and a national or other contracting state which the parties to that dispute consent in writing to submit to the Centre. Once this consent has been given it cannot be withdrawn unilaterally. Although the term `investment' is not defined in the convention a wide range of investment disputes come within the ambit of the convention including those relating to profit sharing, service and management contracts, contracts for the transfer of technology, and building projects.

The conduct of conciliation proceedings is dealt with in chapter III of the convention. Any contracting state or a national of a contracting state may institute conciliation proceedings by means of a written request to the Secretary-General of ICSID. The conduct of arbitration proceedings is dealt with in chapter IV. Like conciliation proceedings, they are also instituted by means of a written request. The tribunal must decide the dispute in accordance with such rules of law as may be agreed between the parties. In the absence of such agreement, the tribunal must apply the law of the state party to the dispute and such rules of international law as may be applicable. The tribunal makes an award which is final and binding on the parties. All questions in a dispute must be decided by majority vote, and the award must be in writing.

Mr Deputy President, there are four types of remedies against an award under the convention. Firstly, where the tribunal has not decided a question submitted to it, a party may ask the tribunal to supplement the award. Secondly, a party can request an interpretation of the meaning and scope of the award. Thirdly, either party may request revision of the award in the light of new facts. Finally, either party may request an annulment of the award on certain grounds specified in article 52.

Chapter VI deals with the costs of the proceedings. In the case of conciliation proceedings, the costs are to be borne equally by the parties. In the case of arbitration proceedings, the decision on responsibility for costs forms part of the award. Pursuant to chapter VII, proceedings are to take place in Washington DC unless the parties otherwise agree to their taking place at the Permanent Court of Arbitration at The Hague, or any other approved centre. It is possible that in the future Australia could host an approved centre. We already have two centres for arbitration, one in Sydney and one in Melbourne, and ratification of the convention would enable this to be built on. Under the provisions of chapter VIII, any disputes between parties relating to the interpretation or application of the convention may be resolved by the International Court of Justice.

The ICSID Implementation Bill amends the International Arbitration Act 1974 and the International Organisations (Privileges and Immunities) Act 1963. The amendments to the International Arbitration Act include: proposed new section 32 which gives force to the convention; proposed new section 33 which provides that an award made pursuant to the terms of the convention is final on the parties to the dispute and is not subject to any appeal or remedy other than those provided by the convention; proposed section 35 under which the Supreme Courts of the States and the Territories will have jurisdiction to enforce ICSID awards; and the insertion of the convention as a new schedule 3 to the Act. The International Organisations (Privileges and Immunities) Act is amended to insert a new section 9a to enable regulations to be made under the Act granting privileges and immunities to persons who act as conciliators or arbitrators under the convention.

Although we are supporting the Bill and the convention, I mention briefly that there are three principal areas in which the convention has proved to have limitations. The first relates to jurisdiction. One issue has been the effect that the convention may have on limiting State sovereignty. In this respect, arbitral tribunals have taken a broad view of the concept of jurisdiction and the word `investment'. Another issue that has arisen is the position of multinational companies and whether they can be considered to be nationals of a contracting State.

The second area concerns which law should be applicable in the resolution of disputes that have been referred to ICSID. The common practice of parties to investment agreements has been for the domestic law of the host nation to apply. However, difficulties have arisen where the parties have not specified the applicable law; for example, where a nation does not have a unified legal system because of its colonial heritage. The third area of concern relates to the question of whether the convention covers multipartite arbitration. The convention, as presently drafted, only covers disputes between two single parties and, in the absence of agreement, multipartite disputes or proceedings cannot be dealt with by ICSID.

Having raised these three matters, Mr Deputy President, I nevertheless point out that the coalition is of the view that it is appropriate that such issues be resolved at the international level, or by parties using appropriate arbitration clauses to overcome these problems, rather than by amendments to this Bill.

We would encourage the Government to examine the existing provisions of the convention as a starting point for making it more relevant to the nature of contemporary investment disputes. During the debate on the second reading in the other place, my colleague the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown) representing the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), raised two issues which we believed required the immediate consideration of the Government. The first was in relation to article 25(1). It was whether the Government intends to designate what it describes as any constituent subdivision or agency of the Commonwealth which will for the purposes of the convention assume the status of a contracting state. For example, could a dispute between a foreign corporation and a Commonwealth agency or a State government fall within the ambit of the convention in the absence of such a designation, and would it not be desirable that they should all be covered?

The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) replied in relation to this matter that all States and Territories had been consulted to seek their consent to be designated as constituent subdivisions under article 25, and that all jurisdictions, with the exception of Western Australia, had consented to be so designated. That might not come as a surprise.

The second matter which the Opposition brought to the Attorney-General's attention was whether the Government under article 25(4) intends to notify ICSID of the class or classes of disputes which it would or would not consider submitting to the jurisdiction of ICSID. The Attorney-General did not cover this matter in his final remarks on the Bill, and the Opposition would appreciate some assurance that it will receive his due consideration.

These matters aside, the Opposition, as I said earlier, is pleased to be in a position to support this legislation. One of the factors leading to the Opposition's support of the Bill is Australia's growing status in recent years as a leader in the field of international arbitration in the Asia-Pacific region. There have been some influential advocates for expanding Australia's role in this field, notably Sir Laurence Street. It is hoped that the implementation of the ICSID convention will encourage this process. A second potential area of benefit is that having clearly established mechanisms for dispute resolution may well assist in attracting foreign investment to Australia. It will undoubtedly also prove to be an advantage to Australian companies proposing to invest overseas.
For these reasons the Opposition is supporting the Bill whilst pointing out the areas in which we believe the convention has limitations which should be addressed at the international level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Hill who, on behalf of the Opposition, supported the ICSID Implementation Bill. I will ensure that those matters that he raised are drawn to the attention of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) although, as he said, they were raised in the House so I am sure they are matters of which he is conscious, but I will draw them to his attention.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appropriate that the Government and the Opposition should both be supporting this matter. Awkward as the acronym might be, it is an initiative that is, as the Attorney said, a step in advancing the Government's objective of developing Australia's role in international commercial dispute resolution-a point which was the foundation of Senator Hill's support. Also I think it is appropriate that it should have speedy passage and once again I thank the Opposition for its support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (PLANNING AND LAND MANAGEMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Amendment Bill extends for an additional one year the transition period as is defined by the Australian Capital Territory Planning and Land Management Act of 1988. The transition period in that Act commenced on 11 May 1989, which is the day regarded as self-government day in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), and was specified in subsection 57 (2) of the Act to expire not later than one year after self-government day. During the transition period, the pre-self-government planning regime, mainly consisting of the policies of the National Capital Development Commission, was to remain in force, and under this Act the transition period could be ended on a day specified by proclamation. The prerequisite for this proclamation is that the national capital plan should be in force providing the ACT with a new planning regime. The national capital plan has not yet come into force and the transition period expired on 10 May 1990. As the Act operates on the premise that the national capital plan, together with the Territory plan, are substituted once the transitional period expires, this Bill will correct an apparent anomaly whereby currently there is no planning regime in force.

SPEECH.PARA: The preparation and entry into force of the national capital plan is, in fact, taking longer than anticipated. There has been some suggestion that it may not be in place even by the middle of next year and it may be that another Bill like this will have to be passed to extend it again, but it is undesirable that it should take any longer than absolutely necessary. The planning vacuum created by the expiration of the transition period prior to the entry into force of the national capital plan has already given rise to litigation in the Territory over the validity of planning decisions made by the Interim Territory Planning Authority. I understand that the Federal Government has received advice from the Attorney-General's Department to the effect that that is not a problem as it stands, but this Bill is designed to remove any doubt about it, and the ACT Government, I am able to tell the Senate, is not opposed to the passage of this Bill.

However, the ACT Government and the people of Canberra have concerns arising out of the dual planning system provided in the legislation which establishes both the National Capital Planning Authority and the Territory Planning Authority. The concerns are twofold really-the additional costs that the national capital plan may impose upon the Territory, particularly the way in which it restricts land use, and the confusion which seems to be in existence created by a dual planning system. Whether it is inevitable that there will be confusion because there are two, I do not know but the fact is that a lot of people find it confusing. ACT business has to contend with the concepts of the national land and Territory land, land in designated areas and land subject to special requirements. Maybe it is because it is so new that it is still causing this confusion and it will all become clear, but I believe there are some grey areas and there are some areas which the Commonwealth has attempted to retain which I believe is not justified.

Contending with planning authorities, I am sure all would realise, can be complicated in the best of circumstances, but where there are two bodies answerable to two different governments in a city the size of Canberra, I think it is confusing. The ACT Government regards the matter as one which should be on the table for discussion in the context of the issues which arose out of the recent Special Premiers Conference, which I have referred to in asking a question here previously. It was agreed at the Conference that areas of functional duplication should be examined and I think there is no better example of functional duplication than is arising with our dual planning system.

The ACT Government proposes the Territory Planning Authority be the only planning authority and act as an agent for the Commonwealth in relation to the national capital planning issues, and that is certainly one aspect of resolving the matter that should be looked at. The Federal Government has not yet acknowledged the importance of these issues, but I believe that it should do so and hope that it will.

The other issue that arises is the additional costs which arise from the plan. The financial implications and finances at the moment in relations between the Commonwealth and the Territory are somewhat of a sore point, and for two reasons, to which I wish to refer briefly. There were moneys unilaterally held by the Commonwealth which should be available to the ACT. That occurred only a matter of weeks after the ACT became a self-governing territory. Subsequently, the Labor Chief Minister sought some of those moneys from the Commonwealth and they were granted. Recently, the Chief Minister has sought $18.6m, $8.6m to recover redundancy payments to be offered in restructuring the ACT Administration, having inherited 17,000 public servants from the Commonwealth and $10m for restructuring the hospital system in accordance with the report of Professor Kearney, which the Federal Government commissioned and accepted as the way to go for the restructuring of our hospital system.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has refused to release any further moneys to the ACT Government, and says that the projects that they have been sought for are not of, in his words, `exceptional quality'. I wish to refer to his letter, which he addresses to the Chief Minister. He states:
. . . the last release of funds . . . we established criteria for their release-that the projects to be funded be of exceptional quality and cannot be funded by any other means.

The letter went on to state that the Commonwealth was not persuaded that that was the case in this instance. Both of these restructuring processes are absolutely vital to the finances of the ACT and the way that the place can be run and governed in the future. One wonders what it is that the Federal Government expects, especially when one considers what the $7m that it released last year was released for. We are talking about `exceptional quality' and not being able to obtain it from `other means'.

Last year, when the Chief Minister sought money from this trust fund, it was for the upgrading of irrigation and watering systems along Canberra's roads-and no-one denies that that needs to be done-for the replacement of leased cars and for the upgrading and efficiency of the ACT hospital kitchens. None of it is quite in the category of being visionary or exceptional, and I wonder how on earth the Prime Minister justifies the fact that he released $7m last year and refuses, for the grounds sought, this year to do so. I believe the present request, in fact, has considerably more merit and I do not believe the refusal can be justified on other than party political grounds-just refusing to give it to a government that is not one of his own kind.

There was a letter in this morning's Canberra Times suggesting that the Chief Minister should take the matter to the High Court. Probably, perhaps, but at what cost, at what additional cost to the people of Canberra to try to sort these things out?

I perhaps should refer to the fact that the Chief Minister, I gather, referred to the $80m which the Federal Government has found and given to the Tasmanian Government to assist with public services and redundancies; the same reason, which was rejected, for releasing our own money to us in this instance. The Prime Minister, in his letter, says:
Finally, with regard to your references to the Commonwealth assistance provided to Tasmania . . . I should note that this assistance recognised the serious financial position faced by that State.

Nobody is denying that there is a serious financial situation in Tasmania. There are in other Labor States as well. Is he telling us that if we really get ourselves into such enormous debt that we cannot look after ourselves, then we can expect some help from the Commonwealth but, meantime, while we are trying to be responsible, not to get into debt, and run a balanced budget, we can go jump in the lake? That is what he is actually saying to the people of the ACT. The people here are being penalised, personally, by the Federal Government refusing to take a responsible attitude. It is clear that the ACT Government is not seeking any privileges or special treatment; merely seeking money which has been withheld and to which it is entitled. I regard it as appalling treatment by the Commonwealth of the people of Canberra.

It is, I regret, consistent with what occurred when the infrastructure was allowed to run down by the Government before it was handed over to the people of the ACT and the way it behaved over the Gowrie Hostel. I shall not repeat again-I have spoken of it before in this place-the totally unjustified way in which the Commonwealth retained for itself the Gowrie Hostel so it could sell it and retain the profits. I know it won the argument in the court and I am not disputing the court decision. Technically, it was correct; morally, the Federal Government has behaved despicably. Now, the ACT is faced with additional costs, I believe, as a result of the national capital plan and the way it has been developed, with some of the prime areas of land being retained, as they are, by the Commonwealth.

The Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, of which I am a member, in its response to the draft national capital plan, made it clear that any additional costs imposed on the ACT arising out of the plan should be borne by the Commonwealth, but I do not feel very optimistic that it will honour any such request. The Committee also recommended that the National Capital Planning Authority should provide more information about the financial implications of the plan and I certainly do not accept the view of the National Capital Planning Authority that the plan has no cost implications for Canberra. I think it has a very large job ahead of it if it is going to attempt to persuade the people of Canberra that that in fact is the case.

These are all matters that arise out of the national capital plan that we are referring to today. As I said, we do not oppose this Bill which extends for an additional year the transitional period of the planning and land management Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that Senator Reid used this non-controversial legislation and time to rehash a lot of those old arguments in circumstances when, obviously, because of the need to get the legislation passed, I do not have the time to respond in detail. I simply say that I will not pursue those tired old arguments. I think that there are some fundamental flaws in them. They have been pointed out by others before and we will probably have the chance to debate them several times in the future. I support the Bill and I welcome the support for it. It removes any doubt that might exist about the appropriateness, viability and continuing operation of the national capital plan during the period until May next year, although I do not believe, and the Commonwealth does not believe, that there was that doubt. It is not our view that there is no such plan in force but while the proper processes are under way it is appropriate that we should pass this legislation to remove any doubt, and it is another step in the proper implementation of self-government for the ACT. I welcome the support for the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, who I understand has read the Treasurer's comments of yesterday. I refer the Minister to the Treasurer's statement that the recession `is a condition which is within the Government's control'. I refer the Minister to the fact that 3,000 jobs are to be lost at Ford; 750 jobs are lost at Email; 2,000 jobs are to be lost at CSR; 8,000 jobs are lost in Coles Myer; 380 jobs are lost at International Trucks; 1,000 jobs are likely to go at ANZ; 1,500 jobs are already lost at Westpac; and 17 jobs were lost yesterday at BTR Nylex. I ask the Minister: if the recession is a condition that is within the Government's control, why did the Government adopt policies to force these retrenchments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I do not for a moment accept that all the retrenchments which Senator Hill has read out from his list are, of necessity, the result of the downturn in demand in the Australian economy. Of course, a substantial proportion of them are, but not all of them.
—Which ones are not?

—For some time a process of restructuring has been going on in Australian industry-perhaps that is a new word for Senator Walters because her Party did not do anything about it in all its time in office. Consequent upon that process of restructuring there is, of course, usually some job loss or reduction in employment levels.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as the first part of the question dealt with the recession being within the Government's control, I think I answered that question yesterday. Most forms of engineering are not totally precise arts, and engineering a slowdown in an economy is not a precise art either.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Social Security by saying that some time ago, in relation to the social security amnesty, the Minister commented that the numbers were fairly close to those expected but that the amounts that the Government looked like recovering were not as high as anticipated. Can the Minister report to the Senate on what the final outcome may have been?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did say in the Senate that I thought we might fall under the Budget estimates quite considerably. I think I indicated in this chamber that perhaps the amount would be closer to $40m than to the $53.4m which the Budget indicated we might gain from the amnesty. It would appear that we have done a little better than that.

ANSWER.PARA: Two categories were considered in this amnesty and in past amnesties. The first category is the cancellation or reduction of payments to people who applied for and were granted the amnesty. The second category is the voluntary surrender of payments by people who were not entitled to receive unemployment benefit, sickness benefit or whatever but who were motivated by the publicity that attaches to an amnesty to take that course.

Overall, the amnesty generated 23,400 applications-and that is in advance of the 20,000 which were predicted in the Budget. I am pleased to inform the Senate that the total savings were $49.9m, which is very close to that $53.4m estimate. If one looks at those two categories of payments one sees that cancellations and reductions amounted to $22.5m and savings attributable to the voluntary surrender of payments by people who were prompted by publicity surrounding the amnesty are $27.4m.

It is probable that some clients who were receiving pension or family payments without entitlement also surrendered those payments because of amnesty publicity. However, we have not attributed any savings to those, nor to cases where people claimed the amnesty but were not entitled to it because, for example, they were not current Department of Social Security clients. There were about 1,300 of those. I suppose it would be possible, by some wrestling with statistics, to actually get our figures over the $53.4m. The reality is that of the amnesty has been a great success and has come very close to the Budget estimate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a further question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, bearing in mind the answer that he gave me a moment ago. I ask the Minister whether the Prime Minister's statement yesterday that `The Australian people should not fear the recession' applies to the workers at Ford, Email, CSR, Coles Myer, International Trucks, ANZ, Westpac and BTR Nylex?
—I interpret the Prime Minister's statement as being one in which he is saying that the Australian people should not fear the recession in terms of it being long term and very deep.
—Tell that to the workers at Ford, Email, CSR, Coles Myer and many others.

—I understand the point. But as I said in answer to an earlier question, a lot of these changes in employment levels are a result of structural adjustment in particular industries. Some of them are undoubtedly due to a fall-off in demand.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WESTERN AUSTRALIAN COMPANIES: RAISING OF CAPITAL

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General follows a question that I asked on Monday concerning the decision by the Western Australian Liberal Party to block legislation in the Western Australian Legislative Council enabling the application of the Australian Companies and Securities Act. Can the Minister inform the Senate what effects the Liberal Party's obstruction will have on the raising of capital by Western Australian companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the decision by the Opposition parties in the upper House in Western Australia to opt out of the Australian Securities Commission administered regulation of companies and securities Australia-wide will have a devastating effect on Western Australian business confidence and in the money that can be raised by companies operating in Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It is quite clear that, as a result of this very shortsighted decision, Western Australian companies will be severely disadvantaged. When such companies are seeking much needed capital for their operations, there will be different rules applying to the issue of prospectuses in Western Australia and in the rest of Australia. As the rules will be different, their application by the Australian Securities Commission and the Western Australian Corporate Affairs Commission will have to take account of that difference.

Companies in many cases will not only have to pay two sets of registration fees but will have the added transaction costs, including legal and accounting fees, in order to comply with both laws. In some cases it may even involve issuing a different prospectus in Western Australia than the rest of Australia.

Senator Beahan would realise, from that short description, that there will be added costs of thousands of dollars involved in Western Australian companies seeking to raise capital on the Australia-wide market. After all, that is what it is. We are now operating in a situation where Australia-wide we have the one capital raising market and it is essential that we have the same set of regulations and laws applying and the same administrative techniques applied by the Australian Securities Commission. So, just on the simple question of legal and other transaction costs in raising capital, there will be an increase of thousands of dollars in each company. But there is a much more fundamental question which I think lies behind Senator Beahan's query in the Senate this afternoon.

One wonders how investors in, say, Sydney or Melbourne or certainly overseas can have any confidence in the situation that is being created within the Western Australian jurisdiction. The West Australian of today in a very fine editorial, which echoes much of what I said a couple of days ago in the Senate, said:

Just when national consensus appeared to be emerging on the need to eliminate wasteful duplication and inefficiency in Federal-State relations, conservatives in the West Australian Legislative Council have dealt the process a body blow.

I know that Mr Peter Costello, the shadow spokesman in this area, along with Premier Nick Greiner, has made that point time and again in the last few days. I know that Senator Campbell was going to use his good offices to try to see that his colleagues in the Western Australian upper House saw good sense in this regard. The West Australian, which is not a red rag broadsheet but a quite conservative paper, went on to say today:

There is no question that Australia needs an effective national system to regulate companies and securities. Nowhere is this need more evident than in Western Australia where corporate misbehaviour has assumed alarming proportions that have set off several inquiries and now a royal commission.

This is the absolute paradox and contradiction. Just when all the political forces in Western Australia are leading to a situation where the companies and securities area in that State can be such that investors can have confidence in it, we have this extraordinarily contradictory effort of the Western Australian upper House to create an enclave, a retreat from a nationwide approach to the regulation of companies and securities. So investors can very well ask why are the Liberals and the National Party in the upper House creating this situation which can only provide opportunities for a very weak regulation of the companies and securities markets in Western Australia. That can only benefit those who are engaged in nefarious and crooked activities.

I believe that once Western Australian businesses realise that tremendous costs will be imposed on them by this decision they will put a lot of pressure on the Liberals and the National Party in Western Australia to reverse their stance. Senators will know that Mr Hartnell of the Australian Companies and Securities Commission has stated that from 1 January 1991 it will be illegal for companies registered in Western Australia to trade in other States of Australia unless they have registered under the provisions of the new corporations law. In other words, they will be treated as foreign companies. By virtue of the law about to be passed in this Parliament, and certainly passed in other parliaments already, for example, in New South Wales and Victoria, Western Australian companies as a result of the action of the Western Australian Liberals and National Party will be treated as though they were companies registered in New York or Vanuatu. It is an extraordinary situation, which will lead to more costs and certainly a loss of investor confidence in the companies and securities market in Western Australia. I believe that the matter needs sober reconsideration by the upper House in Western Australia. I hope that for the sake of the business, commercial and trading life of Western Australia a reversal of that decision will soon take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I ask: what limitations are put upon veterans in pursuit of their entitlements through appeal? What steps are being taken by the Department of Veterans' Affairs to remove these limitations? Does the Minister agree with the opinion of the Victorian Returned Services League, expressed in a letter dated 19 April 1990 to a Mr George Scott of Pomona, Queensland, that the appeals procedures imposed on veterans are more stringent and constraining than those imposed by the Department of Social Security?

—I do not have a brief on that particular letter, which apparently has been forwarded to the Minister, but I believe veterans would expect that, in the expenditure of taxpayers' money in relation to the services they truly deserve, nevertheless there should be a process in place to ensure that that money is expended in a way that is provided for in the legislation in fulfilment of the obligations which the Australian community has to veterans in regard to their service and to the disabilities and the effects of that period of their life when they gave such sterling service to this Australian Commonwealth. I believe that the question of the actual appeal process can always be a matter for review to ensure that it acts in a way that is utterly fair to the interests of veterans, whilst at the same time protecting the legitimate interests of those who need to ensure that taxpayers' money is expended in a proper way.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister did not address the question in any way at all, so I shall rephrase it. Do the procedures of appeal relating to veterans' entitlements differ from the procedures of appeal relating to social security entitlements? If so, in what respect?

—I would be utterly astonished if there were not differences. The question is whether they act unfairly and to the detriment of veterans. I would not believe that that is the case because of the commitment to the furtherance of the obligation that the Australian community has to veterans. I believe that that is the key question. It is not a question of comparison of one system of appeal against another, but of whether the veterans have a fair and effective appeal system within which to operate. I believe that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Ben Humphreys, will endeavour to ensure at all times that that is available to them.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. I ask: has his attention been drawn to complaints by Mr Richard Tastula, Chairman of the Gold Producers Association, that among other things inflation is rising, the gold industry will have new taxes next year, and the industry has never had any government assistance? Are these complaints as ridiculous as they first appear? Can the Minister advise the Senate how the goldmining industry is doing these days?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In all the things I have ever heard over the electronic media, this must be the most extraordinary, and why the Australian Broadcasting Corporation ever runs someone who is so absolutely and fundamentally wrong on all of the main points is beyond me. Mr Richard Tastula is the Chairman of the Gold Producers Association and in a report today he said that inflation was rising, that taxes would be applied to the goldmining industry next year, that gold `took off to be No. 3 in the export earnings list after wool and coal without any government assistance', and that `in one greedy move Canberra has destroyed it, our confidence has gone and investment has dried up'.
—Does he mine gold or mine patents for St Georges Terrace?

—Well, he is from the Gold Producers Association, but he could be one of those people Senator Walsh referred to last year as the spivs of St Georges Terrace in Western Australia. I think that Mr Richard Tastula discredits himself and the organisation that he represents. In the September quarter we saw inflation come down to 0.7 per cent, the fifth successive quarter in which inflation had dropped under our Government, meaning that the Budget target of 6 per cent this year will be realised. In terms of the gold industry and government assistance, the gold industry was the only industry which was exempt from paying normal company tax on profits, which in effect meant a subsidy of roughly $300m a year to that industry and, of course, we stopped that practice. The price of gold has increased in response to tensions in the Middle East, to answer the last part of the question. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics expects the world gold price to average $US385 an ounce in 1990 and $US400 an ounce in 1991. The Bureau also expects exports of gold to rise by 17.8 per cent in 1990-91. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures indicate that profits in the mining industry have risen by 41 per cent in 1989-90. Going back to the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, its figures show that Australian gold production in 1990-91 is expected to be steady at 215 tonnes compared with a record level of 222 tonnes in 1989-90 and 188.4 tonnes in 1988-89.

ANSWER.PARA: While it is frequently the fact that lobby groups in presenting their cases to government do stretch the facts to suit their argument, in this case we have one in which the facts are completely wrong on the four major points that have been made. That is, as I have said, a discredit to the spokesperson and the organisation. I cannot for the life of me glean what the motive might be, other than trying to cloud over how well the goldmining industry is in fact doing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to a letter from Senator Beahan, the leader of the Centre Left faction, to the Prime Minister on Wednesday, and in particular the following passage:

QUESTION.PARA: There was .some suggestion, even in relation to this Tuesday's statement, that the Centre Left should support a Caucus revolt against the Government's decision. While the group's final decision was one of contingent support, it will not be possible to maintain such control in any consideration of additional commitments.

I ask the Minister: what was the contingency on which the Centre Left support depended? Secondly, in the light of this letter, is the Minister able to reaffirm that the Government, as the Prime Minister has said, would be prepared to consider increasing our military commitment should the circumstances so warrant?

TALK.START.PARA: —A really united party.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill interjects that this is a really united party. A minute ago he was interjecting about the gold tax, which his party took two and a half years to make up its mind about. And he talks about us being a united party! The task of being a spokesman for the Centre Left in Question Time is beyond my ministerial responsibility. But, in so far as the Prime Minister has commented on this matter, let me say-as he said a few minutes ago in the House of Representatives-that it is not proposed to make any other contribution of naval, air or ground forces. The Prime Minister was subsequently asked about a further upgrading of forces and he said, `I do not believe it will happen but if a particular circumstance arose where a request would be made then we would consider it'.

ANSWER.PARA: Subsequently, the Prime Minister has, of course, had correspondence with Senator Beahan and has said that there is no disagreement between Senator Beahan and himself; that is to say, that Senator Beahan agrees with his assessment-and that assessment is the one which I have just given-plus a further commitment that the Australian Government would not make any further commitment. We do not expect a further request but, if in the unlikely event one came forward, we would consider it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question to the Minister also asked: what was this contingent nature of the support of the Centre Left? What is that contingent upon?
—That is not a matter of relevance.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has his attention been drawn to suggestions by the Opposition, some employer groups and some media commentators that the application in the national wage case for a $12 a week pay increase next May, as agreed in the accord, should be withdrawn? Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether or not there is any basis for the claim by these so-called experts that the economy cannot afford the revised accord mark 6?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted in some newspapers some employer organisations, and some people accredited as spokespersons for the Opposition, saying that accord mark 6 as revised is too rigid, that it is a failure and that it should not go ahead.
