All I can say is that these people have very short memories indeed. The accord was revised two weeks ago in the wage-tax trade-off. This means that there is a 12-month wage pause in this country, a wage pause that would not have been able to be contrived by any other means.

ANSWER.PARA: In the metal trades industry, an important benchmark industry for the rest of the economy, the pause is from March 1990 to May 1991-a 14-month pause. The possibility of the wage-tax trade-off was, of course, brought about by the September quarter consumer price index, which was to be the indicator for the next wage increase. That has been bought out in a tax trade-off by the Government. The Australian Council of Trade Unions has agreed to that and we now have a 12 months wage pause which will lock in a lower level of inflation for the economy and ensure that Australia's inflation level is going down when the level of inflation in Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries is going up.
In order to put the advantages in context I have before me a copy of Syntec's corporate brief for December. It says of the wage-tax trade-off:

The September quarter CPI, and the way the Government has handled it, now amount to a circuit breaker of considerable promise. The extended nature of our recession will have the virtue of locking a lower wage/price trajectory into place.
It also says:
It is difficult to exaggerate the benefits that this would bring.
And further:
We now have a chance to settle into a wage/price setting roughly equivalent to the US, and hence a setting for profoundly lower interest rates, stronger market rates and sustained growth.

I think it ought to be said immediately that Syntec does not normally come out and praise the Government. Those words underline the benefit of the wage-tax trade-off. The wage-tax trade-off and the accord also mean that the next wage increase is on 16 May, which is $12 across the board to everyone. At average weekly earnings that is a 2 1/2 per cent increase, hardly what one might call a wages blow-out. As well, it provides for a 3 per cent increase in superannuation being taken in one per cent lots annually starting from 1 July 1991. That is 3 per cent over 3 1/2 years- hardly an unreasonable provision. Further, it provides for enterprise level negotiations for achieved productivity and profitability gains in that enterprise, which means that those wage increases will not increase unit labour costs.

All of that has been possible with the accord to achieve a very stable wage fixing environment in Australia, and at the same time to enable the very great progress that has been made in award restructuring to make Australian industry more efficient to continue. That award restructuring will put in place, when it is properly completed with workplace reform, a much more competitive economy. They are the advantages of the accord. They are not inflexible. They are of huge value to this economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is the Minister aware that legal opinion obtained by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal finds that the agreement between the Commonwealth and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia under the National Health Act does not comply with the requirements of the Act? As no agreement now exists between the Minister and the Guild, will the Minister inform the Senate what action the Government proposes to take to rectify its monumental incompetence?

—I know nothing of a legal opinion that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal may have obtained, but that would not necessarily sway my judgment as to whether the legality of the sorts of arrangements which have been put in place is in any way in jeopardy. The mere fact of some opinion having been obtained by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal does not in itself determine the legality of the matter, and the Government is not at all concerned.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It seems to me incredible that the Minister would have no knowledge of a letter written to the responsible Minister by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal yesterday. If consultation between the Ministers is not as good as it should be--
—What is the supplementary question?

—I ask the Minister: will he seek to rectify that situation and have before him suitable answers for us when the Minister is well aware of the information that I have requested? Can the Minister have a reply for me before the end of Question Time?
—Order! I call Senator Reynolds.

—On a point of order, Mr President: I am not sure whether Senator Tate heard my question because of Senator Cook's interjection. I asked him whether he would get me the answer to the question before the end of Question Time.
—Order! Senator Walters has had a supplementary question. The Minister indicated that he was not going to answer the supplementary question so I call the next questioner.
—Mr President, on a point of order: how can Question Time work if Ministers are simply going to refuse to answer questions?
—That is not a point of order. It is the prerogative of Ministers whether they answer a question or a supplementary question.
—How is the refusal to answer a question an answer?
—A Minister is not obliged to answer a question.

—On a point of order, Mr President: I asked the Minister a question; he did not respond but you informed the Senate that he had indicated to you. I do not think any of us on this side of the chamber saw that indication and I ask the Minister whether he will respond by getting to his feet and saying that no, he will not respond.
—By leave of the Senate, I will bring all Senator Walters's questions, supplementaries and other interventions to the attention of the Minister.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. What is the Government's response to the resolution of the General Assembly of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) at its eighteenth session in Perth this week calling on the Federal and Queensland governments to halt logging operations on Fraser Island and to proceed immediately with World Heritage nomination? Can the Australian Government ignore this international statement of concern about continued logging which will continue until Tony Fitzgerald's recommendations, which are not due until next April?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the resolution which the IUCN passed this week but, as Senator Reynolds would be aware, some time earlier this year the Queensland Government set in place a commission of inquiry to make recommendations on the conservation and management of Fraser Island and the Great Sandy region, and it appointed Mr Fitzgerald, QC, to head that up. I know that Mrs Kelly's Department has lodged a submission to that inquiry on the heritage values of the region and like all of us I anxiously await Mr Fitzgerald's finding.

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly the Government would like to work with the Queensland Government in any nomination of Fraser Island for World Heritage, and we will make a decision upon that as soon as Mr Fitzgerald has brought down his report. I hope that can be done as soon as possible, and I shall certainly check with Mrs Kelly, but I think the Government would be most reluctant to take action independently of the Queensland Government on this matter in the same way as we spent some time talking to the Western Australian Government before we nominated Shark Bay. We got there in the end and I hope we will get somewhere with Fraser Island as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Does the Minister agree that the proposed 20 per cent impairment level, which will be used as a basis for determining eligibility for the disability support pension, is causing widespread confusion and uncertainty in the community? If the Minister clearly understands the concept, can he please explain it to the Senate?

—I think we have been through this several times in here before. There was concern over time that people were going on to invalid pensions for reasons other than medical reasons and that perhaps when people were falling between categories, when it was becoming difficult to know exactly where they ought to be placed, too often the invalid pension was used. I think there were sufficient times when it was used inappropriately. So in looking at a review of disability support payments-and I might say reviews of that have been going on for six or seven years-it was clear to me that the best course of action to adopt was to ensure that an appropriate medical standard was used as the criterion for entry. That being the case, the Government looked at impairment levels which measure the level of dysfunction at a whole lot of percentages. In fact other departments made suggestions during those reviews and indeed during Cabinet discussions on what an appropriate impairment level might be. In the end we came down with 20 per cent. The discussions I have had with disabled organisations since the Budget-and they even included some yesterday-suggest to me that overall that has certainly been accepted.
—It is your Government that is disabled. You called them disabled organisations.
—Oh, really witty stuff! By and large disabled organisations have been very pleased with the announcements we made in the Budget and I certainly see no reason to change them.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. In view of the Minister's pretence that he understands the concept, can he please explain why he recently told the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled, as reported in its latest newsletter, that there is still a long way to go on assessment procedures and that, although he had been in the job for six months, it was still unclear to him exactly what was meant by a 20 per cent impairment level?

—I believe it is very difficult to come up with proper impairment tests. In fact a number of the greatest specialists of the land inquired into this a couple of years ago and came up with an alternative set of tests. I went through those tests and I could not see where they advantaged us here. I would not pretend for a second that impairment levels are a perfect way to go. I have explained that to disabled organisations but, in the same way as they accept that we have to have some kind of test, and that these are the best we can do for the moment, I have proceeded with them. That has been accepted by the disabled organisations right across the country.
— Did you tell them you didn't know what it meant?
—I just answered Senator Alston's question. I will repeat it because he does not seem to be able to understand.
—You haven't answered the question.

—I have; I answered it exactly. As I said, a number of specialists spent a long time reviewing the impairment tables we had. They came up with alternatives but I did not think the alternatives were any better than what we had, which was highly complicated and difficult for people to understand. I would very much prefer to have an easier way of doing it, but there is not an easy way all the time, no matter how long one searches for it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It concerns the damage to the environment caused by excessive public reliance on fossil fuels as a source of energy. What is the Government doing to encourage society to utilise other sources of energy that are less damaging to the environment? Further, what research is being done in the field of alternative sources of energy that may facilitate a more rapid shift away from a reliance upon fossil fuels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously fossil fuels and their use are at the forefront of the environmental debate around the world, not just in Australia. As a result of that worldwide debate and what I think was a very active debate within Australia in the past few years, in October this year the Government adopted an interim planning target to stabilise greenhouse gas emissions to 1988 levels by the year 2000 and to reduce emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2005.

ANSWER.PARA: That is a recognition of the significance of this greenhouse issue. It is also a clear declaration to all Australians that we will have to rationalise our use of fossil fuels. The Government has made it clear that the strategy for achieving the greenhouse target will be met not by cutting energy and other services but by satisfying such demands more efficiently and reducing waste. The targets should be achieved largely through energy conservation and efficiency and if we can achieve that we will be able to maintain or improve our position against trading partners in Europe which will obviously adopt these targets and will be working towards them. By improving the efficiency of industry, our trade competitiveness must be improved. A number of overseas countries are already reaping the benefits of their energy efficiency programs and there is an absolute need for Australia to join with them and put more effort into this aspect of energy use.

Within a fortnight of the Government's announcement of the target, the Government adopted a package as part of its national greenhouse response strategy. That package includes the development of an energy conservation information kit which will be distributed to every household in Australia. Energy efficiency in residential and commercial buildings will be promoted through demonstration programs and the development of building codes. The Commonwealth itself will lead the way by upgrading energy management in its own operations, including an energy audit of the Commonwealth vehicle fleets, appointment of energy managers in government departments and authorities, and setting high energy efficiency requirements for government housing and commercial building leases. This initial effort is estimated to achieve $1 1/2 billion in annual average savings by 2005 and to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 14.2 million tonnes each year. Another package which will involve longer term measures is expected to be ready before the end of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is clearly becoming an abuse of Question Time. The Minister is reading from a statement. Why does he not present the statement at the appropriate time?
—It is within the Minister's area of responsibility, but it is getting to be a very long answer. Senator Richardson, have you concluded?

—I am just about to conclude, Mr President. Obviously, the ecologically sustainable development working groups have been asked to examine options for achieving those targets cost effectively. I would have thought that this very important issue for all Australians was worth hearing about-especially with regard to the Government's response-and I thank Senator Foreman for his excellent question.

—I address my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I noted the Minister's attendance at the Last Great Aussie Breakfast this morning, where he made a further significant announcement that package labelling would show clearly the country of origin of fresh food products. The Minister's announcements on labelling over the last week have been welcomed by all primary industry groups and will go some way to helping Australian growers and producers. But there is still the problem of consumers who wish to purchase Australian goods and cannot identify them on the shelves. Is the Minister aware that food imports increased by 12.8 per cent in October and now represent 12.7 per cent of the total current account deficit, and that these imports now cost Australia $2.134 billion per year? Will the Minister now give an assurance to growers and to Australian consumers that labelling laws in Australia will ensure that the country of origin will be shown on the front of the can or package in letters no less than five millimetres high so that Australian consumers can easily distinguish superior Australian products from inferior, subsidised and dumped foreign products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Boswell for his question. He has taken a very keen interest in the matter of country of origin labelling. I have to acknowledge that, and do so quite freely. But I urge him to exercise a little caution in talking about the balance of payments in this context because, whilst it is true that we import some $2 billion worth of foodstuffs into this country, we export some $10 billion worth. Given the state of negotiations in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round occurring at this very time, I think we have to keep that proportion in mind.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that many orchardists and vegetable producers around Australia are suffering greatly because of the influx of imported food products. It is also true that Australian consumers are not always in a position to make choices which would benefit their fellow Australians on the land who are in the orchard or farming sectors because the information is not always presented to consumers, either as to the country of origin or in a way which is immediately accessible to them, to help to influence their choice.

Senator Boswell would know that I announced a little while ago that it will have to be signified on packages of imported juice that the particular juice being sold on the Australian market carries some imported ingredients. That is a very essential move to help to protect citrus growers, and we met some of the orange growers this morning. I am sure also that Senator Boswell has an interest in the pineapple industry in Queensland, as I do in the apple industry in Tasmania, and I am sure that those orchardists and producers would benefit from the juice market indicating truthfully the country of origin of the product which is being sold.

This morning I was also able to mention that I have urged all health Ministers around Australia to support, and the Commonwealth is certainly vigorously supporting, the idea that in the area of unpackaged food, fresh or frozen, coming into Australia-and I am referring to vegetables, fruit, fish products and nuts-there ought to be a clear indication of the country of origin.

I believe that, whilst New Zealand is in an exceptional position because of the closer economic relations it has with us, this would be of great advantage to consumers to enable them to make an informed choice, and it would be of particular advantage to those people engaged in fishing, in the orchards or on the land who are putting their own food products onto the Australian market in competition with overseas products.

Finally, Senator Boswell asks particularly about the minimum print size that might be attached to such labels. At the moment it is thought by officials that 1.5 millimetres is sufficient. I have indicated that, in relation to health warnings on tobacco products, some four millimetres is required and for health warnings on other food products some three millimetres is required. Therefore, I have asked the Australian Food Standards Committee to look at this issue of the minimum size required and I have asked the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to liaise with Professor Tony Worsley of the National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health, who is working on the benefits to consumers of food labelling information.

Those labelling size requirements are simply minimum size requirements. My plea is that producers of foodstuffs for the marketplace which contain Australian produce should of course label them `country of origin, produce of Australia' in much larger print to promote and encourage the consumption of Australian produce in the Australian marketplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services: is it true, as reported in the Australian on 28 November, that the Minister is considering a public-private partnership between Bond University's School of Science and Technology and Griffith University? If so, does that mean that public funds are earmarked to prop up what would remain a private facility?

—I am advised that at the reported meeting the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, did not offer any money. I am further advised that no public money will be going to Bond University. It has not been offered and, more explicitly, it will not be offered.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. Yesterday the Minister made the very rash admission that he had succumbed to my ageless charms and had accepted an amendment which I had put forward and which was designed to remove from the legislation being debated a clause which denied people over 65 years of age the opportunity to serve on the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority. Does this mean that the Government will respond to the longstanding call from the Opposition for it to address the issue of purging all existing legislation of provisions which discriminate against people over 65 years and which currently prevent over-65s from being full participants in our society?

—I have to say to Senator Patterson that either she has aged in my eyes or I am not as easily seduced as I used to be, because I have to say that yesterday's statement, whilst somewhat rash, nevertheless does indicate a general concern in the Government to address the issue of `ageism', as it is called, in respect of appointments made within the Commonwealth. I understand that the Attorney-General, together with other Ministers, is looking at a comprehensive review of the question of the retirement age which should apply or, of course, the lack of retirement age which should be put in place, as far as appointments to Commonwealth tribunals and other bodies are concerned. So I believe a comprehensive review is being undertaken, and I hope that as a result of that review we will be in a position in the Autumn session to inform the chamber of a more comprehensive Commonwealth approach to this matter.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Could the Minister please explain why he succumbed yesterday-and I could not quite understand from the answer whether he succumbed to the amendment or to me-and why he did not succumb to the previous amendment to eliminate the ages clause in the Maritime Museum Bill.
—Obviously, whoever the Minister on duty at the time was, he was able to withstand the senator's charms to a greater extent than I was.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I understand that the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill is not going to a committee and therefore I ask the Minister whether he has received representations from small business expressing concerns about the increase in the expenditure threshold and the reduction from 70 per cent to 50 per cent in the grant rate. Does he consider that this will disproportionately affect those with a high proportion of small business exporters?

—I have received a number of representations from small firms and organisations purporting to represent small firms about the threshold and about the reduction in the rate from 70 per cent to 50 per cent. These issues were all dealt with at some length by the Hughes Committee which inquired into the export market development grants (EMDG) scheme, and the Government essentially adopted the recommendations of that committee. What this means, of course, is that available resources will be better concentrated and I remind Senator Harradine that in reaching this decision we also provided for trading houses or a consortia of small firms to apply for EMDGs. The strategy was to try to get small firms collaborating in export markets rather than trying to go out there on their own in a big market like the United States, where they inevitably get lost. So I do not know whether it bears disproportionately on States. I take it that the honourable senator has Tasmania in mind because, according to the implications of his question, it has a disproportionate number of small businesses. I cannot answer that but I will certainly try to get an answer for the honourable senator in relation to that question, even though it does not matter much, in my view.

— My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: can the Government unequivocally claim that it has not informed the United States in any way at all, either directly or indirectly, that requests for additional support for the Gulf forces should not be made?
—I do not think that I am in any position to claim anything about that, unequivocally or otherwise.
—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. Will the Minister endeavour to obtain the answer to that for the Senate?
—I am told by somebody who knows better than I do that the answer is no. I accept that advice from my colleague.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask: is the Minister aware that both the Victorian and New South Wales governments are presently conducting investigations into accidents involving the industrial use of hazardous substances, particularly chemicals? Is it fair to regard the industrial use of chemicals as a major occupational health and safety issue? Can the Minister advise the Senate as to the means by which the Australian Government has set about reducing chemical accidents and other incidents involving chemicals in workplaces throughout the country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have consistently said, when we talk about lost time in industry, that lost time owing to accidents and disease in industry is the largest single factor. This question focuses on chemicals, which are a significant cause of accidents and disease in industry. Yes, in Victoria and in New South Wales there are investigations currently on foot. In Victoria a ministerial task force on the management of hazardous chemicals was set up in response to a fire at the V/Line, formerly VicRail, storage depot in Melbourne and, in New South Wales, the New South Wales Government chemical inquiry was set up in response to the liquid petroleum gas explosion at the Boral plant earlier this year. They are just two examples of the significance of chemicals in occupational health and safety and the sorts of problems that arise.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to the second part of the question, I can say that today the national workplace chemical safety plan was announced. It is a national management strategy for the use of chemicals at work. It is the first time that a national integrated approach has been developed to manage workplace handling of chemicals. The plan has four major elements: firstly, assessment; secondly, information and education; thirdly, control; and fourthly, emergency services. The assessment provision in the plan includes the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme, known as NICNAS, which became law earlier this year. The information element features a new national public access database on chemicals in occupational health and safety. This is expected to be available in the middle of next year. The control element of the strategy centres on model regulations and a code of practice to control hazardous substances in the workplace. Those regulations were endorsed at yesterday's meeting of the National Commission in Canberra The emergency services component of the national strategy requires the placarding of chemical stores and the provision of a list and a plan of the location of hazardous substances.

As part of the Government's commitment to chemical safety, Worksafe Australia will fund four research projects at an estimated cost of $400,000. They will examine carbon monoxide, occupational asthma, bladder cancer and toxicity of solvents. The Government is confident that implementation of the strategy will have significant beneficial results for the health and safety of working men and women throughout Australia. Accidents involving chemicals occur almost every day in the Australian workplace. A Worksafe Australia pilot reporting system recorded more than 500 significant hazardous incidences in a six-month period in 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: is the Minister aware that the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is continuing to use the 1990 Budget tax rates for calculation of provisional tax through fiscal 1990-91 and is not adjusting in the light of Mr Keating's announcement of new tax rates on 20 November 1990? Given the difficulties the Australian Taxation Office found itself in earlier this year with the calling of an early election, is the ATO anticipating another early election? Will the Government ensure early passage of the new tax scales to help both the Australian Taxation Office and provisional taxpayers by providing a legislative base for the reduced tax rates?
—If the ATO is expecting an early election, it would be making a mistake. In so far as the other parts of the question are concerned, they require detail which I will obtain from the Treasurer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I ask: has the Minister seen the article in yesterday's Age entitled `How to beat sexually transmitted debt'? Does he agree that Australian women have greater difficulty in obtaining credit and secure employment and, therefore, greater difficulty in establishing financial independence? Can he outline what steps the Government is taking to ensure financial independence for women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crowley for the question. I am sure that Senator Tate could have assisted us with the answer as well. The Government does recognise the imbalance and as a consequence we have in place a program committed to improving the status of Australian women and the financial independence of women. Recognition of, and measures to alleviate, that imbalance are fundamental and crucial to that process.

ANSWER.PARA: The primary issue is access to finance. The Government is concerned that all Australians are aware of their rights within the finance sector. Our programs in this area are directed towards the special needs of disadvantaged groups, including women. To this end Senator Tate could have mentioned, and I do so now, that the Government provides $1m a year for financial counselling. We run information seminars and provide information booklets. More particularly, Senator Tate is currently working with the States and Territories to introduce uniform credit legislation.

We recognise that this particular issue is part of an overall problem. We must break down all the barriers to equal opportunity for women in the work force. Since assuming office we have introduced a number of measures, including a range of legislation, to deal with that particular problem-affirmative action, equal employment opportunity and sex discrimination legislation.

There is also a special recognition of the role of women with families. To that extent we recognise the need for measures in this area. The establishment of the equal pay unit in the Department of Industrial Relations, together with the ratification of International Labour Organisation convention 156 on workers with family responsibilities, is geared towards addressing this problem. It has also been recently announced that the Office of the Status of Women, in close cooperation with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, will undertake a research program to assist paid maternity leave. That will form the basis of developing future policy in this area. Finally, the Government recognises the problem. It is part of the overall problem of barriers to equal access in our community. We are taking measures to redress this inequality.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It occurred to me that there may have been some ambiguity in the response that was given to Senator MacGibbon in Question Time. For the record, let me state clearly what I understood the question to be, which I answered by way of interjection `no', and which interjection Senator Button incorporated in his answer. The question which I took Senator MacGibbon to be asking was as follows: has there been any communication, direct or indirect, by the Australian Government with the United States Government asking that the United States Government not make a request of Australia for some further contribution of Australian forces?

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to that question-not that Senator MacGibbon deserves an answer or is entitled to one-is no. There has certainly, to my knowledge, been no such communication and it is an extraordinary suggestion that there should have been.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the question was asked of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in his capacity as the senior representative of the Government here and therefore entitled to give the most authoritative view that could be given on what is a crucial question. It was not helped in any way at all by Senator Evans's dissembling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. On 4 December Senator McKiernan claimed that I was `offering Saddam Hussein a reward for invading a country and holding hostages'. Today Senator Crane said that he concurred with Senator McKiernan's comments. In my speech on 4 December I was referring to two of the contentious issues that Iraq cited as reasons for invading Kuwait but which I believe could be dealt with through negotiation to the satisfaction of both sides, which would not constitute rewarding Saddam Hussein.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, on the islands issue, there is a useful precedent over the issue of two islands that block Iraq's access to the sea; that is, the Aland islands in the Baltic Sea which were the subject of a dispute between Finland and Sweden after the First World War. Instead of fighting, these two countries went to a third party-in this case the newly formed League of Nations-and their decision was to allow the Aland islands to remain under Finnish control, but they were to become a demilitarised zone, and they have remained so to this day.

Such a solution in the Gulf would give the islands, which are uninhabited, back to Kuwait as demilitarised zones with international guarantees, but would also give Iraq access to the sea without threat of interdiction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Vallentine, you are debating, not giving a personal explanation.
—I will just conclude, Mr President, by saying--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We on this side of the chamber have provided the same indulgence that you have in not previously raising the very obvious and glaring point of order; that is, that Senator Vallentine is seeking to rewrite history and events. She is not addressing her claim of misrepresentation by Senator McKiernan.
—I have reminded Senator Vallentine of that fact. I am asking her to conclude, which I believe she is about to do.

—Thank you, Mr President. I am suggesting a possible solution, which is not giving a win situation to Saddam Hussein. It just might prevent an all-out war. It is not a reward for Saddam Hussein's aggression. We must have negotiating points about which to engage in a dialogue.
—Order! Senator Vallentine, you are still debating.

—I dispute what Senator McKiernan claimed. I dispute the fact that what I said was a reward for invading a country and holding hostages. This does not constitute a reward to Saddam Hussein, but it might be a solution which would prevent an all-out war. Surely it is in all of our interests for me to be able to say these things rather than to be misrepresented by what Senator McKiernan said.
—Order! You have pointed out how you were misrepresented. That is where you should stop. You should not go into additional arguments.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Michael Baume proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The disastrous impact on young Australians of the Hawke-Keating Government's deliberately `engineered' recession which has already resulted in youth unemployment `rocketing up' with worse to come.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem of unemployment among young Australians is one of the most important problems that this chamber can discuss and try to resolve. We know that it is an important matter because our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has consistently said so. He said so in his policy speech back in 1983 when he made a whole series of promises about what would be done about youth unemployment and how appalling the level of unemployment among our young people was at that time which, as the Senate remembers, was in the midst of the worst drought Australia had had for 50 years.

SPEECH.PARA: At that point he lamented that one in four young Australians looking for work were unable to find work. That is the figure we are approaching now. He lamented that one in 10 Australians were out of work-`a figure no Australian would have believed possible a few years ago and which no Australian government should ever be forgiven for creating'. That is the figure we are approaching now under this Government.

It was only a little while ago that this Government was consistently crowing about the success of its policies-policies which were to bring down unemployment. We remember the Government after it was elected-having lamented the large number of Australians who were out of work, as we all did-saying that it would fix it up. This sort of headline dramatises how it did fix it up: `Public spending will double in creation of 70,000 jobs'. This Government bought its way out of unemployment. We said at the time that that was not the way to bring a lasting resolution to that problem. We said that it would not bring jobs that would last, and it has not.

Now we face the dreadful situation where Australia is going into a world recession-a world downturn-not coming out of its own serious problems, following a time of world boom, the most consistent run of dynamic world economic activity since the war. We have gone through that, and Australia is in a disastrous situation with, as Senator Richardson admitted the other day, unemployment among young people `rocketing up'.
In January 1984, when talking about serious economic problems, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said there was:

. . . none worse than the disastrous unemployment situation, particularly that facing young Australians. We placed the highest priority on tackling this problem. We believed then, as we do now, that levels of unemployment anything like those of the past couple of years cannot and should not be tolerated.
In consequence, we have developed policies directed at the promotion of sustained economic growth, which will lead to increased employment opportunities for all Australians, including young people.
We have had a one-third increase in youth unemployment in the latest available statistics.

TALK.START.PARA: —And spent the money.

—And spent the money, as Senator Archer said. We have seen a one-third increase so far this year in youth unemployment, and the latest figures do not yet show the rocketing up that Senator Richardson has revealed from his weekly statistics which he kindly indicated to the Senate the other day. I commend him for doing that; for letting us know that the situation is, in fact, far worse than the latest official statistics reveal. In fact, at the end of November the number of people on unemployment benefit was 480,000. That is 34 per cent more than the number of people on unemployment benefit during the same month last year. A one-third rise in unemployment is almost unbelievable. It is an incredible rate of rise.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Government that although Mr Hawke was talking about how it was unsustainable and disgraceful that any government could have such a high level of unemployment, in only five months of all those years of the Fraser Government did the level of youth unemployment exceed the level that now exists in Australia, and that was after the worst drought in 50 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a world recession.
—And a world recession. Of course, we are concerned about the unemployment of young people. That is why I have proposed the following matter of public importance today:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous impact on young Australians of the Hawke-Keating government's deliberately `engineered' recession which has already resulted in youth unemployment `rocketing up' with worse to come.
In May 1983 when Mr Hawke, as Prime Minister, talked to the summit-the summit that was going to solve everything-he said:

The raw statistics do not show what unemployment means in terms of the loss of human dignity and self respect. What it means in terms of the break up of families and the social alienation of one third of the best and brightest generation we have ever produced. What it means in terms of the defeat of human hope and the crushing of the human spirit.

Of course, that is when it was unemployment that took place as a result of a disastrous drought, when the Fraser Government was in power. I wonder whether it still holds today. I wonder whether we will see Mr Hawke beating his breast and making the same sorts of statements about the one in four young people now unable to get jobs, clearly and certainly rising to something like one in three in coming months, as the school leavers find it very difficult to get jobs. We know that they will find it difficult to get jobs. Surveys have been done by a range of people. The Sydney Morning Herald, only last week, ran a page one story which said:
The job outlook for the 54,000 school-leavers in NSW is so grim that they were advised yesterday to delay their post-HSC holidays and apply for work before the traditional January rush.

Latest Federal Government figures show the jobs slump is continuing with the number of skilled vacancies dropping to a near seven-year low. The number of skilled vacancies has dropped by a half in the past year.
The big employers are cutting back. Major banks will curb their intake of school-leavers, with the Commonwealth Bank slashing recruitment by 1,500 this summer.
The retail industry has been reducing staff and offers few job prospects. The outlook for graduates is also poor.

Yet we noted, at the time that the Prime Minister was telling us how he was going to fix up unemployment in Australia, that he was going to say that his sound economic policies were an essential part of the longer term response to youth unemployment. He said:
We are particularly concerned that the programs, the majority of which are aimed at young people, should be both comprehensive and integrated.

That was the Prime Minister talking just six years ago. How integrated and effective have the programs been? Later in this debate Senator Vanstone will deal with the incompetence and the collapse of these nonsensical programs which simply have not worked. One can see that they have not worked from the disastrous--

TALK.START.PARA: —And at great cost.
— And at great cost, as we can see. Mr Hawke, in those days, went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past two years the youth employment situation has been exacerbated by a serious fall in the number of apprenticeships becoming available.

Has he had a look at what is happening with apprenticeships these days? This Government has, in fact, largely as a result of its wages policies, priced young Australians who are trying to learn skills out of jobs. Not having a training wage is a madness at a time like this; at a time when so many employers are finding it so difficult to keep their doors open, let alone to take on more young people.

When I raised this problem-which was self-evident, I must say to the Minister-a couple of months ago in this chamber, he took the question seriously and answered it on the basis of advice. He told me that his advice was that the situation was trending down. On the ground, that was simply self-evidently not so. That is why I raised it at the time.

I had been going around the Illawarra region, particularly in Wollongong itself, talking to unemployed youth; talking to the employers who are unable to take people on; talking to all those people in the Commonwealth Employment Service, for example, who have to deal with this mounting and disastrous problem. I was told then-this was back in September and October-that the unemployment situation was, to use the word that the Minister likes, `rocketing'.

In fact, this week's Illawarra Mercury at last reveals the official statistics from that time-this was the time that the Minister was saying the figures were trending down. That is almost like Mr Keating saying everything is on track; it is going to be a soft landing; there is not going to be a recession. At the same time Mr Keating was saying that sort of thing, we had Senator Richardson saying, `Don't worry, the figures are trending down'. On the ground they were not.

These statistics from the Illawarra region, at the very time the Minister was saying they were trending down, revealed that Illawarra's youth unemployment rate had rocketed to 28.4 per cent, which is almost double the New South Wales average. Maybe I was seeing the worst end of it, but the fact was that on the ground one could see that trend. One could see what was happening. What bothers me is whether this Government really does have its finger on the pulse; whether it has been in office so long that it is right out of touch with what is happening. Before the six weeks about which the Minister said, `In the last six weeks the figures have rocketed up', in the Illawarra region the unemployment rate for young people was already 28.4 per cent.

If the unemployment figure has rocketed up since then, clearly about one in three young Australians will not be able to find a job. That is an absolute disaster. I want to hear whether the Prime Minister will now adopt the same note of concern that he expressed for political purposes in 1983 when his policies have brought about this kind of disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —Deliberately.

—As Senator Walters says, they have been brought about deliberately. I must admit that, when Mr Keating said that there was no recession, that there would be a soft landing and that everything was on track and when Senator Richardson said that the figures were trending down, I had assumed that this was on the basis of sound advice and that they knew what they were doing. Maybe it was a charitable view. The fact is that if that was their advice, if that is all that they knew, no wonder the policies they have been implementing have brought about such disaster. They have consistently been the wrong policies at the wrong time bringing about the wrong results.

SPEECH.PARA: The policies of those opposite, their refusal either to face the reality or, even worse, not even to know what is going on on the ground, have resulted in a continuation of the wrong policies, which have clearly brought about this disaster in unemployment. Those opposite cannot blame anyone else-they cannot blame the rest of the world. This is a home-grown recession that Mr Keating is proudly prepared to claim he engineered. It is the young people who are in the front line of his engineered recession.

The extent to which the young people are in the firing line is evident from the latest break-up of the age groups of Australians who are out of work. These figures go back all the way to August, when about 441,000 people were on unemployment benefits. The situation is now far worse. As Senator Richardson concedes, those figures are now rocketing upwards. Forty per cent of those 441,000 people on unemployment benefits were aged under 25 years; in other words, people between the ages of 16 and 24 made up the 40 per cent. The 35 to 65 age group totalled only 150,000. The unemployment is concentrated at the young end; it affects the young people of Australia. People under the age of 25 made up 40 per cent of the people on unemployment benefits.

What sort of future is this Government giving the young people? These figures appeared before unemployment started rocketing. This is an interesting situation as this figure-the huge proportion of unemployed being made up largely of young people-has rocketed despite the extraordinary efforts and, in some cases, dramatically successful efforts of the Government to reduce the number of young people available on the work market.

I certainly do not criticise the Government for its programs to encourage young people to develop greater skills. In fact, I am all in favour of it. The Government has been very successful in encouraging people to stay on at school. After all, if one cannot get a job there is not much point leaving school anyway. Despite the fact that the Government has been successful in getting people to stay at school, there have been dramatic rises in unemployment figures. Despite the fact that last year's retention rate at schools was about double what it was in 1982, there is this huge increase in the unemployment of young people. In 1982 there were about 90,000 students in year 12. Last year there were almost 170,000 students in year 12-just about double. The Government has managed to cope with that part of the problem quite successfully. But despite all the schemes, the gimmicks and the dollars being thrown at the problem, it is now worse than it was during almost all the time of the Fraser Government. As I said, only in five months of seasonally adjusted figures were there worse youth unemployment figures under Fraser than have been generated now by this Government's deliberate policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the last 7 1/2 years?

—What about the last 7 1/2 years? I did not hear the then Opposition congratulating the Fraser Government on the fact that its unemployment figures were far lower than those during the great bulk of this Government's life. Only in the last five months of the Fraser Government did we have these high figures-figures which this Government is not only getting all by its own work but has also engineered, brought about deliberately. That is the sin; that is the appalling legacy of this Government: it has deliberately set out to engineer a recession-in the Treasurer's words-where the people in the front line, the people suffering most, are the young people. That is the Government's sin; that sin will be brought home to it over and over again. When those opposite say things like, `Don't worry, things are trending down. Don't worry, there will be a safe landing' the Australian people, particularly the young people, will know that they can never believe them again. It is the young people who are in the firing line; they are suffering as a result of these deliberate policies. And these policies must end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note this passionate appeal to the youth of Australia to vote Liberal. I note, in particular, this passionate appeal to the unemployed youth of Australia: `Vote Liberal-we'll look after you'. What Senator Michael Baume neglects to talk about-what he and his colleagues now run from every day-is that great promise to cut out unemployment benefits after nine months. They will not talk about what will happen to the unemployed after nine months. Under a Liberal government, if people are young and unemployed, they will fend for themselves; there will be no government policy for them; they will find out how to live on the streets.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously it will always be difficult to explain to Australia why an economic slowdown or indeed a recession occurs. There will never be applause for explaining it. Nonetheless, explanations are obviously called for. The difficulty that the Australian economy faced a year or two ago was that spending was far outstripping production. No-one responsible in politics believes that he or she can simply play for the applause of the crowd and ignore the problem. Had this Government chosen to ignore the problem, all we would have done was pass on a much worse situation to be dealt with by our children. We would have simply passed on to future generations our lack of responsibility. We would have left them with a poisoned inheritance. That is something that the Australian Labor Party just would not do.

Only a year or so back, spending was running at a growth of 9.1 per cent and gross domestic product (GDP) at 4.2 per cent. We cannot have a 4.9 per cent gap between the two for very long. In the end, while using management policy, while using high interest rates to slow down that spending, we have to look at the whole context of this recession-declining inflation, a current account that is coming down, an historically high profit share, low real unit labour costs, a competitive exchange rate, declining interest rates, a very large Budget surplus, investment running at well above the average for the last 25 years. When we address long term structural problems, we do not get solutions overnight. There are no easy answers. The easy answers proffered by the false prophets will be seen through very quickly by the Australian people.

There cannot be any comparison, given that declining inflation, given that declining debt, given that competitive exchange rate and the other things I just mentioned, between this situation and that in 1982-83. We do not have an economy that is out of control because all those factors are in place. In 1982-83 employment fell by 2.6 per cent over five consecutive quarters. We are a long way from that. In that recession private business investment fell by 20 per cent. Both inflation and unemployment were at double figures. It is only a couple of weeks since we were able to demonstrate that inflation in this country is now at 6 per cent and falling as against 11 per cent and rising when Senator Michael Baume and his colleagues left office.

Let us not forget that, in 1982-83, 90-day bank bills peaked at an interest rate of 22 per cent. This time they peaked at 18 per cent, and, since then, they have gone down by 5 per cent. There are just no comparisons between the two when we look behind them. The Budget was in deficit when we came to office in 1982-83 to the tune of 2.6 per cent of GDP. We have turned that around to where this year we announced our fourth consecutive surplus-four in a row. Our surpluses are far greater than the Fraser-Howard deficits. What is more the Opposition has the hide to get up here today still without any wages policy. Just remember what happened the last time the Opposition actually had a wages policy. In 1982-83 there was a massive wages explosion, wages totally out of control. All around the country wage outcomes of 13 per cent, 14 per cent, 15 per cent, were being announced on a daily basis. There is absolutely no comparison between the situation today and the one then. What is the Opposition's prescription? As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said yesterday in another place, it is scorched earth. He said:
The Opposition sits up there with a lightning rod to scorch the economy to earth.

With the economy already in recession, the Opposition proposes to slash $3 billion off government expenditure and those opposite still do not have a wages policy. What effect will that slashing of government expenditure have on the level of economic activity? What do honourable senators think that will do to the level of unemployment in Australia? All the Opposition can do is to propose to make it worse and, while making it worse, to rip the unemployment benefit out of the hands of the unemployed after nine months. That kind of prescription is all about disaster. It harks back to what the ex-Prime Minister of Great Britain, Mrs Thatcher, tried to do. She has gone and has left Britain with inflation at 11 per cent, wages outcomes of between 15 per cent and 19 per cent, productivity at between 1 1/2 per cent and 2 per cent and manufacturing devastated. That is what the Liberal Party of Australia would once again attempt to do to Australia.

Let us look at this question of youth unemployment that Senator Michael Baume has raised today. Strong employment growth has been one of the hallmarks of the Hawke Government. More than 1 1/2 million jobs have been created during that first seven years and young people fortunately were benefiting from that growth. The Government was able to oversee a period where 70,000 new jobs were created for people aged between 15 years and 19 years. When the Government came to office the unemployment rate for that group was 24.3 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it now?

—Do not worry, we will get to that. In the last three years of the Fraser Government the teenage unemployment rate increased from 16.3 per cent to 24.3 per cent. Teenage employment-these people whom Senator Michael Baume cares so much about-fell by 85,000; 85,000 people put out of work. The teenage full time unemployment growth now stands at 20.8 per cent as compared to that under the previous Government at 24.3 per cent. We have to take into account the extraordinary difference that exists between now and then, in participation rates of those who have been staying in education longer and the pathetically low retention rates in the years of the Fraser Government. The number of 18-year-olds to 20-year-olds in receipt of unemployment benefits was 73,500 in August of 1990. That is about the level recorded in the late 1970s when it was between 65,000 and 75,000. It is well below the peak, I might say, of 127,600 that we inherited in February 1983. In September, 7 1/2 per cent of the teenage population was unemployed and seeking a full time job. That is a considerable improvement from the 12 1/2 per cent that we inherited when we came to office.

SPEECH.PARA: But the real change has occurred in education and I suspect that is the reason for the difference in the figures. Australia had always lagged behind its trading partners in education retention rates, whether we looked at Japan, Europe or the United States. Australia always lagged behind. Those seven years of Fraser and Howard saw nothing to change that- no initiatives, nothing; just simply ignored. More teenagers now are combining education with part time work, with teenage part time employment up by 128,000 or 81.8 per cent. These are figures that Senator Michael Baume neglected to mention. During the period from 1980 to 1990, the teenage full time education participation rate has increased to 57.4 per cent, up 14 per cent in just seven years.

The year 12 retention rate has increased from 37 1/2 per cent when we came to office to 60.3 per cent now. They are the real successes of Labor in government: giving young people a proper education, having them stay at school longer and getting through, giving them that real chance to get a job when they leave. Between 1989 and 1993, about 70,000 additional places for Australian students will be funded by this Government. Look at Austudy: an increase of over 95 per cent in the number of students receiving income support since we came to government. Not only did we provide extra places for a better educated work force, particularly amongst the young, important as that is, but we also made sure that they were getting income support while they were studying. These things were unheard of in any previous era. Since 1983 apprenticeship intakes have risen by nearly 50 per cent. Senator Michael Baume was talking about apprenticeship intakes and about how bad they were going. I want to repeat that statistic: since 1983 apprentice intakes have risen by nearly 50 per cent to an annual level of more than 60,000. That is the record. You might not like the record but that is the record. The Government has obviously been successful in raising the level of participation of young people in eduction, especially in the later years at school.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are willing to stand by that?

—Of course I stand by it; it is a fact. I know that you do not like facts; you never have. But sometimes reality will crowd in on you. I might say that this is one of those times. Quite obviously, this year will be worse. There is no doubt about that and no-one pretends it. All the bleating you were going on with, no-one will pretend that unemployment, whether a person is young or over 55 years and laid off after a lifetime's work, will do nothing but at best bruise the spirit or, at worst, crush it. Of course it will. That is why Australia has to get out of boom and bust cycles. That is why we are trying to get the fundamentals right. Fortunately we have.
—What is this year going to be like?

—I would like to go through that list, which you, as usual, have forgotten: inflation 6 per cent and going down; the current account going down; the historically high profit share; and the lowest real unit labour costs. Why do you never refer to those? We are getting them right and we are going to make sure that when we come out of this it can last.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Could the Minister address his remarks through the Chair. I think the level of interjections is now becoming a bit unharmonious.

—Certainly, Mr Acting Deputy President. Given that during the period of this Government we have almost doubled the number of young people staying at school, one cannot talk about youth unemployment levels without referring to that extraordinary success in education.

SPEECH.PARA: We made sure that it did not stop there. In the 1989-90 Budget the Government announced a package of social justice initiatives costing $100m over four years to assist homeless and disadvantaged youth. These initiatives provide greatly enhanced assistance for young people in terms of not only income support but also housing, the labour market, education and health. In the portfolio of Social Security, those measures include a 17 per cent increase in the rate of the young homeless allowance from $81.40 a week to $95.10 a week and automatic indexation.

When one mentions indexation and this great concern of the Liberal Party for the young of Australia, whatever happened to the indexing of child payments under a Liberal-National administration? It was simply never done. It took a Labor government to introduce indexation of those payments. Thank God we were around to do it. It took a Labor government to introduce an independent rate of Job search allowance for young people who have demonstrated long term independence from their parents; it took a Labor government to reduce the youth homeless allowance waiting period from six to two weeks, accompanied by the abolition of the waiting period for young people who leave home because of domestic violence or those kinds of exceptional circumstances.

What are the prescriptions for looking after those who have become unemployed? Of course, the messages from the Opposition on this question have been pretty difficult to read in recent times. They come and they go with the blowing of every wind. Here we have an Opposition coming in here today pretending to care, pretending to be concerned and to have some sort of prescription for the future. I think we ought to go back to what Dr Hewson has said in recent times. Not only does Dr Hewson want to do away with the Department of Social Security, he also wants to do away with the Department of Employment, Education and Training-the two departments that most affect the people we are talking about this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are pathetic.

—I am going to quote the honourable senator exactly. I will not need to make anything up. I will just quote Senator Alston and his leader. That is all I will need to do. I think it is always a good idea to be exact. Let me quote from the Sunday Sun of 22 October last year, when Dr Hewson was not leader but on the way. I want to quote the kind of compassion that Dr Hewson can display, the kind of compassion that these young unemployed, for whom he professes so much concern, can expect. Dr Hewson said:

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly most of the long term unemployed will be expected to accept jobs that they would otherwise find unacceptable or live by their own means.

What can we interpret Dr Hewson to mean from this? What he means is that we would cut them adrift. We would cut them adrift from any lifeline, from any safety net that a civilised society will provide. That is the kind of macho nonsense we get from the Opposition. But it got worse. Not only will they be expected to cop jobs they would find unacceptable or live by their own means, but he also said:
This may involve moving to areas where jobs are available.
So they will be bussing the unemployed around the country, dropping them into some other city and saying, `Good luck, we wish you all the best'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is your policy.
—Nonsense it is our policy. Not even the honourable senator is stupid enough to think that. Dr Hewson said most recently:

SPEECH.PARA: I think the most effective level for distributing welfare benefit are those at the coal face.
Then we come to Senator Alston, who is interjecting so well here. He talked about having our unemployed youth queuing up at the local branch of Coopers &Lybrand. The exact quote is:
In the United States it is the increasingly common practice to have private companies contract for the delivery of services to all sorts of recipients.

Of course, those attempts to have social security paid by private companies have done so much to harm the poor and so much to increase their numbers. One gets a real gauge of just how much the Opposition cares by looking at what it did in 1982-83.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the best the Minister can do? I thought the Minister was going to come up with something.

—Sadly for the honourable senator, everyone is judged. I have done an awful lot better than he has-not, mind you, that I regard that as much of a compliment; not that I regard that as having anything to do with working up a sweat.

SPEECH.PARA: If we want to judge how the Opposition would really go in government, we need only look at 1982-83 when not only were the numbers so high in respect of unemployment-so much higher than they are now-not only was inflation out of control and not only was the deficit out of control but also the then coalition Government slashed the payments to those in trouble who were relying on social security. We can see what the coalition did when it had the chance to deliver the goods. Despite a savage recession, the Liberal-National Party chose a deliberate policy to cut in real terms assistance to the poor, the unemployed, the youth, the pensioners and, of course, the single parents.

The Opposition has now promised to do it again. It has promised once again that, if it is given the mantle of leading this country, it will once again hit the poor; it will once again cut the benefits to all those who need them. One might as well hark back to the Depression of the 1930s when one thinks of the way that this current Opposition would behave.

We are told that the Opposition's general direction and its lack of a wages policy are going to lead to a greater reliance on a policy of high unemployment. Agencies like the Salvation Army, the Brotherhood of St Laurence and the St Vincent de Paul Society are predominantly urban based. Yet, Senator Alston would have them deliver social security payments. The only reality of that is that if one is a young unemployed person in the bush, look out. With Senator Alston's hand on the tiller, there is nothing for that person-there is no hope. Mr Acting Deputy President, at least what Labor will be leaving will be hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not heard much in the contributions so far that will improve the situation in Australia. I really get quite frustrated listening to such a debate because it seems to me that we are arguing about a set of statistics.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that recession is now official and that unemployment is expected to continue to rise. While that is most edifying, I think there are not many people in Australia who did not know that and who needed the time of this chamber to be taken to become fully informed in that regard.

What we heard in response from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) was a set of indicators, a set of figures. As far as I am concerned, one can use all the statistics one likes. It can be contended that 20.8 per cent of teenagers are unemployed and that that is better than 24 per cent or some other such figure. It can be contended that 73,500 people are now defined as being in receipt of unemployment benefit and that that is better than the 127,600 people who were in receipt of the unemployment benefit in February 1983.

As the Minister quite rightly said, the education retention rate has changed these figures. What does that mean? As far as I am concerned, that means that the unemployment situation has in fact been delayed and that there is a wave yet to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolutely right.

—I agree that that is all too evident, but it seems to have escaped the attention of the Government, which is trotting out a set of figures in an attempt to dismiss the concerns of the Opposition. The Australian Democrats contend that this Government and the Opposition are both using the wrong tools to measure what is happening in society. The tools that have been trotted out today on both sides are debatable: the accent that is put on the tools of measurement and the interpretations that can be derived from those tools are all debatable. Even while we continue to measure our society's well-being in terms of things such as gross domestic product and percentages of unemployment and employment participation rates, these sorts of things are not much use when we are measuring our society's well-being; they are not much use when we want to debate the welfare of our people. We are not measuring the status of our resources, our real social prosperity in this country. With these tools we have only an inadequate representation of what is actually happening.

SPEECH.PARA: What is actually happening was demonstrated to us this morning outside Parliament House. A group of citrus growers were telling us what was happening. They did not need percentages, tools, retention factors and all that sort of nonsense. They were able to tell us straight out in black and white that all was not well in their industry. They were able to tell us that we have been exporting the jobs, the employment prospects, of people in their industry. In our primary industry we have allowed the influx of foreign products to such an extent that the jobs in fruit picking, fruit processing, transport of the processed product and retailing are now in other countries.

The Opposition has put forward the idea that the engineered recession is responsible for the employment situation in Australia. I contend that it is a whole range of policies and not just that particular area which is responsible. In fact, it is our attitude, the misguided, misconceived commitment to the free trade philosophy, which is shared by both sides. I contend that many factors are responsible for the unemployment situation in Australia. It is about time we changed our attitude towards a number of things if we are really interested in ensuring a future for our young people. It is important to demonstrate this by using the tools-as much as I do not like to use them-which have been used in the discussion so far to indicate how extensive that is. There are about 150,000 school leavers expected nationally, but about 240,000 people are expected to leave all forms of education next year. That is the wave which has been caused by this retention rate. Senator Michael Baume has described this as a disaster and he will get no disagreement from us on that, but we disagree with the Opposition's contention that this is all due to economic policies.

There is a need to redefine and reassess what is work. It is all very well to say that a person who is unemployed is somebody who does not have work, but if we redefine it and begin to value socially useful work, if we encourage youth to experience and to learn, and if we are able to give youth meaningful work instead of a sense of worthlessness, we might be able to engender the sort of self-esteem that is necessary for people to contribute to our society in a worthwhile sense. If we looked at and valued our human resources, if we devised tools that were able to measure our human resources as a country, we would not then discount and insult our unemployed people. We would not see them just as a side issue, as people to be discarded. We would rightly see them as victims of our present employment attitudes. If we valued these citizens, we would then be able to harness their energies and talents to improve this country's well-being, and that is surely what we are on about. Surely we are not-I would hope not-just concerned with scoring points from the other side of the political debate. I hope that we are not just interested in embarrassing the Government over the disastrous position in which our young unemployed find themselves.

If we were honestly concerned with the well-being of our young people, we would be measuring their talents and putting them to work. We would not be confining them within schemes and programs and within bureaucratic paradigms which do not allow them to engage in alternative forms of work which are equally valuable to society. My notice of motion earlier today sought to congratulate the Sheffield Women's Shared Workspace on its initiative and success in achieving employment opportunities for seven people in the town of Sheffield in Tasmania-an area with very high unemployment. That area has benefited from an enlightened set of initiatives which has brought to that area work which would otherwise not be there. This has come about through the imagination and initiative of a group of people who have refused to be written off as unemployed or unemployable and have been able to create their own answer to the situation which has been imposed on them. We should take their example and follow it more closely throughout Australia. I understand that there are many other examples of such activity through Australia, but there is not enough effort in this regard.

So often the support schemes which enable people at least to get a start are removed-both by this Government and by the policies espoused by the Opposition. It is necessary before people are able to work in a cooperative or work together at least to have the notion that their presence is valued by our society-that the nation as a whole values them and the contribution which they could make. To write them off to fend for themselves, as might be proposed by the Opposition, is such an insult that it is almost a self- fulfilling prophesy. To restrict, restrain and confine such people within the framework of the bureaucracies which have grown under this Government is equally stultifying. We propose the opposite of that. We seek to value people for their presence in society and for their potential rather than their situation as measured by an inadequate set of tools, about which I spoke earlier.

It is disappointing to come in here and listen to an argument about a set of opposing contentions and constructions placed on figures derived from perhaps different sources, with different interpretations being placed upon them, rather than to see imaginative initiatives brought forward which might actually make progress. We hear that the Opposition proposes to cut $2 billion off Government spending, but the Opposition has never actually said where it would cut it. I suspect immediately that those sorts of cuts would impinge on the ability of young people to survive the process of transition from school to employment. It would impinge on their ability to assess their position and come up with employment-creating initiatives while they make the transition.

The Government's contention that a highly educated set of young people is more able to deal with life and becoming employed is not debatable. It is a fact that education is extremely valuable. It cannot be contended that it is not. I would repeat that merely increasing the retention rate over the last couple of years is not something to be particularly thrilled about, unless the Government has been able to demonstrate that upon leaving education-no matter how much further it is extended--

TALK.START.PARA: —They can get a job.

—That is quite right. Employment will be available in some form or another. What I have been trying to say in this short contribution is that one is not necessarily constrained to the traditional forms of employment which we have been measuring over a number of years. The Democrats make the point that there are many other alternatives. We have not seen enough imagination and initiative in the development of those alternatives. For the Government to say merely that by increasing the education retention rate the problem is solved is misguided and is not really contributing to the success of the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this afternoon a matter of public importance-and indeed it is just that-put forward by Senator Michael Baume from New South Wales; namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous impact on young Australians of the Hawke-Keating government's deliberately `engineered' recession which has already resulted in youth unemployment `rocketing up' with worse to come.

This is one of the most important topics that this chamber could be debating and we seem to agree on that. The worst kind of unemployment one can have is youth unemployment-when our future nation comes out of school and says, `I have got no hope; I can't get a job'. So we all agree on that.

We heard ad infinitum from Government members when they took office in 1983 what a bad job the Fraser Government had done; how it had not coped with the recession properly and how young Australians were out of jobs and had no hope. What Senator Baume is pointing out is that we are back in that position. We have been on a long circuitous route where some things have been achieved, but not much-a lot of things have been left untouched-but youth unemployment is heading back to where it was at that time.

The Opposition wants to know what the Government is going to do about this. We have seen attempts by the Government to do something about youth unemployment, as Senator Baume said. Some of us will remember the Priority One: Young Australia scheme launched by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in a much vaunted bolt of publicity in 1985.
