In parallel with the continuing SNC impasse, there have been recent reports of dissatisfaction by the SOC regime and Vietnam with aspects of the Permanent Five framework of 28 August, as elaborated in Paris on 26 November 1990, including questions which relate to the administrative and military mandate for the proposed United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia. The continuing sensitivity of these issues has been known for some time. Australia's view is that the reported expressions of concern by the SOC and Vietnam confirm the urgency of resolving the SNC impasse quickly so that the Cambodian parties can address directly the substantive issues of the comprehensive settlement at a reconvened session of the Paris Conference Co- ordination Committee.

As I stated at the outset it is important for the Cambodian parties themselves to appreciate that the international community does not have infinite reservoirs of commitment and patience to provide to the peace process, particularly if the Cambodians themselves are not willing to help maintain forward momentum. There are indications that the commitment to the peace process of some of the key international players will be difficult to sustain much beyond the end of the year. The Gulf crisis and forthcoming major issues in Europe are likely increasingly to command the priority attention of most Permanent Five countries.

Taken together, these observations point to the conclusion that, while we are now much closer than we ever have been to reaching a comprehensive settlement of the Cambodian conflict, the window of opportunity for progress may well start to close around the end of this year. It is incumbent on Australia and other like-minded participants to give every possible support to the Paris Conference CoChairmen in the period immediately ahead so that, if possible, an unstoppable momentum towards a comprehensive settlement can be generated by the end of the year, even if the culminating Ministerial session on the Paris Conference has not taken place by then.

As I also indicated at the beginning of this statement, despite the efforts of Australia and many other players and despite all the progress made during the past year, it is still by no means certain that we will be able to achieve a comprehensive settlement of the Cambodian conflict. We should know one way or other during the next two months or so, as the parties are forced to come to grips with the actual obligations set out in the single negotiating text.

If it becomes clear that, despite the best efforts of all concerned, a comprehensive settlement is unachievable, Australia, along with other Western and regional countries, will need to review other policy options. It is very clear that any course other than a comprehensive settlement would be very much a second-best option. Diplomatic recognition and the moderate levels of economic assistance which might be forthcoming over time would obviously help the SOC psychologically and to some extent practically. But the Khmer Rouge military threat, on the assumption of continuing arms supply from China, would remain a major challenge to the survival of the SOC regime. The internal weaknesses of the SOC regime, with all that they imply for its long-term vulnerability, could be expected to continue.

Given the sorry history of Western military involvement in Indo-China in recent decades, it would be a very large assumption that any future Australian government, or any future government in the West generally, would be willing to contemplate the dispatch of military forces to help the SOC fight the Khmer Rouge. Certainly Vietnam has made it clear that it cannot afford to, and will not, play that role again. Up to 200,000 Vietnamese troops, fighting over a period of nearly 11 years, were not been able to eliminate the Khmer Rouge so long as it was supplied by China, and there is no reason to assume that anyone else would do as well.

The kind of alternative policy approach which is constantly recommended to the Government-built around recognition of the SOC-has, then, obvious limitations in helping save the ordinary Cambodian people from continuing civil war and the appalling prospect of a second military takeover by the Khmer Rouge. Nor can it be assumed that it will help in removing the Cambodian conflict as a source of international tension in the region.

Recognition of these realities strengthens the Australian Government in our conviction to do all in our capacity to help achieve a comprehensive settlement in the coming months. We are further reinforced in our commitment by the knowledge that Australia's diplomatic contribution to the solution of this deep-seated and complex problem has been welcomed and encouraged by the key international players in the negotiating process and all Cambodian parties except the Khmer Rouge. Just as importantly, Indonesia and other regional partners have welcomed the contribution we have made towards resolving an issue which has obstructed the harmonious development of relations in our region for over a decade.

Given all that has been achieved so far in the Cambodian peace process, and given the importance of the issues at stake-partly in terms of our own regional standing, but more importantly for the long-suffering Cambodian people-we do not intend to walk away from the effort to achieve a comprehensive settlement as long as there remains some reasonable prospect of success. While we may eventually have to consider other options if others allow the window of opportunity to once again slam shut, to do so now would be to demonstrate a lack of that nerve and stamina in foreign policy which is increasingly necessary in the ever-more fluid and uncertain international environment we now face. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to this motion to take note of the statement which the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has put down today on the subject of Cambodia. The Minister advised the Senate two days ago that this was to be a major statement. We have been wondering, not surprisingly, what it would contain. There has been considerable speculation about this matter of recent times. We read of intended visits by the Minister to Phnom Penh; we read of plans to establish a mission in Phnom Penh. In fact, I understand that certain personnel from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have been advised that they will have positions in that mission. We were therefore expecting something of some moment in this statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that, although it is a very long document-perhaps that is a definition of `major'-we find it somewhat puzzling because it contains very little that is new. First and foremost, it is a history of the sad events of Cambodia and a record of the contribution of this and previous governments to do something to contribute to a peaceful resolution of the Cambodian conflict. Secondly, it is an attempt to refute some of the concerns that we have been expressing about how the peace process that is being advanced might facilitate or advantage the Khmer Rouge, and I will come back to that because it is a particularly important aspect. Thirdly, in some ways it seems to sow the seed of an acknowledgment of failure, to suggest a need for a substantial policy change. I guess that is new.

We are left wondering whether the Minister genuinely believes that the comprehensive settlement process might now fail. Up until today the Australian Government has been incredibly optimistic-we have suggested at times even overoptimistic-particularly in its timetable expecting peace to come about by the end of this year, the United Nations forces to be in Cambodia and the UN administration in place. We have tried to put to the Government just how unrealistic some of these hopes have been. Now it seems that, in the Minister's terms in the statement, the window of opportunity is closing. It is the first time that has been said by the Minister, so perhaps we are being softened up for an about-turn in policy.

The statement also fails to allay our fears about the position of the Khmer Rouge. At no time have we suggested that the Australian Government has wanted to take any step to advantage the Khmer Rouge, but it has seemed to us that, under the shield of the comprehensive settlement process, the Khmer Rouge has been advantaged, and the thought of the Khmer Rouge retaking power in Cambodia is almost too horrific to contemplate. Whether that is why the Minister is now softening us up for an about-turn in policy I do not know. We simply do not get the answers to those questions in this paper.

I also want to take the opportunity to make one point clear because it has been suggested otherwise from time to time. We do recognise the efforts that this Government has taken in making a positive contribution to the resolution of this awful conflict. We recognise the application and energy of Senator Evans in this matter. We are pleased that he has recognised that previous Australian governments, as I said a moment ago, have also made a contribution. He recognises in his paper that the Fraser Government decided to derecognise the Democratic Kampuchea (DK) regime, and did so in February 1981.

Senator Evans recognises in his statement the contribution that his predecessor, Mr Hayden, made as Foreign Minister. We have always said that Mr Hayden's efforts were well intended. His strategy was to look for a great Australian influence through developing a better relationship with Vietnam. It was believed by many that in some ways the application was mistaken in that Mr Hayden got Australia out ahead of our Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) friends and as a result we lost some capacity to influence events. But that was not the intention; the intention was clearly to find a worthwhile role for Australia in this particular issue. As I have said, Senator Evans has continued those efforts and has left his mark on the history of the international communities' attempts to facilitate a resolution.

Senator Evans realises that, when he announced the new moves in his policy some time ago for an enhanced role for the United Nations, we criticised the fact that this was packaged in a way to suggest that it would no longer be necessary to involve the Khmer Rouge in the process-that once we had moved away from a quadripartite solution and a direct role for the four factions to an enhanced role for the UN, in some ways we were avoiding the Khmer Rouge difficulty. That is simply not so. Senator Evans recognises the cooperation and participation of the Khmer Rouge in this comprehensive settlement process is as vital now to its success as it has ever been. Therein lies one of our concerns: the Khmer Rouge is simply using the process to its advantage.

Secondly, I have to say that we have been somewhat unimpressed by the level of self-congratulations that has been accepted by our Minister and other Foreign Ministers in this particular exercise. This was well expressed in the editorial in the Australian Financial Review a day or so ago, which stated that the degree of one-upmanship by Foreign Ministers in this issue is almost unprecedented. There has been Nobel Peace Prize talk as each offers to nominate the other, and one can continue in this vein.

It is important to recognise that while the Foreign Ministers of the world are slapping each other on the back on this issue, men and women are continuing to be killed and maimed every day in Cambodia. They continue to be dispossessed of their homes. There are somewhere between 150,000 to 300,000 displaced people in Cambodia at the moment. If Senator Evans goes to Cambodia next year, he will witness some of that tragedy which has been witnessed by people like Senator Schacht when he was there earlier this year and me. This does bring home the reality of the horror that is a daily event in Cambodia.

The few days that I was in Phnom Penh happened to coincide with one of the three major attacks on trains by the Khmer Rouge only 70 kilometres from the capital. The train was mined. Those who were not killed by the train being derailed were removed from it. The officials were separated from the peasants. The officials were all then shot and the peasants were sent home to the villages to give the message. Those who were wounded were later taken into Phnom Penh, where the message further spread.

The message, of course, is one of terror. It is the age old strategy of the Khmer Rouge and it is being practised now as effectively as it ever was. It remains as horrible as it ever was. Peasants return from the fields during the day, go to their grain baskets, put their hand in and have their arm blown off by a Chinese-made plastic mine, put there by the Khmer Rouge to spread terror. This is the background. The Minister has been interjecting but I did not hear what he said. But that is why we have been saying that we would far have preferred more effort to be put into pressing the parties to a cease-fire than some of the other--

TALK.START.PARA: —What does the senator think we have been doing?

—The Minister did not do it in Tokyo. That was his best chance to get a cease-fire. The Minister ignored that. The Khmer Rouge did not attend that conference because they did not wish to be locked into a cease-fire.

SPEECH.PARA: The third area of concern that we have had, which I mentioned a moment ago, is that the policy might be wrong. It might in fact be less likely than more likely to lead to a settlement and to peace. We have said that the comprehensive settlement ideally is the best option. In an ideal world, a process that could lock all four Khmer factions into a settlement would appear to be better than a process that leaves one-say the Khmer Rouge-out of the process, to continue its path of aggression.

The problem is that with Cambodia one is not looking at an intellectual exercise and one is not looking at an ideal world. What we have observed is that when the comprehensive settlement process was advanced a year ago, the position on the ground in Cambodia then was very different from the position now. The position of the Khmer Rouge was different. They significantly advanced their position, which I might go into in more detail in a minute, during the ensuing year. On the other hand, the position of the Hun Sen Government in Phnom Penh has significantly deteriorated. I think the paper delivered today is the first time that that has been acknowledged by the Australian Government.

Through a series of events-in particular, the withdrawal of Soviet and Eastern Bloc aid for the Phnom Penh Government-Cambodia's economic position has significantly deteriorated. It has run into internal political difficulty as the old guard has sought to see advantages from the dialogue process. It has failed to do so and, as a result, has turned on Hun Sen in particular. It has lost credit as the terror campaign of the Khmer Rouge has proved more successful and the morale of the population has dropped. The situation has been reached where one must really put a question mark over the future of the Hun Sen Government. The Opposition has been saying that for some time.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have never offered an alternative strategy.

—If the Minister is patient, he might hear some. This is the first paper in which I have noted the Minister acknowledging the deterioration of that regime's position. What I am saying is that the balance has significantly changed during the course of this last year. The position that was to be locked in by the comprehensive settlement a year ago is very different to the position that might now be locked in by the comprehensive settlement, particularly when we look at the balance between the Hun Sen regime and the Khmer Rouge. That has caused us very genuine concerns, which seem to have been ignored by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Two days ago my colleague, Senator Teague, asked the Minister a fairly simple question that concerned our worries about the rise again of the Khmer Rouge and whether they were being adequately excluded from this process. He asked the Minister:

. . . what arrangements in the settlement process have been agreed on in order to disarm and contain the Khmer Rouge? Secondly, what mechanisms are in place to prevent Pol Pot and his deputies from returning to power? Is it in fact the case that the P5 agreement-
the Permanent Five agreement-
provides no assurances at all? Finally, is it true that Son Sann, one of the Khmer Rouge representatives on the Supreme National Council-
I remind the Senate that there are only two-
is a Pol Pot deputy and allegedly responsible for gross human rights violations during their period in power?

Three simple questions, I would have thought, to put to a Foreign Minister of this country. The Minister declined to answer the questions, instead saying that there would be a major paper put down today and that we would presumably find the answer to those questions in that major paper. Well, they simply are not there. No-one has adequately answered the first question-how the Khmer Rouge are to be disarmed and contained. The Hun Sen Government is not satisfied that it can be done because of the two to three years during which everyone seems to concede weapons will be hidden. Therefore, we have developed this quaint notion that in some ways the Khmer factions would voluntarily give up their arms but they would have access to them in case the settlement breaks down. What that really amounts to is that there are no effective guarantees of disarmament of the Khmer Rouge at all. Senator Teague also asked:
Secondly, what mechanisms are in place to prevent Pol Pot and his deputies from returning to power?

The Government's answer to that in the paper seems to be that no-one will agree to Pol Pot's standing for election. Nobody realistically expects Pol Pot to stand for election. That is not the way in which Pol Pot exerts and maintains power. He does not go through an electoral process. Obviously he never will. His power has been gained at the point of a gun. He is in a stronger position now since he was last removed from Phnom Penh and he simply is not going to give up that power and influence. It seems to be generally believed that Pol Pot and his deputies are still in control and still pulling the strings, usually from their camps in Thailand.

The Minister says, `Look at the documents and see what provisions are there to ensure that Pol Pot and his deputies will not be returned. I read the P5 statement, and it contains no assurance, no mechanism at all to ensure that Pol Pot and his deputies will not maintain power and influence after a settlement. That causes us serious concern.

Finally, we said to the Minister in that series of three simple questions, `Is it true that Son Sann, one of the Khmer Rouge representatives, is a Pol Pot deputy allegedly responsible for gross human rights violations?'. This is the person that the international community is apparently endorsing as one of the two Khmer Rouge representatives on the Supreme National Council (SNC), and I find no answer to that in the statement that the Minister has put down.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is on page 17.

—I remind the Minister of the article in the Economist, a highly reputable journal, of 22 September that refers to Son Sann, who said that he was a general in the Khmer Rouge Army that captured Phnom Penh in 1975, that he subsequently became Defence Minister in the Pol Pot Government-these are the people who are being legitimately returned to power under the Minister's program-that ruled Cambodia until it was banished by the Vietnamese in 1978. He had some role in internal security-that is, imprisoning, torturing and killing everyone the Government said was his enemy. His name has been linked with the Tuol Sleng school in Phnom Penh that the Minister might visit if he goes there next year, the torture chamber, which might bring the Minister back to earth on some of these issues. It says in the Economist:

SPEECH.PARA: His appointment to the SNC presumably came on the instruction of Mr Pol Pot, who is assumed still to be running the Khmer Rouge from a refugee camp they control in Thailand.

The two men, Pol Pot and Son Sann, are related. We genuinely ask these questions of the Government and we do not get answers or assurances in the statement put down by the Minister today. So our concerns remain as valid as ever.
Let us look for a moment at the position of the Khmer Rouge. The Minister has assumed that they are genuinely wanting to participate in this peaceful process towards election.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I have not.

— That is the basis of it, otherwise the Minister might as well not be going down this path, the path that he seems now willing to abandon. What step does the Minister intend to take then? The legitimacy of the Khmer Rouge is enhanced by the process; there is no doubt about that. Once they get a position on the SNC, they get national legitimacy as a result.

SPEECH.PARA: During the year-this is the year of the Minister's program-their military activity has increased. Most experts seem to accept that their influence in the countryside has extended. They are now exerting influence over a much greater proportion of the country as a whole, having moved away from just the mountainous and border areas. The strategy is the encirclement of Phnom Penh with guerillas fanning out from Kompong Thom in the north, to Kampot in the south and Kompong Chhnang in the north-west of Phnom Penh-a process of expanding influence. I mention the practice now of attacking trains, with three trains having been attacked in the past year and ever extending signs of influence-still principally a terrorist exercise, not seeking to take and hold large tracts of land.

We have been disturbed by the allegations that they have now been provided with tanks by China. I see that the Minister in his statement today refutes the fact, indicating that Australian intelligence sources now doubt whether tanks have been supplied. That is interesting-it is the first I have heard of it-because it was reported not in any rag but in Jane's Defence Weekly--

TALK.START.PARA: —For fuck's sake.
—For what?
-Minister!
—For what?
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw that.
—For goodness sake.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw that comment.
—It is not on the record.
—I am afraid it is, and I ask the Minister to withdraw it. The speaker responded, it was most disorderly, and I ask you to withdraw any intemperate statement.
—Of course I withdraw it.
— I think it is probably unprecedented in the history of this place.
—Well, what a monstrous piece of nonsense--
—Jane's Defence Weekly--
—Order! Senator, take your seat. Minister, you have repeatedly--
—Of course I have withdrawn it.

—Minister, take your seat. You have repeatedly interjected; that has been ignored by the speaker. You must give him the right to be heard. There was a disorderly interjection, you have withdrawn it and I will call the speaker to continue without any further interruption.

— Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Oh, now it becomes a laughing matter apparently. Mr Acting Deputy President, what I was doing was expressing concern about the expanding influence of the Khmer Rouge under the shield of the Minister's proposals in this area. There is no doubt that that has occurred, there is no doubt that the Phnom Penh Government during this period has lost influence. There is no doubt that there is the chance of a comprehensive settlement if it can be realistically expected to work-that is, if one can realistically expect the Khmer Rouge to participate in a democratic process. I have always wondered whether that is so. There is no doubt that the Khmer Rouge has vastly expanded its position of power and influence within Cambodia during the past year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has kept interjecting, asking what other options are open, what should he be doing, and I expect that we shall hear fairly soon from the Australian Government as to what alternative process it will adopt next for Cambodia. We have been saying that we believe there was an alternative of greater influence towards a cease-fire and that that has been largely avoided. We believe it would have been worthwhile if there had been more effort to try to lock out the military aspect of the Cambodian issue over the past 12 months, and perhaps a little less on the diplomatic set. We think that advantages could have come out of it. We have been saying for years that this Government and other governments could have brought an action in genocide against Pol Pot and his regime. This Government has had its own internal advice to that effect, but it has disregarded that advice. It would have had the advantage of properly excluding Pol Pot and his deputies from the process-those whom we fear are to be advantaged by the Government's action.

We have said also that if it appears on a realistic assessment that this will be a path back to power for the Khmer Rouge, or alternatively that the comprehensive settlement process will not work, again the international community should have been looking at the option of a linkage of three factions that excluded the Khmer Rouge, but that has been disregarded. I know that the argument for disregarding it is the one I mentioned a while ago that nevertheless leaves the Khmer Rouge in the field, but if the international community is prepared to support the three factions at the exclusion of the Khmer Rouge, it can be equally argued that the position of the Khmer Rouge becomes marginalised. There is a lot that can be done that has not been done by this Government. Why does it now seem that we may be going to face an about-turn? Why is the Minister now saying that it looks as if the window of opportunity has been closed?

I suggest that it might be a sudden realisation of the enormous hurdles that still remain-hurdles that the Minister will not acknowledge, hurdles that I mentioned in this chamber some little time ago-and the difficulties that the UN itself still sees that lie ahead with containment and disarmament of the Khmer factions. As the UN officials say, they cannot get to square one with that because the factions have not even been prepared to give them information as to their military assets.

The UN still needs to send another military adviser group to Cambodia, but they cannot go until there is a cease-fire. It comes back to that key political point. The UN says that before it can take any action there must be major development of infrastructure-ports, roads, airfields and communications-which is a massive job in itself. The 200,000-odd displaced persons have to be resettled. The land has to be cleared of mines. The security of the UN personnel and perhaps Australian personnel, if that is what the Government is intending, has to be ensured.

Also, the UN has to take over the administration, which is a key to the breakdown of the five functions of government that the Hun Sen Government was to give to the UN; that is, foreign policy, defence, communications, interior, and finance. Of course, it is only in the last few days that Hun Sen has come out again and said, `I am simply not prepared to give over those functions to the UN. I am not prepared to weaken my position in any political process that might further ensue by handing over those functions of government'.

Perhaps, finally, the Minister is realising the enormity of the challenge that is still ahead. It is not a matter that can simply be resolved through conferences in Paris, in Indonesia, in Jakarta, and elsewhere, because on the ground Cambodians have continued to suffer. Perhaps he is now finally recognising that that should be the key and that attempts should be made more realistically to assess what efforts the international community can make, particularly to bring the Khmer Rouge to heel, which is now in a stronger position than it has been in since it was last removed from Phnom Penh. I am pleased that we have had a statement and I am pleased that we have had an opportunity to talk about some of these issues. But I regret that the statement has not advanced the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), the Australian Democrats have been encouraged that so much has been achieved in terms of a comprehensive and workable peace settlement for Cambodia. At the same time, we are concerned that we have reached a stalemate in negotiations, particularly over the question of the composition of the Supreme National Council. Nevertheless, it is a credit to the value of the negotiating process and, in particular, to the efforts of a few people--

—Order! Senator, could you take your seat. I am sorry to interrupt your speech. Minister and Senator Hill, you have both spoken and the chamber was very interested in what you had to say. It is now Senator Bourne's turn to speak. I again ask for no more interjections. This debate has been, in fact, labelled a major statement, and people in this chamber want to hear everyone speak and without interjections continuing. I will not ask again.

—It is a credit to the value of the negotiating process and, in particular, to the efforts of a few people, including Australia's negotiating team, that we have arrived at the stage that we are at today. In many ways, agreements that have been achieved to date are due also to the changed international climate in which we now live. The Cambodians have for many years now been fighting someone else's war. Now with the Cold War officially over, those external powers have no interest in the continuation of a nasty, unwinnable proxy fight in South East Asia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Soviet Union, the principal sponsor of both Vietnam and Hun Sen, has its own serious economic problems and can no longer afford to sustain military adventures in Indo-China. China, as the principal supplier of arms and funds to the Khmer Rouge, no longer feels the need to go on punishing Vietnam and is now seeking international approval since the atrocities of Tiananmen Square took place. In fact, since the Tiananmen Square outrage, China now appears willing to be seen as a peacemaker in Cambodia.

The United States (US) has slowly and finally realised that the Vietnamese communists have been punished enough for defeating the Americans in the Vietnam war and that a change of heart was necessary on their part. A peace settlement in Cambodia would remove the last obstacles to the lifting of US-led embargoes and sanctions against Vietnam, giving Hanoi access to desperately needed international aid and loans. Therefore, to a large extent, the UN peace plan has gained the support that it has precisely because the international mood has now shifted. This has created an environment in which the cause of peace in South East Asia can now realistically be advanced.

We note that the Foreign Minister has refuted any suggestions that the Khmer Rouge are somehow exploiting the peace process for both political and military advantage. I am encouraged by the Minister's comments in this regard, and I am hopeful that he is right when he suggests that the best way of dealing with the Khmer Rouge is to include them in the negotiating process for, once a comprehensive peace settlement is in place, the Khmer Rouge will eventually be marginalised. Let us all hope that this is so.

We believe that the Minister is also right when he suggests that China is the key to eliminating the Khmer Rouge. It is true that, unless a comprehensive peace settlement is established in Cambodia, China will continue to fund and supply the Khmer Rouge with military supplies. The fact remains, however, that China has a less than perfect record in such matters, and the Khmer Rouge are of the same bizarre communist strand that gave the world the atrocities of Pol Pot.

The point I am seeking to make is that I have very little confidence or trust in the Khmer Rouge or in their sponsors. The Khmer Rouge should not be underestimated in this regard. They will undoubtedly want to gain as much of the country as possible before a cease-fire, hoping that an advantage is obtained when the election is held.

It may seem inconceivable, but I have seen reports of United States intelligence suggesting that at least 30 per cent of Cambodians would vote for the Khmer Rouge in any election; I hope that is wrong. This information seems to be at odds somewhat with the Minister's stated belief that the Khmer Rouge should obtain only a minor share of the vote when the election actually takes place. Already there have been reports that vote buying has started with the Khmer Rouge guerillas paying farmers generously for everything that they can buy from them in return for voter support during any election in the future.

By his own admission, the Minister has said that the Khmer Rouge have access to two or three years' supplies of arms, even without continued external support, and will be able to make quite a nuisance of themselves for some time to come. It is understandable, therefore, that some of us remain fearful that, despite recent developments, the Khmer Rouge are still intent on winning power-by the ballot box if possible and by force if they do not get their way.

Nevertheless, we feel that the Australian Government's proposed way of dealing with the Cambodian conflict and the policy option it has pursued is the one most likely to succeed. In this regard, the Minister does have the support of the Australian Democrats for what has been achieved to date and the efforts he has outlined that are likely to be followed up in future international forums. It must be said that we should keep trying along the path outlined by the Minister, because the sad fact is that few countries have suffered quite as much as Cambodia has in recent generations. Bombed by the United States, brutalised by the Khmer Rouge, occupied by the Vietnamese, and then fought over in a four-faction civil war, Cambodia has endured more pain in two decades than most countries have to in two centuries.

There is no doubt that Cambodia, regardless of any outcome of the current peace process, is a country in ruins. Its Government has been running an annual Budget deficit equal to 30 per cent of the country's modest gross domestic product. Defence accounts for 45 per cent of all government spending. Meanwhile, credits and highly subsidised oil from the Soviet Union have kept the Government's finances afloat. We understand that these hand-outs will stop at the end of the year and one can only imagine what the impact of this will be.

Cambodia should be the rice bowl of South East Asia. Instead, it operates with an economy which is in a shambles. In most districts, there are of course no telephones. There is an erratic or non-existent electricity supply, no clean drinking water and few vehicles or indeed passable roads. In many of the guerilla war zones, thousands of landmines are sown amongst rice fields.

With this situation in mind, we sincerely hope that the international efforts will shortly bear fruit. Most of all, we need to see a resolution of the current impasse concerning the dispute over the membership of the Supreme National Council. When one considers how far we have come and how close indeed we are to a settlement in Cambodia, we share the Minister's fear that it would certainly be tragic if indeed the whole thing were to come apart now.

We cannot forget, however, that an interim United Nations administration, even if it does get set up, will need formidable administrative help and a fair sized force to keep the various factions under control. In some ways, a comprehensive peace settlement now would open up an even greater number of problems. There should be no doubt that the United Nations will be engaged in a task far more ambitious than anything it has undertaken for years. For instance, officials supervising the elections would have to contend with a population that has known power only through violence and terror for an entire generation. Most Cambodians probably have no concept of freedom of choice.

In terms of cost as well, the sheer size of the operation would need to be large. By way of comparison the operation in Namibia cost $US373m and at its height involved a total of just under 8,000 people. This is quite small when compared to what Cambodia would need. I note that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has estimated that the proposal to use the United Nations in administering and overseeing any elections in Cambodia would cost around $US1.3 billion and this should give us some idea of the scale of the operation involved. Nevertheless, as the Minister has correctly pointed out, a world so preoccupied by events in the Gulf and in Europe might be reluctant to turn its attention in a generous way towards Cambodia. Under those circumstances, a failure to respond would indeed be a tragedy. The world should not lose sight of the fact that a successful transition to democracy in Cambodia would open the way to a more peaceful and secure South East Asia. Given the fact that many of the problems now facing South East Asia are themselves the creation of external forces, one would have thought that those same forces would not be unwilling to contribute now to the success of a comprehensive peace plan in Cambodia.

We also believe that the success of the peace plan would be a chance to show the world that the recent achievements of the United Nations have not pushed that organisation to its limits but were in fact the foundations on which bigger accomplishments could be built. Regardless of the success or otherwise of the United Nations peace plan, we must also not forget the magnitude of the economic problems facing Cambodia. Accordingly, should the peace plan succeed and should Cambodia be able to choose a government of its choice, the foreign aid required from the outside world will need to be massive. Indeed, we would like to see Australia increase its foreign aid to Cambodia to address the chronic shortages in basic necessities which were described by Senator Gareth Evans. There are already large numbers of refugees and it is now clear that many of the relief agencies operating in Cambodia are not coping with the magnitude of the problems they face there. Nevertheless, like the Foreign Minister, we hope we are much closer than we have ever been to achieving a long lasting peace settlement in Cambodia. It has already been pointed out that the next few months will be crucial in determining whether the Cambodian people will finally be granted the peace and security they deserve.

In conclusion, I take this opportunity to pay tribute to and recognise the efforts of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and the officials in his Department who have moved the peace process along to the stage it is today. Regardless of the outcome, we are confident that the Minister has done all in his capacity in a sincere and genuine way to bring about a lasting peace in Cambodia and this needs to be recognised. In addition, we would like to recognise the efforts of Australia's special envoy, Michael Costello, for his part in the process. Mr Costello's special and unique skills as a mediator played a crucial part in moving negotiations along and I know that we could not be where we are today were it not for his perseverance in the matter. We remain hopeful that all these efforts will not have been in vain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak in support of the Government's statement on Cambodia. It is a comprehensive statement which gives a detailed history of Cambodian politics basically since the Second World War. It also gives considerable detail about the situation reached in the peace process in Cambodia at present, and particularly the events of the past year or so.

SPEECH.PARA: After hearing part of Senator Robert Hill's speech, I must say that it was full of nitpicking and offered no alternative to what the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) outlined. I think it is disgraceful that the Opposition would nitpick without any substance and without any overall theme but above all else would not produce an alternative program of how to get peace in Cambodia. I find it extraordinary that Senator Hill consistently argues that the Government is going to allow the Khmer Rouge back into power in Cambodia because we do not understand the evil nature of the Khmer Rouge. If one reads the statement carefully and listens to what Senator Gareth Evans and his predecessor, Mr Hayden, have said over a number of years, one finds it is clear that the Government more than anyone else understands the evil nature of the Khmer Rouge and the Pol Pot period. It is extraordinary that Senator Hill should ask, `What are you going to do to stop the Khmer Rouge?', and yet he does not outline what he wants to do to stop the Khmer Rouge. He implies that the Government should recognise the Hun Sen Government forthwith. He implies that we should probably send weapons to the Hun Sen Government to fight the Khmer Rouge because, if he does not propose anything else, that is the only deduction I can reach from the way in which he asked his nitpicking questions.

The statement makes it quite clear that had it not been for the Australian initiatives, the so-called `Red Book' launched in October-November last year, we would not be at the stage we are now where all the permanent members of the Security Council have basically agreed to adopt the Australian proposition. It was the Australian initiative that laid the groundwork, and Senator Bourne has just paid tribute not only to the Minister but also to Mark Costello, Australia's Special Envoy in the negotiations who made many visits to Asian capitals, to Europe and to the United Nations (UN), often at a rapid rate, to discuss and explain what we were proposing and to break sometimes the walls of resistance to the peace process. I do not think we would be where we are today had it not been for that process.

The big change which gave momentum to the process was the one in American policy in July this year. The Americans said they were willing to negotiate with Vietnam and they were no longer going to vote in the UN to support the Khmer Rouge and the other resistance factions as the official government of Cambodia. That was the change that broke the deadlock in so many ways in the negotiations. Firstly, it showed to the Cambodian resistance factions-the Sihanouk group, the Son Sann group and the Khmer Rouge-that they could no longer rely on American influence in the UN to protect their so called sovereignty in the UN.

Some people have asked why America changed its position. I think the Americans finally found it intolerable to defend a position where at one level they were saying, `We do not want and never will support the Khmer Rouge coming back to power in Cambodia', and at the same time they were voting in the United Nations to recognise the Khmer Rouge as part of the official government of Cambodia. The position and policy of the Americans were the ultimate in political contortions, convulsions and hypocrisy. At one level they said they did not want the Khmer Rouge in any way back in government but on another level they were recognising them as the official government. In the end the American public woke up to this stupid dichotomy and put pressure on the American Congress and Administration. I congratulate the Bush Administration and, in particular Mr Baker, the Secretary of State of the United States of America, for making the announcement of the change in American policy.

It broke the log jam and it broke it in particular with China. For the past 15 years China had the luxury of knowing that, no matter what it decided about Indo-China, it was secure because America would not have any dialogue with Vietnam. However, the day the Americans announced they were going to start talking to Vietnam, the Chinese realised they no longer had the luxury of always saying no, and that if they did not watch out they would be alone and isolated in the peace process. They had to readjust their thinking about the peace process to make sure they were not left out and that America did not reach an agreement with Vietnam over a peace settlement in Cambodia. Once that position was reached by the Chinese, they were willing in the Security Council discussion of the Permanent Five (P5) to vote for the peace plan outlined by Australia, including the call for free elections and United Nations administration and so forth. That would also put pressure on Khmer Rouge by saying, `The game is up. You cannot consistently veto the peace process with other Cambodian factions'.

I believe that has led to the situation where we now have agreement within the P5 and in the United Nations that this process can work. We still do not have agreement in the Supreme National Council (SNC), which has been formed of the four factions, about how it will operate, but we do have an opportunity for agreement to be reached in the next month or so. It is not certain, and this is the area where there is still some pessimism. But I do not think it is appropriate today for the Opposition to start criticising the Minister for, quite rightly, pointing out in his statement that the whole plan may still fail because the SNC may not reach agreement about its composition and its operations. The Minister was forthright in saying that that is a risk. If he had not said it, Senator Hill would probably have been even more vocal in his criticism of the Minister's statement.

The fact that the Minister has said that there is some chance that the process will not come to a successful conclusion does not mean that the whole process is wrong. I again reiterate: if it is wrong, what does the Opposition want to put in its place? It puts nothing in its place, except to imply that we should automatically support the Hun Sen Government and probably even supply it with arms to fight the Khmer Rouge. That fighting would lead to extensive killing in Cambodia over a longer period and the Cambodians would be the great sufferers.

I think it is hypocritical of Senator Hill to claim that he is against killing when he is willing to denigrate the only plan that is on the table anywhere in the world which, if implemented, will guarantee an end to hostilities. What he is proposing is a long war of attrition. Unfortunately, that may be what will occur if the peace process falls apart, but if it falls apart it should not be a matter of triumph for the Opposition; it should be a matter of considerable concern and disappointment that there will be ongoing killing, disagreement and conflict inside Cambodia, in which the ordinary Cambodian people-overwhelmingly the peasants-will be the major sufferers.

I think Mr Ruddock in the other place and I are the only members of the present Parliament who have visited Cambodia on two occasions in recent years. When I was there in July this year I saw the consequences of the increased fighting by the Khmer Rouge. I visited the displacement camps which now hold some 150,000 people. I should point out to the Senate that recently the Australian Government announced a special aid grant through non-government organisations (NGOs) of some $1m to provide humanitarian assistance such as food, medicines, basic utensils and housing materials, such as canvas and so on, for these camps. Anybody who had been to visit those camps would have been appalled at what he or she saw. There were children who were clearly suffering from malnutrition and people living in appalling conditions, basically with no sanitation. This was at the end of the dry season and I could not imagine what the camp I saw would be like after a few days of the wet season-it would have been nothing but a mud heap.

Australia has made a major aid contribution to these camps. I think of all the Western countries it has been the biggest contributor of aid to help overcome the problems of the people in these displaced camps. Since 1983, Australia has also been the biggest aid donor to Cambodia of any Western country. All of our aid, of course, is provided via NGOs. I must pay a tribute, as I have done previously in this place, to the magnificent work of Australian aid workers in Cambodia. Most of those people who work there, if not all, put their health at risk by working in conditions where practically every known tropical disease in the world is prevalent. But those aid workers are willing to put up with that and work in appalling conditions as part of their commitment to help the people of Cambodia. I have no doubt that, whatever the outcome of the conflict in Cambodia in the immediate future, in the long term those aid workers who have been there for a decade or more will be remembered by the Cambodian people as their true friends. A friendship will be established and maintained between the people of Australia and Cambodia which will endure for a long time to come and this will establish a long term relationship between Australia and Cambodia that can benefit not only the Cambodian people but also Australia. I pay tribute to those aid workers, many of whom are working in appalling conditions, often at some risk to their health.

In recent times, some aid workers in Cambodia have been risking their lives due to attacks from the Khmer Rouge. At one place near Siem Reap I was told that an international aid team of doctors was carrying out operations in a makeshift hospital with machine guns under the operating table with which to defend themselves in case the Khmer Rouge burst into the hospital and attempted to shoot them. That is the level of the commitment of the aid workers in that country, of which Australia has a large proportion, and I pay tribute to them.

I believe that this statement is an important one. It will not be the last such statement and it will not be the last time we debate the issue of Cambodia in this chamber. I hope that sometime next year we can have an extensive debate after a peace agreement has been signed and after the United Nations has been asked into the country to conduct the administration and the holding of elections so that the Cambodian people can choose the government that they want.

Senator Bourne said that there was an assessment that the Khmer Rouge may get 30 per cent of the vote in that election. I find that hard to believe, but let us remember that if we believe in democracy and if the people of Cambodia choose to vote for the Khmer Rouge that is their business and they will take the consequences of it. The people of any country take the consequences when there is a free election and the people vote a government in, so long as the election is free, fair and properly conducted.

Despite the problems surrounding the formation of the SNC, I think that is the last problem to be overcome. It is not a major problem, but it is a difficult one. A formula will probably be worked out-I certainly hope so-in the coming weeks so that the Paris peace conference can begin. If it is, the documents will be signed and the Secretary-General will be invited by the SNC to take over the important parts in the administration of Cambodia. When that is achieved during the next few months, as I have said before in this chamber and elsewhere, that will mean the end of the longest war of the twentieth century-a war that has been going on for 50 years in Indo-China. Most of that time the fighting has been in Cambodia, Vietnam or Laos. It is a war that will rank in the history of human civilisation as being as horrible as the Thirty Years War of the seventeenth century in western Europe or some of the great wars of the feudal age in western Europe. In my view, it is no credit to the Western world that much of this fighting in Cambodia and in Indo-China has been exacerbated by the wrongly thought out policies of Western countries.

That is why, whatever our mistakes in the past have been and whatever our disagreements have been in a partisan way within Australia, Australia does have a moral obligation to be concerned to have a peaceful outcome in Cambodia and Indo-China, because we have been involved in the conflict in one form or another. I think it is incumbent upon all Australians, whatever their views, that we take this responsibility and do whatever we can to end this long, terrible and unfortunate war. The Minister's statement today gives a clear indication that our country and our Government have done more than any other Western government and Western country to achieve peace in Cambodia. When the history of peace in Cambodia is written, the Australian Government and Foreign Ministers Hayden and Gareth Evans, with the backing of their Government, will have pride of place as having achieved that peace. In my view, they will rank with Thai Prime Minister Chatichai and the Foreign Minister of Indonesia, Ali Alatas, in getting the important breakthroughs in this very complicated problem of how to achieve peace. Therefore, it is with great pleasure that I support the statement that has been tabled today by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement that we are discussing today provides an excellent summary of events and achievements to date. As such, it is a very useful document. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and his Department should be congratulated on the progress that has been made towards a comprehensive settlement, on their enormous commitment and their strenuous efforts to achieve this progress, especially on the part of Australia's chief negotiator, Mr Michael Costello.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's determination to pursue the comprehensive settlement, as long as there remains some reasonable prospect of success, should be supported. It should be acknowledged that public discussion of other options at this time might undermine the delicate process under way. However, we look forward to public discussion on other options, should it be necessary to abandon the comprehensive settlement process. We trust that discussion of such options would canvass the views, observations and experience of those members of parliament and the community and, in particular, those community organisations which have been working with the people of Cambodia, both inside the country and on the border, who have a particular interest in and knowledge of Cambodia.

The Minister has attempted to explain away some expressed concerns with regard to the participation of the Khmer Rouge. Firstly, in order to avoid continued civil war in Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge must be involved, and China has agreed to discontinue support for the Khmer Rouge only in the context of a comprehensive settlement involving all parties. That is a huge stumbling block-the continued support by the Chinese of the Khmer Rouge. Somehow or other more international pressure has to be brought to bear on China. But can we really depend on the international legal undertaking by China that it will desist from supporting the Khmer Rouge with military options once a comprehensive settlement is made? This is a promise by a country which continually shows blatant disregard for international opinion. We saw how carelessly it responded to criticism about the Tiananmen Square event and how quickly trade events overtook the outrage of the international community which was expressed at that time.

Secondly, the Khmer Rouge is using the time delay in the implementation of the United Nations (UN) peace plan to make the major military gains. The Minister reassures us that his intelligence assessments are that there is no prospect of an early military takeover. I hope, in that respect, his intelligence sources are correct. We do know that in the meantime each week several hundred more Cambodians are being maimed or killed by landmines on the roads and in the fields. The Khmer Rouge does not need tanks to continually sabotage and break down the spirit of the people.

The state of Cambodia is continually being worn down. There are very good reasons for us to increase our support inside the country to ensure that the system does not break down completely before the UN plan is implemented. That is why I ask that if the Minister acknowledges that Vietnamese troops have left Cambodia, why will the Government not recognise Cambodia so as to allow aid and trade to flow through and to help prevent the ongoing destabilisation of the current government, which has struggled for over 10 years to survive without realistic outside support and recognition? Coming on top of the despicable events of the Pol Pot regime, it deserved much more attention and support than it got from the international community.

If Australia recognises states, not governments, why are we not providing all the assistance we can and should be providing to the state of Cambodia? Why do we not have full bilateral relations? We know that officials in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have opted for such recognition, as have many aid agencies around the world. What is blocking a decision to go ahead and offer such recognition to allow for a realistic supply of aid? I know the Minister will not like my quoting John Pilger on this, but this letter from him, published in the Sydney Morning Herald today, may begin to provide some of the answers:

The so-called Evans ``peace plan'' for Cambodia came to light just one year ago. It was the direct result of public concern, expressed through the media and ALP branches, that the Hawke Government was selling out Cambodia to a revitalised Khmer Rouge, as part of Washington's continuing war of revenge against Vietnam . . .
I think that last phrase is telling; that, in fact, Washington has a great deal to do with our non-recognition of Cambodia. I continue:

Indeed, at last year's Paris conference on Cambodia, none was more zealous that Senator Gareth Evans in supporting US and Chinese plans to bring back the Khmer Rouge as part of a ``comprehensive settlement''. In his own handwriting, Senator Evans proposed changes to an Australian briefing document so that reference to Pol Pot's ``genocide'' was eradicated.

Last week's announcement by Premier Hun Sen that the Phnom Penh Government would not resign and allow Pol Pot the opportunities offered by the UN plan (in effect, Washington's plan) should bring home to the Australian Government that its ``initiative'' serves only to waste time, and lives, and in Cambodia.
I think that last week's statement is really a turning point in this debate, and that is why we need a reassessment of the Australian Government's position. I return to John Pilger's letter:

Recently I was told by a member of the Hawke Government that the Department of Foreign Affairs had a contingency plan to recognise the Hun Sen government ``around next July'' should the UN plan fail. In other words, the Australian Government is prepared to allow Pol Pot to press home his military advantage for another eight months before backing the only opponents to his return to power.

On the question of continued fighting and power plays during the transitional period and following elections, assuming the elections do not favour the Khmer Rouge-and, of course, that is a big question mark, as Senator Bourne has alluded to-how will the international community ensure that the Khmer Rouge is not supplied with arms? This includes the big question about China continuing to supply arms-but not only limited to China. The world is full of enterprising arms dealers who know no international boundaries and, of course, have no moral scruples whatsoever. I believe that the Thai military, for example, is in an excellent position to continue to exploit the situation of demand and supply in the region. I firmly urge the Minister not to underestimate in any way the power, cunning or resourcefulness of the Khmer Rouge. I am sorry that the Minister's statement did not address the question of Khmer Rouge disarmament during the transition process. This obviously is a big gap and probably a question that would not be easy to tackle; nor was there any mention of human rights violations in the refugee camps in Thailand.

I was also disappointed that although the Minister criticised China-and that is well-deserved-he made no mention of United States (US) aid to non-communist faction members of the coalition or the camps on Thai soil that I have just referred to. There have been many allegations of illegal United States military assistance and British military assistance directly to Pol Pot. In that regard I quote Gary Klintworth in Australian Society of August 1990:

The US annually provides at least $US20 million in cash. Much of it is used for military purposes, according to testimony by William Colby, former Director of the CIA, and Jeremy Stone, president of the Federation of American Scientists. They were appearing before the Subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific Affairs of the US Senate Committee on Foreign Relations on 28 February 1990.

There is a lot of detailed evidence about what they said to that Committee. Some of the US aid is allegedly syphoned off to the Khmer Rouge, which is logical given that the ANS and the Khmer People's National Liberation Front have been joined with the Khmer Rouge since 1982 in a coalition dedicated to overthrowing Hun Sen. Of course, there have been allegations quoting members of the Special Air Service Regiment from the United Kingdom and senior American military officials who have decided that they cannot, in conscience, any longer support this military backing for the Khmer Rouge and have decided to speak out publicly against their former involvement. Their words ought to be taken seriously.

The Cambodian people have worked hard for the last 10 years to rebuild their country peacefully and against all odds. They have received little international support and encouragement; no opportunities for trade or investment; no access to international development assistance other than through non-government organisations, which have been doing a fantastic job. Is it any wonder that the country is now experiencing extreme difficulties with the withdrawal of Eastern Bloc support? The Soviet Union, which used to give it some support, is obviously far too busy with its own domestic problems to continue any kind of support whatsoever. So it is most important for humanitarian reasons, and for the future stability of the region, that other countries come in and fill that gap.

Many Australian aid agencies urge the immediate recognition of the state of Cambodia, to thus give a lead to many other countries who are worried about the possible return of the Khmer Rouge. The people of Cambodia deserve our official government support immediately. I have to admit a bias here, although I have not been to Cambodia, in favour of saving people's lives, especially the lives of innocent people caught in the international power struggles. This is a particularly callous power struggle between China and the United States. The United States wants to make the Vietnamese pay for the embarrassment caused in the loss of the Vietnam war. These two countries get together at international conferences now to discuss these peace plans without paying enough attention to the will and the struggle of ordinary people on the ground.

Unlike many politicians in this country, I respect the work, the diligence and the hands-on research and compassion of Australian expatriate journalist John Pilger. People often try to downgrade his comments because they are challenging and uncomfortable. I will conclude with the positive aspects of his letter which was printed in the Sydney Morning Herald today:

By recognising Phnom Penh, the Australian Government would give a significant lead to many governments with deep misgivings about the UN plan. It would not be long, I believe, before Pol Pot was excluded from both the diplomatic chain he has used so effectively and the ``peace process'' over which he has been allowed to operate a veto.

At the same time, Australia could build on its good relations with the Thai Government and give all support to Premier Chatichai's courageous efforts to get rid of the Khmer Rouge from Thai soil and to reach out to Phnom Penh. I say courageous, because Washington has repeatedly threatened to cut off trade preferences to the Thais if they continue with their peace initiatives.

In addition, a clear statement by Senator Evans, calling on China to cut all its links with Pol Pot, would reinforce the isolation of Asia's Nazis. If the Australian Government wants to be remembered for other than obsequiousness to great power interests, now is the time. Wait much longer, Senator Evans, and it will be simply too late for a nation which desperately needs all our help.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —All senators are looking for a peaceful and stable outcome for the people of Cambodia. We in the Opposition recognise that the proposal by the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) a year ago for a comprehensive settlement is an ideal solution. Our concern all through this year, when it was seen that there was an initial failure for the comprehensive plan to be accepted by the four factions, and even after the acceptance by the P5 and the Paris conference, was that it was still not going to be achieved. Our scepticism has grown to the point where we are looking at a more realistic or more achievable way of gaining the stability, the settlement, the peace and the democracy for the people of Cambodia to which we all aspire.

SPEECH.PARA: In the debate which has occurred internationally and in this chamber, where the keenest alternative to the Government's comprehensive plan has been that put forward by the Opposition, in particular through Senator Hill, there has now come this opportunity for the Foreign Minister to put down another statement on the situation in Cambodia. I recognise that, for the first time, it directly addresses the criticisms which many around the world, not least the Opposition, have made of Senator Evans's proposals in the comprehensive plan. That centres around the assessment of the Khmer Rouge. It is because there is not a genuine trust in this plan as a result of the past and present role of the Khmer Rouge that it has been essential, we have argued, for the Australian Government and for all governments to contemplate a solution that excludes the Khmer Rouge. It is that alternative that has been here addressed for the first time by the Australian Government.

Whilst there is nothing new in the Minister's statement, whilst there are no new initiatives, whilst there is no announcement even of his own plan to visit Cambodia-as was speculated in the newspapers over recent days-whilst there is no answer to the specific questions that I put earlier this week in Question Time to the Minister about Cambodia, and whilst there is a great deal in the statement that has no real significance at all, the element that is new and that is significant is that the Minister is trying to address the question of the Khmer Rouge.

There are hints in the ministerial statement put forward today of a plan B, a second alternative, and that that second alternative is the view the Opposition has been advocating as an option for consideration by this country and internationally.

I support the remarks of my colleague Senator Hill earlier in this debate. I share the emphasis he places upon realistic assessments and not just `hope so' statements. The position of the Australian Government and of Senator Evans is still a `hope so' position. Senator Schacht, who supported the Minister, finished his speech by saying, `I certainly hope so'. I think that is the theme of Government speakers and, indeed, of the Australian Government.

This statement, along with the comprehensive plan announced a year ago, is a `hope so' statement. I feel that we have not been given in this statement any basis, any ground, for believing that that `hope so' statement will be achieved. We must come to terms with a realistic assessment of the Khmer Rouge and the connection of the Khmer Rouge with China. I wish to address my remarks chiefly to that area.

I reiterate that there has been no answer to the three questions I put very directly to the Minister last Tuesday. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the question I asked and the answer given by the Minister, Senator Evans.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and concerns Cambodia. I refer to reports that Khmer Rouge military activity is escalating, especially in the western region, including Siem Reap province, and also directed to control one of the two major east-west roads in Cambodia. In view of the Government's support for the Khmer Rouge and this faction's inclusion in the settlement process, I ask: firstly, what arrangements in the settlement process have been agreed on in order to disarm and contain the Khmer Rouge? Secondly, what mechanisms are in place to prevent Pol Pot and his deputies from returning to power? Is it in fact the case that the P5 agreement provides no assurances at all? Finally, is it true that Son Sen, one of the Khmer Rouge representatives on the Supreme National Council, is a Pol Pot deputy and allegedly responsible for gross human rights violations during their period in power?

—It is a gross caricature of the Government's position-or anyone's position-to describe support for the United Nations peace plan as involving support for the Khmer Rouge. The matter in issue is support for a peace proposal that will genuinely bring comprehensive, lasting and durable peace to that country in a way that no other peace proposal so far identified is capable of doing, bearing in mind the necessity for any successful peace proposal to take out of the picture external sources of supply, in particular to the Khmer Rouge, which are crucial in maintaining that particular group's role and influence.

SPEECH.PARA: Many questions are raised by Senator Teague's multipronged question. I am proposing to deliver in this place on Thursday a major ministerial statement on the whole subject of Cambodia. Those questions will all be addressed in that statement. Until then I think I will ask Senator Teague and anyone else who is interested to hang on to their hats.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Senator Hill has already analysed the lack of answers to these three questions that I put only two days ago. I note that there have been no answers even though in my question I directly addressed the difficulties with the Khmer Rouge. We have felt this way for many months. The Minister, in his statement today, is directly addressing his own assessments of the Khmer Rouge, but he did not have the information or he did not wish to put on public record any answers to the specific questions that the Opposition is addressing with regard to the Khmer Rouge.

SPEECH.PARA: To that extent, the statement today is disappointing: it is not comprehensive; it does not satisfy the Opposition; it does not answer, for example, our concern that there is no mechanism in the P5 agreements or in any of the solutions put forward by the Paris conference or, indeed, by Senator Evans's plan to exclude Pol Pot and the others most responsible for the genocide of the Cambodian people; it does not answer the particular status of Son Sen, who is one of the representatives of the Khmer Rouge on the Supreme National Council; it does not address the question of whether the Australian Government will take any action in the International Court of Justice for genocide against the Khmer Rouge leadership; and it does not give any reassurance at all to the Opposition in its concerns about the Khmer Rouge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we adjourn, I inform the Senate that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs will meet in committee room No. 18 at 6.30 p.m. to consider the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990.

—In the Minister's statement today about Cambodia there is nothing new, there is no new initiative. It is a defensive statement. It is also a `hope so' statement. The comprehensive plan which we in the Opposition recognise as an ideal solution, given the present circumstances in that troubled country, is so distant from being realised, as it has been all of the months of this year, that it remains a `hope so' statement.

SPEECH.PARA: The key to the Minister's statement is those pages after page 13 which address the questions that have been raised about the Australian-United Nations peace plan. It is in an attempt to answer questions that have been raised by the Opposition in this chamber, and similar questions that have been raised internationally, that the Minister, Senator Evans, has brought down this statement today. He is seeking to defend the ideal that he has put forward as a solution, as Australia's suggestion to the international community and to the four factions involved in Cambodia, to find a stable and peaceful outcome for that country.

As one in the Opposition who has raised the questions that the Minister has set out here and attempts to defend his position by answering, I am not convinced and I am not reassured. I am glad that he has begun to address those questions. As I was saying before the suspension of the sitting, for the first time, there is in this statement an attempt by the Minister, Senator Evans, to put forward a transition to plan B. plan A is the comprehensive plan. Plan B is a solution that excludes the Khmer Rouge.

I do not trust the Khmer Rouge. I do not believe the majority of the Cambodian people trust the Khmer Rouge. How can they? Not only did the Khmer Rouge kill more than a million of their own people but also, even now they are excluded to defensive positions as bases for their guerrilla warfare against the present Government in Phnom Penh. They are torturing, maiming, killing and destroying the people.

I find it impossible that even Senator Evans can trust the Khmer Rouge. It is the distrust that the Australian people feel towards this brutalising group of extremists that leads to the scepticism that we have sought to address, not out of any wish to detract from Australia contributing a solution to this unhappy country, but in order to stir the Minister and this Government to be realistic, and to see that several options need to be considered at once. One option is the comprehensive plan that Australia has initiated, but that was a year ago. Another option is a solution that excludes the Khmer Rouge.

I believe that in the statement we have before us we have the first signs of the Minister building a bridge to plan B. This will allow him in the months ahead, as events develop, to start to define, along with other countries and especially the Cambodian people, a solution that I will now try, for my own part, to define.

I believe that if the Khmer Rouge are vetoing a comprehensive plan they ought to be shown, by the international community and by the other factions, that a solution may be found that does exactly exclude them and that will lead to the necessity for the other three factions, together with international support, to beat the Khmer Rouge on the battlefield. The only substantial support for the Khmer Rouge is the Chinese Government's supply of ammunition and military equipment. I mention China, and I note that Senator Vallentine also mentioned China. In his statement, on page 14 especially but in other parts, too, the Minister addresses the connection between the Khmer Rouge and China. In fact, he builds his comprehensive plan-plan A-on the basis that he believes that China is likely not to accept any other way forward but the comprehensive plan, that is, a plan that is agreeable and agreed to by the Khmer Rouge. Page 14 of the statement says:

The simple truth of the matter is that unless and until China is prepared to withdraw from the picture-and only the UN peace plan seems capable of delivering that-then whatever Australia and other countries choose to do, the continuation of bloody civil war is inevitable.

The Minister in his statement today is saying that China, it appears, is only prepared to withdraw and not supply the Khmer Rouge with military equipment and ammunition if there is a comprehensive plan.

It is interesting that in this carefully written statement the Minister, Senator Evans, uses the word `seems'. He is not sure. He thinks this is the most likely situation, but he is not sure. Why is he not sure? Because for some 18 months now he has not talked seriously to China, apart from speaking to the Foreign Minister in a brief meeting on 1 October in New York, just a couple of months ago.

In my concluding remarks I wish to call upon the Minister, Senator Evans, and this Government to begin again a dialogue with China. I believe that alternative Chinese responses need to be explored by the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs, and it needs to be tested as to whether there will be grounds on which the Chinese will cease to supply military equipment and ammunition to the Khmer Rouge. I am not extraordinarily hopeful that ideal solutions will emerge in this matter. Frankly, this question of Cambodia is the one significant area in which I have disagreed with Chinese foreign policy statements. There are so many issues over the last 10 years, in the period when Deng Xiaoping has been ascending, and when China has been looking to the outside world and concentrating on its own economic development, in which we have agreed with China.

There has been an extraordinary parallel in the views of Australia and the views of China on foreign policy matters. We have both sought to see the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics withdraw from Afghanistan; to withdraw from Vietnam; to withdraw its aid through Vietnam in its occupation of Cambodia over the last decade; and to withdraw its armaments and military deployment around China. There has been a parallel view in seeking solutions with some justice for Third World countries; in attitudes to world economic issues; in China's attitudes to its own region in the Far East; and in its very friendly foreign policy towards this country.

In all those issues I include the present end of the Cold War and the attitude of China, as a member of the Permanent Five, in contributing with all the other nations of the world to a solution in the Gulf. I welcome the areas of agreement with China, but over the last 10 years this one issue has stood out as being an extraordinary problem in any dialogue between Australia and China. It is an area that we have not sufficiently addressed. I call upon the Minister for Foreign Affairs to reopen the dialogue that was cut off by the Tiananmen Square massacre on 4 June last year and to begin to talk to China, not least for the reason of gaining a sensible set of direct inputs from it on the question of Cambodia.

Of course, there are other reasons to talk to China at this time. There is the call that Australians want to make to China to see international standards and human rights established in that country.
