If we take the ball and run away, if we isolate ourselves from any kind of discussion with China at the ministerial level, how do we know what opportunities we are missing? In fact, the Opposition knows because we went there in September. Party delegations from the coalition went as well in October and in November. We know, first hand, that there may be fruitful outcomes in Cambodia. We know that there are fruitful outcomes with regard to economic relations between our countries, with regard to the Gulf and with regard to a range of international questions. In this question of Cambodia, as much as in the domestic and other international matters involving Australia and China, the Minister's statements here, his assertions, should be tested by direct dialogue with Chinese Ministers and other representatives.

China is in a transition period at the moment where the straightforward, genuine statements of a friend such as Australia will be listened to. It is possible for us to put our position on Cambodia clearly to the Chinese leaders and, I believe, see China come to a position where it no longer supplies the weapons of war to anybody in Indo-China, including the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia. It is the burden of the Australian relationship with China that the Minister has rightly identified in his analysis of the Khmer Rouge in his statement today. I believe that what I have been calling plan B depends upon China. That in turn depends upon us, as a nation, having dialogue with that country.

I conclude by saying that, on balance, this Government statement by Senator Evans on Cambodia has nothing new to say, announces no new initiatives and continues to defend the comprehensive plan announced a year ago. The operative word is `defend' because it is not fresh, it is not initiating; it is in fact a defence which leaves open the analysis of moving to plan B, to a comprehensive solution that sees free and open internationally supervised elections in Cambodia after the exclusion of the Khmer Rouge. In all realism, we must explore that second option, the option which the Opposition has put forward over the last year, at the same time as the `hope-so' option that the Minister has put forward as the comprehensive plan.

Time is of the essence. There is a deterioration in the Hun Sen Government's position in Cambodia. There is a curtailing of aid from the Soviet Union and eastern Europe, which are in no position, given their domestic circumstances, or even their political inclinations these days, to be of the assistance that they have been over the last decade to Cambodia through Vietnam. Those days have gone. The Hun Sen Government is very much by itself. It is with a short window of opportunity that we will see a just and democratic outcome for the people of Cambodia. That is why I, as yet another Opposition senator, put forward this second alternative, this plan B, this more realistic approach, and urge the Government to give it close attention.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The speeches read as follows-
GOVERNMENT AND GOVERNMENT INSTRUMENTALITIES (APPLICATION OF LAWS) BILL 1990

The Governments and Government Instrumentalities (Application of Laws) Bill is substantially the same as the Commonwealth and Commonwealth Instrumentalities (Application of Laws) Bill 1989 which was introduced into the Senate on 26 September 1989 and which lapsed with the dissolution of the House of Representatives. The title has been changed because the new Bill contains a provision to clarify the position concerning the application of Commonwealth and non-self-governing Territory laws to State Governments.

The main purpose of the Bill is to make clear what kinds of State and Territory laws apply to the Commonwealth and Commonwealth instrumentalities. In particular, it is designed to resolve long-standing uncertainties as to the extent of the Commonwealth's implied constitutional immunities from State law, and to remove problems created by a decision of the High Court in 1986 concerning section 64 of the Judiciary Act.

The legal position of the Commonwealth in relation to State legislation is at present very unclear. The Commonwealth has acted on the view-supported in a number of High Court judgments-that, because of implications in the Constitution, the Commonwealth, its servants and agents and many of its instrumentalities have extensive immunities from State legislation. However, there has been longstanding uncertainty as to the scope of these immunities. For example, in 1953 in The Commonwealth v Bogle (1953) 89 CLR 229 at pages 259-260, Mr Justice Fullagar, whose view was shared by 3 other Justices, including the then Chief Justice Sir Owen Dixon, said that a State Parliament `has no power over the Commonwealth' but added that the Commonwealth may become `affected' by State laws. These principles have been subjected to criticism by some eminent writers. A proposal to amend the Constitution in relation to the matter of Commonwealth immunities was discussed at the 1985 Brisbane meeting of the Constitutional Convention but no agreement was reached between the Commonwealth and the States. In its final report in 1988 the Constitutional Commission recommended that no alteration should be made to the Constitution in this respect, recognising that the matter could be addressed through Commonwealth legislation.

In the early years of Federation the Commonwealth Parliament addressed the issue of the Commonwealth's immunities in the particular area of civil liability. Interim legislation was enacted in 1902 modelled on colonial legislation which provided remedies against the Crown. This legislation was replaced, in substantially similar terms, by section 64 of the Judiciary Act 1903 which is still in force. It provides that-

`in any suit to which the Commonwealth or a State is a party, the rights of parties shall as nearly as possible be the same, and judgment may be given and costs awarded on either side, as in a suit between subject and subject'.

Section 64 applies only to civil proceedings to which the Commonwealth or a State is a party. In criminal proceedings under State law the legal position depends on other Commonwealth legislation and on the scope of the Commonwealth's implied immunities.

Until 1986 the Commonwealth acted on the view that section 64 of the Judiciary Act had a very limited effect in subjecting the Commonwealth to legislation to which it was not otherwise subject. Much Commonwealth and Territory legislation was drafted on that basis. However, the High Court's decision in The Commonwealth v Evans Deakin Industries Ltd (1986) 161 CLR 254, means that section 64 of the Judiciary Act subjects the Commonwealth, and also Commonwealth instrumentalities, to a wide range of State and Territory legislation as if the Commonwealth were an ordinary person. Section 64 can even subject the Commonwealth to State legislation that does not bind the State, and in some cases to Commonwealth legislation that would not otherwise apply to the Commonwealth.

This result was almost certainly not intended by the Parliament that enacted the Judiciary Act in 1903 at a time well before the burgeoning of legislation of all kinds. As a result of the Evans Deakin decision, the Commonwealth is subject to the risk of incurring unforeseeable kinds of liabilities under whatever legislation the States might enact from time to time in relation to ordinary persons. The decision in Evans Deakin would also apply to self-governing Territory legislation and to Imperial legislation still in force in Australia.
In the interests of the community, the Commonwealth and the States and Territories, the legal position should be clarified and those risks removed.

The Government has examined various alternative solutions to the problem. One approach considered was to enact Commonwealth Acts from time to time listing by name all the State and Territory Acts and subordinate legislation and instruments that should, or should not, apply to the Commonwealth. However, that approach would be impracticable. Very substantial resources would be needed to monitor existing and new State Acts, self-governing Territory Acts and subordinate legislation (including local government legislation). There would inevitably be delays pending the enactment of the Commonwealth legislation. Meanwhile, the Commonwealth could have incurred obligations or liabilities, or rights could have accrued, where particular State laws had inappropriately applied to the Commonwealth. It would be undesirable to seek to avoid such obligations or rights by means of retrospective legislation.

The Government believes that the only feasible approach is to specify in an Act some classes of State and self-governing Territory legislation (defined to include any relevant continuing Imperial legislation) that should apply to the Commonwealth and its instrumentalities, and to have regulation-making powers to deal with other classes of laws and with any special problems-the regulations being subject, of course, to Parliamentary scrutiny and disallowance. This provides the necessary flexibility to respond quickly to new State or self-governing Territory legislation. The Bill follows this course.

I turn now to outline the main provisions of the Bill. I mention, first, that the Bill treats self-governing territories other than the Australian Capital Territory-that is, the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island-as though they were States. The position under Australian Capital Territory laws is not affected by the Bill since those laws are either covered by section 27 of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 or are Ordinances made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910 that can, if necessary, be amended by the Governor-General in Council to clarify the position of the Commonwealth and Commonwealth instrumentalities.

Clauses 5 and 6 of the Bill set out exhaustively, except in relation to Australian Capital Territory laws, the extent to which the Commonwealth is to be subject to Commonwealth, State and Territory laws.

Under the Bill any changes in the existing position will only apply to events or circumstances occurring after the commencement of the relevant provisions of the Bill. Also, a State, Northern Territory or Norfolk Island law will be applied to the Commonwealth only if the relevant State or Territory is itself bound by that law.

Under clause 5, the Commonwealth will continue to be subject to Commonwealth and non-self-governing Territory legislation that is expressed to bind the Commonwealth or otherwise shows an intention to do so. In this respect clause 5, in providing that the Commonwealth is not bound unless the law discloses an intention to bind the Commonwealth, reproduces the general rule as recently decided by the High Court in Bropho v Western Australia (1990) 93 ALR 207.
In addition, the following classes of Commonwealth, State and Territory legislation are applied by the Bill itself to the Commonwealth:
(l) legislation concerning procedure in civil litigation; and

(2) legislation codifying, modifying or extending the common law with respect to liability in tort. State legislation on contributory negligence in actions for damages for negligence is one of many examples of such laws concerning tort liability.

In the case of laws codifying, modifying or extending the common law of tort the Bill makes an exception for provisions declared by regulations not to apply to the Commonwealth. This will enable the Commonwealth to be exempted from unforeseeable kinds of State or Territory legislation, although any accrued rights existing at the commencement of the regulations will not be affected (see clause 14(2)). The Government will consult the Governments of the States, the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island concerning any proposals to make regulations to exempt the Commonwealth from laws that would otherwise be applied to the Commonwealth by the Act.

The Bill also provides for other State, Northern Territory and Norfolk Island laws to apply to the Commonwealth if prescribed by regulations under the proposed Act. Since the contents of future legislation cannot be predicted, the Government does not consider it appropriate for legislation falling outside the listed categories to be automatically applied to the Commonwealth. The only feasible approach is to include a regulation-making power to include further State and self-governing Territory legislation. When required, regulations can be made quickly, but will still be subject to Parliamentary scrutiny. The regulations will be able to make appropriate modifications to the applied State and self-governing Territory provisions (see clause 6).

Laws applied to the Commonwealth by a provision of the Act or pursuant to a regulation would, by virtue of clause 13, apply only from the commencement of that provision or of that regulation (unless the regulation provides otherwise in accordance with sub-clause 13 (3)).

Regulations would be made so as to apply to the Commonwealth and Commonwealth personnel the provisions of the general motor traffic laws (except in so far as they provide, for instance, for the licensing of vehicles). This will preserve the present position according to the longstanding High Court decision in Pirrie v McFarlane (1925) 36 CLR 170. The Government does not intend that this Bill should be used as a means for the Commonwealth to avoid the operation of such laws. A similar comment applies, of course, to the application of general criminal laws to Commonwealth servants and agents.

Until special occupational health and safety legislation is enacted by the Commonwealth, regulations will also be made so as to apply occupational safety laws to the Commonwealth for the purpose of making the Commonwealth subject to an action in tort for damages for breach of a statutory duty. The Commonwealth will therefore continue to be civilly liable under these laws so that the practical result will be the same as in Strods v The Commonwealth [1982] 2 NSWLR 192 where the employee succeeded in an action against the Commonwealth on the basis of section 64 of the Judiciary Act.

Because of difficulties in formulating an appropriate general description of the classes of contract laws that are to apply to the Commonwealth, the Government has decided to apply to the Commonwealth specific classes of contract laws by the regulations. Examples of laws that will be applied by regulations include sale of goods laws, the Statute of Frauds concerning the enforceability of contracts, laws with respect to unconscionable contracts and laws with respect to the frustration of contracts.

Regulations will also be made applying State laws to the Commonwealth for the securing of the payment of moneys payable to sub-contractors. The provisions of such a State law-the Subcontractors' Charges Act 1974 (Qld)-were held by the High Court in the Evans Deakin case to have been applied to the Commonwealth by section 64 of the Judiciary Act 1903. Although many of the consequences of that decision are considered by the Commonwealth to be undesirable, the particular law in question in that case is of a kind that, in general, should apply to the Commonwealth.

The Government will be consulting the States, the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island to identify the various additional classes of State or Territory legislation that they would wish to see applied to the Commonwealth by the regulations.
Clause 7 contains provisions for determining the extent to which Commonwealth servants and agents are to be subject to Commonwealth, State and Territory laws.

Clauses 8, 9 and 10 of the Bill deal with the application of Commonwealth, State and Territory laws to Commonwealth corporations. While some Commonwealth corporations such as the Australian Postal Commission share the Commonwealth's immunities from State legislation, many do not do so, especially if engaged primarily in commercial activities. However, it is often very uncertain whether a particular statutory corporation shares the Commonwealth's immunities. The present tests involve factors such as the degree of Ministerial control. They are very difficult to apply. The Government believes that any Commonwealth statutory corporation should be immune from State legislation only to the extent (if any) provided by or under the legislation establishing the corporation or other legislation. However, the Bill provides that, in respect of laws existing at the commencement of the proposed Act, immunity can be given by regulations made under the Act before its commencement. Such commencement would be deferred by clause 2 (2) for one year to give time for the making of such regulations in all appropriate cases.
The Repatriation Commission, which is, in substance, a Department of the Commonwealth, is treated under the Bill as part of the Commonwealth rather than as a statutory authority.

Clause 11 of the Bill provides in effect that, in deciding whether a Commonwealth written law applies to a State or self-governing Territory (including the Australian Capital Territory), the same rule of interpretation will apply as in deciding whether a Commonwealth written law applies to the Commonwealth itself. The rule is that the law will not apply unless it discloses an intention to bind the State or self-governing Territory. This accords with the recent High Court decision in Bropho v Western Australia (1990) 93 ALR 207.

Clause 12 contains provisions for determining the extent to which agents or servants of a State or self-governing Territory are to be subject to laws of the Commonwealth and non-self-governing Territories.

Clause 13 limits the retrospective operation of laws applied under the Act. Clause 14 confers regulation-making powers for the purposes of the Bill and contains provisions that will ensure the preservation of accrued rights and liabilities where, pursuant to regulations under the Act, laws cease to apply to the Commonwealth or other persons.

Clause 15 of the Bill provides for complementary amendments to section 64 of the Judiciary Act. Section 64 will cease to operate in relation to rights created by a written law where the Commonwealth is not subject to the provisions of that law in accordance with the Bill or otherwise. The States will also be placed on the same footing as the Commonwealth in relation to section 64. However, section 64 will continue to apply in relation to unwritten laws-for example, the common law of tort which, in the absence of section 64, would not apply to the Commonwealth or a State because of the maxim that the Crown `can do no wrong'.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY BILL 1990
Purpose of Bill
Mr President, this Bill is for an Act to establish a statutory authority, to be called the Australian Sports Drug Agency.

The Bill will provide this country with an independent body to conduct a comprehensive drug testing and educational program for Australian sport. The establishment of the Agency is an integral part of the Government's commitment to achieve drug free sport in this country and to contribute to the global ``clean-up'' of sport.
The Bill sets out the objects, functions and powers of the Agency. It also covers a wide range of issues relating to the management and operation of the Agency.
Background
On 19 May 1988, the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts received the following reference:
``the use by Australian sportsmen and sportswomen of performance enhancing drugs and the role played by Commonwealth agencies''.

The Committee produced an Interim Report, in May 1989, and a Second Report, in May 1990, that in total stretch to over 1,000 pages. It has made 65 recommendations that are far reaching, touching on all the issues of concern in this problem area.

I take this opportunity to emphasise the Government's resolve to address the problem of drugs in sport. The use of performance enhancing drugs in sport is cheating. It is totally against the values that we have in Australia-the value of fair play, the value of reward for excellence and for dedication. We have a proud sporting record that has been built on the notion of fair play-of the best athlete winning, not the athlete with the best chemist.

I am pleased to say, Mr President, that the Government has accepted and already implemented the key recommendation of the Committee-namely the establishment of a comprehensive drug testing program. It has achieved this by establishing the Australian Sports Drug Agency as an extension of the Australian Sports Commission's Anti Drugs Program.

Although the Agency is functioning most effectively, there is a need to ensure the organisational, legal and financial independence of the Agency by establishing it as a statutory authority. The drug testing agency must be, and must be seen to be, totally divorced from any direct involvement in sports administration.

The Government response to the Senate Committee's reports was tabled in the Senate on 7 November. That document indicated the Government's intention to introduce this Bill to establish the Australian Sports Drug Agency as a statutory authority, thereby guaranteeing its independence, and Parliamentary scrutiny of its activities. This legislation is a further indication of this Government's continuing commitment to the task of eliminating drug use in sport.
Major Features of the Bill
The Bill outlines the objectives of the Agency, which are:
* to encourage the practice of sport free from the use of drugs;
* to encourage the development of programs to educate the sporting community at large about the dangers of using drugs in sport;
* to provide leadership in the development of a national strategy on drugs in sport;

* to encourage the establishment of a centralised drug sampling and testing program that exposes all competitors to drug sampling and testing at short notice both at sporting events and during training;
* to encourage State and Territory Governments and national, State and Territory sporting organisations to adopt uniform drug sampling and testing procedures;
* to encourage the development and maintenance of drug testing laboratories accredited by the International Olympic Committee; and
* to promote and encourage the adoption, at international level, of uniform sampling and testing procedures, and of educational programs relating to the use of drugs in sport.
The Bill defines the functions of the Agency, which include:

* the maintenance of an up-to-date schedule of prohibited performance enhancing drugs and doping methods. This will be the internationally recognised List of Doping Classes and Methods developed by the International Olympic Committee;
* the establishment and maintenance of a Register of Defaulting Competitors;
* the dissemination of information about likely penalties and testing procedures;
* the selection of competitors, times and places for testing;
* the collection of samples and arrangements for testing;
* the development and implementation of educational programs;
* the encouragement of uniform policies domestically and internationally on drugs in sport;
* the confirmation of Australia's compliance with international agreements on drugs in sport;
* the conduct of research into drug use in sport;
* the promotion of sports medicine and sports science research; and
* the establishment of a national information service and the provision of advice to the Minister.

The Bill also defines the powers that the Agency will have to undertake its activities and provides for the appointment by the Minister of a Chairperson, Deputy Chairperson, Chief Executive and not fewer than one nor more than three other Members of the Agency to exercise these powers.

Honourable senators should also note the powers and responsibilities of the Minister in relation to the Agency. The Government wishes to ensure that the Agency will work within the framework of Government objectives and policies. The Agency will be required to submit estimates for its proposed annual budget, produce an annual report, an annual operational plan and a strategic plan each of which must be approved by the responsible Minister. Its financial affairs will also be subject to scrutiny by the Auditor-General.

These provisions, together with those allowing the Minister to issue directions to the Agency and to seek information on specific activities, will ensure a proper degree of Ministerial overview and responsibility.

Mr President, this Bill has been framed following widespread consultation with interested parties including the interim Agency, the Australian Sports Commission, the Australian Olympic Committee, the Australian Commonwealth Games Association, the Human Rights Commission and the Privacy Commissioner.

This legislation reflects the privacy and human rights principles laid down in other Commonwealth legislation. In particular, only those who need to have access to information will be informed. The names of competitors who return a positive test result or who fail to provide a sample will not be published. The Government has also been concerned to protect the rights of athletes and has built into this legislation certain appeal rights to ensure athletes are protected.

The issues of protection of individuals' rights, the right of appeal and the process of investigation have also been raised with State sports Ministers and umbrella sports bodies such as the Australian Olympic Committee and the Australian Commonwealth Games Association and all have undertaken to develop policies consistent with the principles adopted by the Commonwealth.
The State and Territory sports Ministers have also undertaken to seek the introduction of complementary legislation once this legislation has commenced.

The Agency will be established as an independent testing authority. In taking this position the Government is conscious of the need to separate the testing process from the broader issue of the policy of drugs in sport. It was decided to provide the Agency with a relatively narrow and virtually non-discretionary role-namely the thorough and professional application of internationally approved drug sampling and testing procedures to detect drugs on the International Olympic Committee's list of banned substances and the notification of positive test results.

The Government wants to be in a position where the registering by the Agency of an athlete's name on the Register of Defaulting Competitors means only that he or she has recorded a positive test or failed to provide a sample. The issues of guilt or innocence, inadvertent or deliberate use, length of sanction, Commonwealth view on the appropriateness of the sanction and so on are therefore issues for Government and non-government authorities other than the Agency.

The Agency, therefore, will not be undertaking a range of related functions such as developing sports drug policies, liaising with law enforcement agencies, adjudicating on penalties imposed by sporting federations or conducting investigations, which the Senate Committee recommended.

The Government considers that these are more properly within the province of organisations other than the Agency. For example, drugs policy at Federal level is better handled by the Australian Sports Commission and by my Department in liaison with other Federal, State and Territory authorities. National sporting organisations also have a role to play in imposing penalties and giving athletes a fair hearing.

However, the Agency will not isolate itself from these broader issues. It will draw upon key areas of expertise such as the medical, legal, sporting and health education communities. It will have an international role in enhancing testing processes, bilateral and multilateral agreements, updating of the International Olympic Committee's list of banned substances and so on. It will have a significant education role. It will be involved, with the Australian Sports Commission, in discussions with national sporting bodies on uniform doping policies and sanctions.
Financial Impact Statement

The strategic and annual operational plan requirements are in line with the Government's commitment to overall financial management improvement within the public sector. In its strategic plan the Agency will be required to develop broad objectives in performing its functions and the manner in which it proposes to perform its functions. Ministerial endorsement and tabling of the plan in both Houses will be required.

The administrative and operational expenses relating to staff, travel, meetings, and day-to-day running costs of the Agency will be determined annually in the Budget. The Agency's budget in 1990/91 is $2.143 million which includes provision for 2,000 ``public interest'' tests to be fully funded from the Agency's budget. Tests additional to these will largely be requested by professional sports under contract to the Agency and will be conducted on a ``fee for service'' basis. It is hoped that this market will be progressively enlarged to include neighbouring countries as they develop their own drug testing programs.

Mr President, this legislation is further evidence of this Government's commitment to sport and its willingness to take positive steps to assist Australian sportsmen and sportswomen achieve their true potential by competing on an equal basis. The elimination of drugs in sport remains one of the key objectives of this Government. I am sure Senators on both sides of this House want to ensure that the long held Australian traditions of honesty and a fair go in sport are preserved for our children.
Mr President, this legislation is an integral step in that process.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES LEVIES AND CHARGES COLLECTION BILL 1990
This Bill is the first in a package of Bills relating to the collection of Primary Industries levies and charges.
The purpose of this Bill is to make provisions to enable measures which will allow more cost effective and efficient levy collection techniques to be utilized.

In 1988 this Government introduced measures to allow the Commonwealth to be reimbursed, out of industry funds, for expenses incurred in relation to the collection of the many levies, export charges and taxes and for other administrative expenses. These measures have meant that the Government has had to seek means, at industry insistence, to reduce the burden to industry, since initially the effect was to increase costs and in some cases cause hardship. This Bill and the complementary consequential provisions Bill have been designed bearing this primary aim in mind.

Other aims are to allow those required to pay small amounts to take the option of making larger accumulated payments over longer periods of time, to allow for regulations, as nominated by industry bodies, which provide for various optional collection methods and to obtain a consistency of approach to procedural matters currently embodied in more than 30 acts.

A review of all levies and charges collection legislation showed that while many administrative provisions were similar in all of the existing Acts, many required updating, some not having been upgraded since 1962. It is on this basis that this Bill has been developed.

This Bill provides one act which will deal with all Primary Industries levy and charge collection, thus enabling a uniformity of collection procedures which was previously not possible due to the large number of collection Acts in existence.
I now come to the main provisions in the Bill.

Most levies and charges are payable by the producer (or grower) of the produce. In order to reduce the costs of collection, particularly by reducing the number of collection points, the Bill provides that for the better securing of the payment of levy or charge, moneys may be collected from intermediaries (such as first purchasers, agents or exporters) on behalf of the producers.

The Bill stipulates that the Commonwealth may enter into collection agreements with States and Territories, and other collection organisations subject to full consultation with industry groups. Such agreements will assist in meeting the goal to keep costs to an absolute minimum by significantly reducing the number of collection points.

New levies and charges which may from time to time be implemented may be prescribed by regulation. In addition there are provisions which will allow for a greater flexibility in due dates for payment, and the introduction of techniques adopted recently in the horticultural industry.

Revised provisions for imposing penalty for late payment of levy or charge have been included reflecting changes in debt collection techniques.Powers of authorised persons seeking returns and information as well as for those carrying out field audits and investigations, have been modernised.

The Bill allows for an authorised person to publish certain information to specified bodies permitting proper administration of each levy or charge scheme. This provision is required to cover the requirements of the Privacy Act.
There are also enhanced but simplified methods to allow reconsideration and review of decisions in relation to remission of penalty for late payment and in certain other cases.
As I said earlier this Bill achieves an aim, of which many legislators will be envious, the consolidation of more than 30 Acts into one.

As the Commonwealth now recovers all costs of collection there are no net financial implications arising from this or the associated consequential provisions Bill. Any savings which are achieved will be immediately passed back to the relevant participating industries via reduced costs.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES LEVIES AND CHARGES (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1990
This Bill is the companion Bill to the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Bill 1990.

The purpose of this Bill is to make the consequential amendments to each of the Levy and Charge Imposition Acts needed following on from the main collection Bill outlined earlier. The specific amendments to each Act are contained in schedule 1 to the Bill.

Most of the provisions in this act are of a technical nature and arise because of the vastness of the scope of the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Bill 1990. Each of the Levy and Charge Acts previously had their collection Act incorporated and read as one with it. Such an approach is no longer considered appropriate where a considerable number of imposition Acts are now associated with a single collection Act. Accordingly, a new method allowing for the interpreting of words and phrases is utilised throughout this Bill. There are no financial implications arising from this Bill.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the accompanying explanatory memorandum.
NATIONAL CATTLE DISEASE ERADICATION TRUST ACCOUNT BILL 1990
This is the third Bill in the package relating to the collection of Primary Industries levies and charges.

The purpose of the Bill is to provide for the continued existence of the national cattle disease eradication trust account. The existing provisions contained in the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Collection Act 1964 are being re-enacted.
This is necessary following repeal of that Act through the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Consequential Provisions) Bill presented earlier.
The trust account facilitates the financial operations of the national program for cattle disease eradication.
There are no financial implications arising from this Bill.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators, and present the accompanying explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Third World Debt: An Australian View, seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows-
The Government's Response to the Recommendations in the Report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade
Third World Debt: An Australian View
December 1990
BACKGROUND
The Report arises from a reference given to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on 1 December 1987 calling for an inquiry and report on:

Appropriate Australian policy responses to the present international trade and financial situation, including debt, and, in particular, measures Australia could take to improve its own balance of trade in goods and services.

The Report was tabled in November 1989 together with a minority report dissenting from the findings and recommendations of the Report. A further report dealing with the Australian current account deficit and overseas debt will be tabled later.

Australian banks are not major lenders to heavily indebted third world countries and the scope for unilateral Australian action in relation to third world debt is limited. Nevertheless, Australia has humanitarian and foreign policy interests in the smooth resolution of the debt problems, and an important stake in the continued stability of the world economy and international financial markets. Moreover, we also believe that the problem of third world debt is not solely attributable to the policies of developing country governments and it is in the interests of all countries to promote a sustainable solution of this problem.

The Report envisages Australia promoting the interests of third world debtors in relevant international bodies of which Australia is a member, particularly the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
RESPONSES TO THE COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS:
The Committee recommends that:

R1. the Government, through its IMF Governor and through requests to the Executive Director representing Australia in the IMF, strongly urge the IMF to prepare social impact statements in respect of country adjustment programs that it initiates.
The Committee adopts as a recommendation:
R2. the UNICEF strategy of `adjustment with a human face' which aims at appropriately changing productive structures while also emphasising:
* more expansionary macro-economic policies;
* concentrating sectoral policy on employment and income earning areas including small farming and informal activities;
* a greater equity as well as cost effectiveness incomes policies and social programs;
* compensatory programs to protect health and nutrition of the poor during restructuring
* closer monitoring of major aspects of living standards, so as to respond more quickly to deprivation;
* ecological responsibility; and
* democratic control of economic policy-making.
Response to Rl and R2:

The Government agrees that international financial institutions (IFIs) such as the IMF and World Bank should discuss social and ecological considerations when negotiating adjustment finance packages with recipient countries, which is already happening. The governors of the IMF and World Bank have stated that essential ingredients in the design and sustainability of successful structural adjustment programs include broad public support and the integration of poverty and environmental considerations. During the replenishment negotiations for the International Development Association (the concessional lending arm of the World Bank) it was agreed that poverty alleviation and the environment would receive higher priority. Nevertheless the distribution among social groups of any austerity measures accompanying a structural adjustment/loan agreement is determined essentially by the political and social priorities of the recipient country.

There are constraints on the international financial institutions imposing social or political conditions on recipient countries. The IMF is required to pay due regard to the domestic social and political objectives of its members. The World Bank under its articles of agreement is prohibited from interfering in the political affairs of any member, and its decisions are not to be influenced by the political character of a member. As regards appropriate sectoral policy and the extent to which macro-economic policies should be expansionary, these are matters for careful determination in the light of the circumstances of each individual country. The IFIs seek to promote growth-oriented adjustment through their programs, involving structural adjustment conducive to growth and external financing sufficient to support a reasonable rate of growth. They have paid increasing attention to the impact of adjustment program on disadvantaged groups. The Australian Government endorses the World Bank's twin focus on economic growth and measures designed to address poverty alleviation directly.
The Government therefore accepts these recommendations in part.
The Committee adopts as a recommendation:

R3. the Government examine in detail international financial institutions with respect to the effects of conditionality on democratic policy making. As long as international economic and monetary issues are seen as only technical and abstract subjects which should be left to officials and bankers, some of the most important economic issues which affect the lives of all people are removed from the area of public debate. Greater political involvement of parliamentarians as well as international co-ordination of parliamentary action is a high priority in this respect.
Response to R3:

Programs supported by IFIs are adopted by the governments of the countries involved and it is the governments which carry the political and social responsibility for them. Nevertheless the IFIs, in their dealings with recipient countries, emphasise the importance of public awareness and acceptance of the need for programs as this contributes to a successful outcome. The economic conditions associated with IFI programs are considered technically essential to the attainment of external viability-that is, they are the minimum conditions consistent with success of the adjustment program. In some cases environmental conditions also apply. It would be inappropriate for individual parliamentarians to seek to impose their own political and social views on recipient country governments through the activities of the IFIs. The recommendation is therefore not accepted.
The Committee recommends that:

R4. in return for this indirect official support, the commercial banks should be required to participate in the debt and debt service reduction proposals, such as the Brady proposal, which are currently being promoted.
R5. a significant reduction in the amount of world debt stock, with appropriate variation country-by-country depending on ability to pay as measured by export earnings and volume of debt.
R6. with regard to remaining debt, measures should include, where appropriate:
* rescheduling principal repayments;
* reduction of interest rates to concessional levels; and

* recycling repayments by allowing local currency repayment into reinvestment funds with repatriation constraints (in order to provide investment resources for developing countries as well as limiting outflows).
Response to R4, R5 R6:

The Government supports the efforts to provide debt and debt service relief to countries which are incapable of servicing their existing debt in appropriate circumstances. The Brady plan is intended to reduce the cost of debt servicing and such measures as reduction of interest rates on existing debt are included amongst the options. The largest debt reduction and restructuring agreement so far under the Brady plan, between Mexico and its creditor banks, supported by the IMF, the World Bank and Japan, will have the effect of reducing external net transfers by Mexico by more than $US4 billion annually, equivalent to 2 per cent of GDP. Other debt reduction and restructuring agreements under the strengthened international debt strategy include debt buyback and interest reduction packages by Costa Rica, Venezuela and the Philippines; and in principle agreements with commercial bank creditors by Morocco and Uruguay. The Government will maintain its support of these efforts and to that extent accepts the recommendations, but would be concerned that such arrangements should not result in the undue transfer of private risk to the official sector or result in diverting resource flows from developing economies which have maintained their creditworthiness.
The Committee recommends that:
R7. the industrialised countries assist the process by co-operative steps including:
* disclosure by tax authorities in the countries concerned;
* disincentives to capital flight such as taxation in the country of inflow; and
* recycling of at least a share of the funds to developing countries.
Response to R7:

``Capital flight'', or the shifting of funds from countries in economic difficulties, is a characteristic of highly indebted economies where governments are pursuing inappropriate policies such as overvalued exchange rates (although not limited to such cases). The total value of assets held abroad by residents of those countries has been estimated to be comparable with their combined sovereign debts. However, some capital outflows will be associated with investment abroad providing genuine benefits to the source country, while restrictions on repatriation of capital by foreign investors will discourage desirable investment capital inflows.

As regards disincentives to capital flight being imposed by developed countries, a basic problem is the difficulty, given the huge volume of international funds transfers, of assessing whether specific individual transactions involve flight capital. Any attempt to regulate flows of flight capital would not only require cooperation by all tax jurisdictions, including tax havens, to be effective. Even then, there would be numerous possibilities for circumvention. The deregulation of many countries' financial systems, and the progressive removal of barriers to international capital movements have further added to the practical difficulties involved in devising effective measures of the kind proposed by the Committee. In any case, Australia is not generally regarded as a common destination for such capital and could not act alone.

More generally the appropriate response to capital flight is domestic economic measures to increase the attractiveness of local investment, and in that regard the adjustment policies negotiated by the international financial institutions with recipient countries are designed in part to restore the confidence of investors. The proposal is therefore not accepted.
The Committee recommends that:

R8. the Australian Government in co-operation with other supporting countries such as France should formally recommend to the World Bank that a proposal for a Debt Management Authority (DMA) be prepared for consideration by member countries.
Response to R8:

The level of benefits claimed from the establishment of a DMA depends in large measure on the discounts so far observed in the secondary markets for third world debt-which have been dominated by selling pressure-being substantially maintained after the establishment of a DMA. Those discounts have reflected the marginal character of secondary market activity to date and would be driven down by large scale repurchases. The cost of borrowing by the DMA could also be high, given the riskiness of its assets, unless guarantees were given by creditor countries-thereby transferring the risk to their taxpayers.

The financial viability of the proposal is therefore not clear-and the Government does not consider that a compelling case for a DMA has been made. The Government supports IFI involvement in the development of the existing procedures whereby debt reduction packages are tailored to the circumstances of individual countries, and which have proved an effective mechanism to provide substantial debt reduction. The proposal is therefore not accepted.
The Committee recommends that:

R9. the Government implement a policy of rapid growth in Australia's ODA as a proportion of GNP: by 1992 Australian aid should once again stand at 0.5 per cent of GNP. This Committee reiterates this earlier recommendation.
Response to R9:

The Government notes the concerns of the Committee in relation to aid volume and will take these into account in the context of future budget deliberations. However, in the continuing difficult economic environment all additional expenditure proposals must, in the interests of competent economic management, be considered against the full range of Government priorities. Nevertheless, the Government is firmly committed to the objective of at least maintaining present aid volumes in real terms. The Government also remains committed in the longer term to attaining the UN target of an ODA/GNP ratio of 0.7% and, economic circumstances permitting, will seek to expedite progress towards this goal. As the Government has previously stated, Australia's international contribution in aid-related matters is somewhat understated by comparisons of ODA/GNP ratios. For example, our contribution to refugee resettlement has been very much higher in per capita terms than in any other OECD country, but assistance to refugee resettlement is not counted as ODA. In addition, Australia's bilateral ODA is given entirely in the form of grants which provide greater benefit to recipient countries than a similar volume of loans.
The Committee recommends that:
R10. the Government vigorously press in international forums for a general increase in ODA from donor countries.
For low income debtor countries the Committee recommends:
R11. a write down of a significant portion of the Paris Club debt;
* a moratorium of ten years on all official interest payment obligations;
* the use of International Development Association terms for these rescheduled payments:
* that the budgetary costs of these debt reductions be added to aid donor commitments and not be taken from existing aid allocations;
* that aid donors who have not already done so plan now a program of cancellation of their aid-related debts;
* significant expansion of concessional resource flows;
* the development of improved means of encouraging the restoration of eligibility for those countries in arrears to the IMF; and
* that the IMF consider the sale of a portion of its gold holdings to finance additional multilateral concessional lending to low-income debt-distressed countries.
Response to R10 and R11:

The Government will continue to support in international fora increased international aid to developing countries, allocated on the basis of established aid criteria. In relation to the third world debt problem, it is particularly appropriate that surplus countries or countries whose banks have substantial exposure in problem debtors should provide increased assistance. For the poorest, most heavily indebted countries the Government has supported the need for special concessions, such as those provided by the Paris Club. The poorest countries are, of course, eligible for concessional financing from the International Development Association, including a special facility to support debt reduction by adjusting countries. The IMF arrears strategy has recently been extensively reviewed and a number of measures are being implemented that are specifically designed to normalise the relationship between the IMF and countries in arrears to it.
The Committee recommends that:
R12. the Australian Government support calls from other countries for a global conference on international financial reform.
Response to R12:

The Report's concerns in relation to this recommendation have to do with the issue of SDRs and access to IMF and World Bank credits for excluded countries. The appropriate fora for discussion of IMF and World Bank matters are, however, the IMF and World Bank. As regards access to IFI credits the Government agrees with the institutions that debtors should demonstrate that they are prepared to carry through the policy reforms which are an essential part of any adjustment package. Provision of funds without a commitment to positive adjustment policies by the recipient member country is not merely an ineffective use of funds, it enables harmful policies to be continued. The recommendation is therefore not accepted.
The Committee recommends that:

R13.- the task of Australian representation on World Bank bodies should be transferred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and his Department. The Committee also considers that Foreign Affairs and Trade representatives will be more sensitive than financial experts or bankers to social, trade and foreign affairs implications of decisions that threaten social stability and have grave environmental and ecological implications.
Response to R13:

The Government has previously indicated that provided that arrangements for Australia's representation at Bank meetings fully reflect the range of policy interests in the Banks and that there is close consultation with Treasury and Foreign Affairs portfolios, there is little to be gained by transferring the governorship of the Banks. The recommendation is therefore not accepted.
The Committee recommends that:
R14. other domestic actions which Australia should take should include:
* reviewing our banking regulations with a view to encouraging private banks to reduce debts;
* regular reporting by the Treasurer to Parliament on Australia's policy stance in the IMF, World Bank and other international debt forums;
* establishing a mechanism for consultations between Government and NGOs on Third World debt and other international financial issues; and
* providing access to policy and background papers by the IMF, World Bank and other international organisations.
Response to R14:

The exposure of Australian banks to highly indebted developing countries was never high, and has been further reduced by secondary market sales in recent years. There is also no impediment in current banking regulations to banks reducing debts should they consider it appropriate. There appears to be no need for a change in Australian banking regulations for the purpose suggested.

The Treasurer already provides considerable information to the Parliament on Australia's policy stance in the IMF, World Bank and other international debt forums. Opportunities will be taken to supplement this information as appropriate. The Government already consults with non government aid organisations as appropriate. The establishment of a formal mechanism for consultations on international finance issues is not considered necessary.

In respect of papers from international organisations in general, it would be consistent with the Government's general policy on disclosure of information for papers to be made available unless there are compelling reasons to the contrary. However, papers and reports of the IMF, World Bank and related bodies dealing with recommendations on specific decisions or otherwise relevant to decision making are not usually made publicly available to preserve the confidentiality of the decision-making processes of the institutions and also of the member countries. Where these and similar considerations do not apply, internal papers will be made available.
This recommendation is thus accepted in part.
The Committee recommends:

R15. increased concessional aid flows, support for future general capital increases of the World Bank to increase development lending, doubling of IMF quotas, and similar expansions in the capital base of the regional development banks and of the International Fund for Agricultural Development.

R.16 The Committee recommends that the Government give strong support to international financial institutions in any actions taken concerning proposals outlined in this report. In particular, the Committee recommends that the Australian Government, in order significantly to influence decisions made in international financial institutions and in foreign capitals, should apply vigorous diplomatic pressure on other participants at the start of any decision making process.
Response to R15 and R16:

Australia is a firm supporter of the role of the IMF in providing finance and of the World Bank and other development banks in providing loans and technical assistance. It has been active as a member and supported the recent increase in the capital of the World Bank, and has recently voted in favour of a substantial increase in IMF quotes. The Government has also announced that Australia will contribute $A10.5 million to the third replenishment of the International Fund for Agricultural Development. It is concerned that these international financial institutions should retain and augment their important roles in providing technical and policy assistance as well as financing. Through its representatives on the boards of the IFIs and in other ways Australia will continue to influence decision making by the institutions to help achieve the most efficient and equitable outcomes possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Third World Debt: An Australian View is very interesting for a variety of reasons, some of which my colleagues will probably take up in their remarks to a greater extent than I. It is a Government response to a report which was tabled and presented in the Parliament a year or more ago-paper No. 456 of 1989, completed in November 1989. The report, as the Government's response says, was tabled in November 1989 together with a minority report dissenting from the findings and recommendations of the report. I understand from the Government's response that a further report dealing with the Australian current account deficit and overseas debt will be tabled later. I am sure we will await the receipt of that report with considerable interest. Were I the Government, I would be tabling that report as soon as I possibly could. It is interesting to ask why the further report dealing with our current account deficit and overseas debt is being delayed in its presentation.
—Too hard.

—As my friend Senator Kemp says, it is too hard. There are various possible explanations: one would be that the Government, like Mr Macawber, thinks that things will turn up. The other, more likely, explanation is that the Government thinks that if it lets this report slide, things might just go away. Given the state of the economy that we have debated at length in recent days, given the statistics that have been coming out in recent weeks, given what we all know about the state of the Australian economy and particularly the situation with our current account deficit and the level of our overseas debt, to which I will come back in my remarks, I would have thought that the prospects of any improvement in those vital indicators of the economic health of this country is whistling in the wind. Were I the Government I would have tried to get this report out of the way as soon as possible. The Government's response is to a report which was very deeply divided on straight party lines with the Democrat members of the Joint Committee voting with the Government.
—That shouldn't come as any surprise.

—That is right. All coalition senators and members shared a dissenting view on many of the major recommendations of the report. The interesting thing in examining the Government's response is that on virtually all matters the Government has come down on the side of the dissenting report recommendations rather than those of the majority report, which was carried on the numbers because the Government has the majority in the Committee. I place it on record that it is very interesting and significant that the Government has rejected the recommendations of its own members of the Joint Standing Committee. I am not sure whether that is without precedent but it may well be. It is certainly very unusual for a government to do that. I think it has done so with very good reason. I share the view of members of the coalition who signed the dissenting report when in their first paragraph they said:

SPEECH.PARA: This report fails to recognise the underlying operation of the commercial banking system around the world in voluntarily mobilising capital funds to seek a profit. If conditions in a developing country do not offer sufficient incentive, needed capital will not be forthcoming.

I believe that the majority report, the report signed by the Government members, ignored that basic point. In terms of the development of the Third World and the meaningful attempts to resolve the desperate problems facing many Third World nations in their debt situation, the worst thing we could possibly do to them would be to make them increasingly think that they need to be supplicants of aid. That is not the way to go. The only way to get development in the Third World-and in the developed world-is to have conditions which are conducive to economic growth and development for the further liberalising of world trade. That is why the breakdown in the current General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round of negotiations is so catastrophic for us all. This is the way to go rather than looking at the aid side, as the Government members did in this report.

I wish to raise just a couple of matters in relation to the report. Although it deals with Third World debt, considering our debt situation in Australia and having looked at the figures, it is not only illuminating but also salutary and alarming to compare our situation with that of many Third World countries on whose debt we are reporting here. Our debt situation is quite clearly running rapidly out of control. Our total external debt now stands at a quite massive $156.3 billion-42 per cent of our total gross domestic product (GDP). That $156.3 billion compares with the figure of $35.9 billion when the Hawke Government came to office just 7 1/2 years ago. During that short period of 7 1/2 years, as a result of this Government's gross mismanagement, Australia's level of debt compared with that of the rest of the world has increased more than fourfold.

Even more disturbing than the actual absolute level of that debt is the fact that, as a percentage of our gross domestic product, our total annual production, our debt has doubled from 21 per cent of GDP to 42 per cent of GDP over the term of this Government. That puts Australia-I was going to say in the league with low income economies such as Nepal, Chad, India, and Rwanda--

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—It is rubbish, Senator Sherry. I will tell the honourable senator why it is rubbish. I said that I was going to say that it was in the league of those countries, but I am wrong. Does the honourable senator know why I am wrong? The reason is that our proportion of debt to GDP far outstrips-it is a far higher figure-the proportion of debt to GDP in those countries. Senator Sherry can laugh about the level of debt that this Government has driven us--
—I am not laughing at the level of debt.
—He is. He is mocking that--
—I am laughing at your stupid analogy, which is incorrect. You do not even know where Chad is.
—Order! I think honourable senators had better address their remarks through the Chair.

—I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am absolutely amazed that a member on the Government benches can laugh about the fact that Australia's debt situation is worse than the situation of Nepal, Chad, India and Rwanda. If the honourable senator wants to laugh about that, he can, but the people of Australia who are hurting minute by minute as a result of the policies of this Government are not laughing.
—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am well aware of what you can do on a point of order. I was laughing at the analogy, not at the level of Australian debt.
—There is no point of order.

—If time permitted and the rules of this House permitted, I would be very interested to know which analogy Senator Sherry is laughing at. I talked about gross debt figures. Even the net debt figures-the figures of Australia's total foreign net debt-represent over one-third of GDP; they represent over 34 per cent. That figure compares with a figure of 13.7 per cent at the time that the Hawke Government replaced the Fraser Government. In other words, our net debt situation has worsened in relation to our total gross domestic product by two and a half times since this Government came to office.

SPEECH.PARA: In United States dollar terms, and that is the conventional measure for international comparison, our total external debt in 1988-the last year for which the figures of other countries are available on a comparable basis-was around five times that of Hungary and Chile; it was more than that of countries such as Poland and Turkey; and it was one and a half times that of Argentina. We have made much fun over many years now in talking about going down the Argentinean road and the banana republic path. Our total external debt--

TALK.START.PARA: —Pity you didn't talk about it a few years earlier.

—We did not need to talk about it a few years ago because before Senator Button's Government came in the situation was that we really could look at Argentina and say, `That is a country of great concern to us'. Now we have the situation, as a result of the policies of Senator Button and his Government, that the total external debt of this country is one and a half times that of Argentina. It is more than double that of countries such as--
—Stop kidding yourself.

—Perhaps the senator has not had a chance in his busy life to look at the actual figures, but I am citing actual figures. This increase in our foreign debt has occurred despite all of the pain caused by monetary policy, which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said is going to solve our debt problem. Instead, what it has done is destroy the confidence and the capacity of the productive sectors of this economy and it has left our great export and import replacement industries reeling.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether the situation is ever going to be reached, but it certainly is high time that the Treasurer admitted the Government's mistakes on the economic policy and put the focus where it is needed to be to solve our debt problems. I do not say this in a party political way; I say it, hopefully, in a bipartisan way: the only way we are going to solve our debt problems in this country is to tackle the supply side of the economy.

What the Government has done, through this excessive reliance on monetary policy, is to clobber demand. What is that going to do when we release the brakes? All it is going to do is bring us back to the cycle that we have had over and over again in the past. Until the Government starts tackling the supply side, until we put the emphasis back on getting our export and import competing industries going again, until we start to tie wages to productivity, until we get on top of our inflation problems, there is going to be no long term improvement in the debt situation in which we find ourselves today.

I do not believe that the average Australian today has any concept of what a problem we have even to stabilise our debt situation. To stabilise Australia's foreign debt situation as a proportion of our gross domestic product by the year 1995, on reasonable assumptions in terms of what the growth will be in that period in our GDP, to get even a stabilisation of our existing enormously high ratios and problems, we will have to move into exports about 3 3/4 to 4 per cent of our total productive activity each year.

That may not sound a lot but we would have to do it every year for five years. Not in one single year in the post-war period have we been able to achieve that result. That gives us some idea of the enormity of the problem that we now have on our debt side, essentially as a result of the policies of this Government over the last 7 1/2 years-policies for which it makes no excuse, policies which it has no intention to change. If the Government does not change those policies, it will not just have to deal with explaining away the `r' word-as it tried desperately to do until it was unable to do it any longer-it will have to explain away why we became a BR, a banana republic, as a result of those misguided policies.

I want to touch on a couple of points in relation to the Government's response to the report of the Committee. The first relates to Australia's aid program. The majority of the Committee-the coalition members dissented-recommended in the report:

The Government implement a policy of rapid growth in Australia's ODA as a proportion of GNP: by 1992 Australian aid should once again stand at 0.5 per cent of GNP. This Committee reiterates this earlier recommendation.

The Government has responded to that recommendation in the following terms: it notes the concern of the Committee in relation to aid volume and says that it will take this concern into account in the context of future Budget deliberations. However, it goes on:

. . . in the continuing difficult economic environment all additional expenditure proposals must, in the interests of competent economic management, be considered against the full range of Government priorities

I support that view, as would the coalition. That view was reflected fairly strongly in the dissenting report by coalition members, but at the same time the coalition continues to support the United Nations role of 0.7 per cent of our gross national product being given in aid. But, like the Government's response, we would say that that has to be looked at in the context of the overall situation facing the Australian economy. The tragedy-not just for Australia, but in terms of what Australia would want to do and should be able to do to assist the development of the Third World-is that the mismanagement of the last 7 1/2 years has left us in a much weaker position to provide the other rational forms of assistance, in the broad sense of the term, that we would wish to see in our relations with the Third World.
The only other recommendation I wish to touch on briefly, but it is an interesting recommendation, is this:

the task of Australian representation on World Bank bodies should be transferred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and his Department. The Committee also considers that Foreign Affairs and Trade representatives will be more sensitive than financial experts or bankers to social, trade and foreign affairs implications of decisions that threaten social stability and have grave environmental and ecological implications.

We could all have differing views on that. However, it is an important recommendation to be considered. I am not in a position to speak for the coalition on that, but personally I would support the point made by those coalition members who signed the dissenting report. I quote from that report:

. . . it is essential that international financial bodies such as the IMF and the World Bank continue to impose sensible and appropriate economic policy conditions on countries which use the services of those bodies. These economic policy conditions should include
* maintenance of realistic exchange rates;
* cuts in subsidies;
* realistic food prices to producers to encourage domestic production of food; and
* expectation of appropriate return on capital for commercial project investment.

They are important policy conditions that have been mentioned in the dissenting report. The broad response, as I read it, of the Government to the majority recommendation takes a lot of cognisance of that. I think that, in terms of who represents Australia on some of these bodies, some of us may have differing views. It is a matter to which obviously further consideration needs to be given.

With those remarks I reiterate the coalition's noting of the Government's response. Overall, the Government has responded in a way that is much more in tune with the recommendations or views of the dissenting members of the Joint Committee report. I welcome that because the dissenting members were the coalition members. I think the report has served a useful purpose. The Government's response was useful. It is a subject with which the Senate does not deal or consider as much as it should. I hope that from time to time we may be able to find the opportunity, in a very crowded program, to give more consideration to some of these very important issues than we often seem to be able to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the Government's response to the recommendations in the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Third World Debt: An Australian View. It is now three years since the report was commissioned and just over a year since it was tabled, along with a minority report dissenting from the findings and recommendations of the report to which Senator Short has just referred. It is rather disappointing for me to have to note that he is pleased that the Government's responses are generally in line with the dissenting report. This was the subject of some controversy within the Committee and the more generous recommendations which were put forward have not been acceded to. I can understand why Senator Short is pleased, but it certainly does not make me pleased. The aid agencies will not be pleased-the people actually dealing with the recipients of aid who, as a consequence, are the ones who are suffering and dying because of the enormous burden of Third World debt.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's response indicates that it is prepared to do virtually nothing about Third World debt, and what little support there is for the 16 recommendations will probably gather dust on the shelves, like most reports of this nature. This is highly disappointing and I find it very irresponsible as a Government response. Responding to the 16 recommendations, the Government gives an outright `no' to five of the stronger ones, accepts three recommendations, mumbles about four, and accepts three in part. That is hardly a ringing endorsement and it must be very disappointing indeed to members of the Committee who put in the majority report.

As for the reiteration of the recommendation on restoring aid to 0.5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), there are the same tired old platitudes about waiting for the state of the economy to improve, so I will count that as a `no' as well. In fact, I think it is worse than a `no'; I think that it is very dishonest because it says:
the Government remains committed in the longer term to attaining the United Nations target of 0.7 per cent, economic circumstances permitting . . .

Of course, we have heard the same thing reiterated now by Senator Short on behalf of the Opposition-the Opposition which, I remind senators, was prepared to cut $100m off the aid budget, or at least that was its plan or promise before the last election. I think it is a really cynical statement that the Government has the intention to get up to the United Nations recommended level. We have seen nothing of that in the past seven years; in fact, we have seen a steadily decreasing amount of the foreign affairs budget going into aid.

Overall, the Government is not prepared to do anything really effective to tackle the issue of Third World debt, the silent killer, which is taking away the lives of far more men, women and children than those being lost in any of the 27 or so wars raging around the world at this moment. It is true that Australian banks are not major lenders to heavily indebted Third World countries, but a number of the major international banks do have branches here. I must say that I was not very impressed with their response to the `Fax the Banks Day' organised last month to draw attention to their role in the international debt problem.

However, this report makes equally depressing reading as the Government simply rejects the relatively innocuous recommendations made, at least where they even remotely risk treading on Treasury's toes. There is a `no' to the proposal to set up a debt management authority. There is another `no' to the idea of a global conference on international financial reform. It is pretty extraordinary that the Government is saying `no' to a conference to talk about international financial reform. Surely this is an urgently needed conference, not only for Third World debtor nations but, as Senator Short has so clearly pointed out, in the case of our own nation as well.

The next strangled `no' is to the idea that Australian representation on World Bank bodies should be transferred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and to his Department, instead of to the somewhat less sympathetic Treasury. Obviously people in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade might have a better understanding of the intricacies of the aid budget and what we might be able to do to improve the situation to assist the debtor nations which are suffering so greatly at the moment. It is hardly surprising that there is little enthusiasm for supporting an increase in overseas aid, either by Australia or other countries. We may be in dire economic straits, or indeed in a recession-now that we can officially call it a recession-but the fact remains that we are far better off than most other countries in the world, particularly the least developed countries.

Aid is not just dishing out money to ungrateful Third World countries. Overall, it is an economic fact that the developed countries are actually recipients of aid from the Third World rather than the other way round, if we include the huge interest repayments and the aid money coming back to get spent on goods and services provided by the donors. Much of the overseas aid provided by Australia comes back to this country and, if the economies of our neighbours were to improve, this in turn would generate trade and improve our economy. So, at the very least, we should be increasing aid with a view to enlightened self-interest in mind.

Aid, of course, is not the heart of the problem. The complex issues of international debt, unfair trade practices or commodity pricing arrangements need detailed and critical analysis, some of which were addressed in the Committee's report. Both the so-called free market and the demands of the World Bank and IMF work against the people of the Third World, if not their elites. The status quo results in a widening of the gap between the rich and the poor, and that needs to change if we as a global community are going to begin to achieve ecological sustainability, because many of the world's environment problems are driven by poverty, particularly poverty in least developed countries.

I would like to conclude by reminding this Government once again of its lamentable record on aid as we sink below the line set to separate the mean countries from the more generous ones and, in particular, the Scandinavians and the Dutch. I have never understood why Australia cannot stand by these countries instead of drifting down to join the meanies, but I know that it will require a lot more development education by the non-governmental organisations such as Community Aid Abroad and the One World Centre, which do so much good work in Western Australia and in other States around this country.
