I regret sounding so negative, but I have to be realistic. I suppose the Government's response today was to be expected, but it is extremely disheartening. My hope now lies in growing support in Australia for the work of the non-governmental agencies that I have just referred to, covering both fundraising and development education. As usual, the people must lead so that governments will follow. International debt is no exception to this rule. We cannot allow the issue of Third World debt to go unaddressed, even if we want to because, in so doing, considering the interconnection of all issues facing all people everywhere, we sow the seeds of our own destruction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the Gulf crisis has been resolved, the major issue which will be facing the world will be the resolution of Third World debt. I regret that neither the original report nor the Government's response is going to contribute significantly towards the resolution of that problem Third World debt is indeed a complex and disturbing problem. The original report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Third World Debt: An Australian View states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is a small industrialised country possessing something in common with developed countries, eg, OECD membership and IMF developed country status.
It also has a number of similarities with developing countries, especially:
reliance on commodity exports and serious continuing current account deficits and mounting foreign debt.

In fact, the point that really did hit me through this report is that, though this inquiry was into appropriate Australian policy responses concerning Third World debt, unfortunately, Australia is fast joining the Third World countries. The so-called many characteristics so vividly described as belonging to Third World countries with ever-increasing debt seem to be describing Australia. Earlier this year, Australia was ranked fourth in the world of the top 10 debtor nations after Brazil, Mexico and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Australia's economy, with its reliance on primary products, bears more in relation to the average indebted developing country-for example, 72 per cent of exports are primary products-than the average industrial economy, where 24 per cent of exports are primary products. Australia shares with the Third World a limited manufacturing base, a reliance on the export of commodities to finance growth, and a consequent high degree of vulnerability to international market forces. Anyone who attended the Last Great Aussie Breakfast this morning can testify to this.

Australia's foreign debt has constantly risen since 1980, when it was 11 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), to 28 per cent of GDP in December 1986 and to 38 per cent of GDP in 1990. Australians should be taking more than an altruistic glance at the debt crisis. However, on reading the original report I see a number of aspects from which my fellow colleagues decided to dissent and with good reason. I would like to reiterate one or two of these to the chamber tonight.

The original report, I believe, failed to recognise that the underlying operation of the commercial banking system is, after all, to make a profit. The conditions in developing countries do not offer sufficient incentive, and needed capital will not be forthcoming. The trends, as stated in the report, are that an increasing proportion of capital flows to developing countries will come from official rather than from commercial sources.

In order to encourage capital input into the less developed countries, it will be necessary to correct the underlying economic malaise in which these countries now find themselves. Therefore, in this context, it is essential that the international financial bodies such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank continue to impose sensible and appropriate economic policy conditions on countries which use the services of these particular bodies. This is an area in which Australia, as a member of these organisations, could be of direct benefit. We should be directly influencing the policies to be of the greatest benefit to the less developed countries, which cannot cope with their present levels of debt and should not be encouraged to take out further loans that they cannot repay.

At present, we have many Third World countries owing more in debt repayments and interest than they earn a year from exports. That makes it impossible for them to repay their debts. Such countries have no option but to borrow more money to survive. Yet to give this money could only exacerbate the problem. I was surprised to read in the last briefing note by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid that there is a gross anomaly in the present aid structure given by this Government. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), while in Washington and Manila, supported increases in Australian aid to the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank but, in Canberra, the aid program is cut. This year aid through the banks increased 250 per cent, while back home $100m is cut from direct aid.

The impact of this policy is that aid is being redirected from victims of emergencies and programs for the poorest, through non-government agencies, so that more can go to the banks. Secondly, Australian aid is being redirected away from the no strings attached grants to World Bank loans that make even worse the debt problems of developing countries. Our policies should not be encouraging the debt problem, but rather should be directed to relieving the debt problem.

I know that there are many ways of doing this and I do not intend to go into them this evening. The point that I do wish to make is that there is a major world debt problem, and that our policies should be directed to reducing this, not encouraging it. Sections of the original report implied that the commercial banks have an obligation to support developing countries. This is unrealistic, as in the commercial area the obligation is in large measure to the shareholders. Therefore, I would like to reiterate what my colleagues said in their dissenting report:

Any need that developing countries have for foreign capital, but which has no commercial incentive, should be provided on concessional terms. In other words, the provision of these funds must be subsidised . . . Although world-wide aid funds have been slowly increasing in recent years, it should not be expected that aid funds will grow in the future as rapidly as commercial funds decreased in the mid 1980s. It is becoming increasingly clear that the role of the creditor countries in providing capital flows to the LDCs is being increasingly borne by the taxpayers in the creditor countries and that shareholder risk is rapidly being shed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to speak on Third World Debt: An Australian View. I guess the Third World would give a bit of a horse laugh to have Australia, which as Mr Keating said is on the Argentine road, trying to advise it on what its problems are. I listened carefully to Senator Vallentine's response and it seems to me that Senator Vallentine and people who share her views often fail to note the central lessons of the past two decades. Although Senator Vallentine is not here, she and the others should have asked themselves the following questions: which Third World countries have done really well? Which countries have succeeded and which have failed? I think one can say without fear of contradiction that the countries that have succeeded are basically those which have relied for their economic growth on market economies. They have given great emphasis to free enterprise. Throughout the world countries which were written off a decade or so ago are now the great growth countries which are generating higher living standards for their people --
—Like Argentina?
— That is an interesting comment. The Argentine has an appalling history of massive government spending and intervention in the economy.
—Another socialist experiment.

— Yes, that is right. It was a classic socialist experiment. One can look at the eastern European countries that bombed out there. They followed the socialist road. It seems to me that, if the Senator Vallentines of this world are genuinely concerned about the living standards of people in the Third World, they should look at history, learn its lessons and at least in their long report, which they give ceaselessly, give some emphasis to the need to develop properly functioning market economies. Senator Vallentine did not say that and we will listen with great interest when Senator Spindler gets up to see whether he can at least acknowledge the importance of free markets and free enterprise in the creation of wealth.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vallentine and Senator Spindler want to tax Australian workers more-people who are already labouring under the failed accord which the Government has brought on-to provide more and more aid to countries which often fail to undertake vital structural reforms themselves. I am not opposed to foreign aid, but I am opposed to throwing money at countries which ceaselessly fail to make the necessary reforms so that aid can be properly used.

The Government's response which we now have before us has by and large totally rejected the report brought down by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. In the end, as Senator Short said, a dissenting report was drafted and signed by all the coalition members of the Committee. I agree with Senator Short that the Government has had little time for the majority report which, in effect, was prepared by its own backbench. The Cabinet is dumping in a fairly fulsome manner on its own back bench. Some seven of the 16 recommendations have been rejected outright by the Government and a number of the other recommendations are so weakly supported as to amount to being rejected. On that part at least I agree with Senator Vallentine.

One gets the feeling on reading the Government's response that it was restrained in order to avoid highlighting the clear differences between the Cabinet and its own back bench even in those recommendations to which it at least tried to give some credence. For example, in recommendation 9 the Committee recommended that the Government implement a policy of rapid growth of Australia's official development assistance as a proportion of gross domestic product and that by 1992 Australia's aid should once again stand at 0.5 per cent of GDP, according to the report we have before us. The Government has in effect rejected the Committee's recommendation. The Government, while in sympathy with some of the thrust of the recommendations to alleviate Third World debt, has in effect comprehensively rejected the detail of recommendations 10 and 11, including such proposals as a moratorium of 10 years on all official payment obligations and a write-down of a significant proportion of the Paris Club debt.

I have the impression from reading the Government's response-and in this area I agree with Senator Short-that the philosophical approach of the Cabinet is more in line with the dissenting report than with the majority report prepared by the Government's own back bench. When one looks at some of the members of that Committee, one wonders whether we are not seeing another element of factional fighting occurring within the Government. There were very strong representations from the Left on this Committee-Senator Childs, Mr Baldwin, Mr Langmore, Dr Theophanous and so forth. I suppose if Senator Sherry had been in the Parliament then, he would have been on this Committee as well.

This report has been brought down and the Government has dumped on the Committee; we now wait to see whether any Labor members are prepared to stand up and defend themselves-or will they, as they normally do, just lie down? We are waiting on Senator Sherry-he can grin and bear it-or one of the Committee members on the Government side to stand up and defend this Government report. We do not appear to have a Minister in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is probably embarrassed.

—Yes, he probably is embarrassed, and so he should be, in my view. Clearly we are again seeing major dissension in the Australian Labor Party. In short, rather than being a useful analysis of and an appropriate response by Australia to Third World debt, this report will go down in the Parliament as another symbol of the great philosophical divisions in the Labor Party today. These are the divisions between those who put their faith in outmoded socialist solutions and those who are learning the lesson that the fundamental way to assist the Third World is to adopt the philosophy of free markets, free enterprise and genuine political democracy. That is another element missing from Senator Vallentine's speech. Democracy and free enterprise are the great drivers of growth in the world economy; they are the great drivers of prosperity and living standards for the working people. It is a great pity that this report did not pick up those themes because they are the themes which history teaches us will deliver to people not only political liberties but also prosperity.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has treated the work of the Committee-the work of its own back bench-with a thinly disguised contempt. It is interesting, as Senator Short has said, that we should be standing in this chamber looking at how we can help Third World countries when we ourselves may soon be joining their ranks. After all, it was none other than Mr Keating, on 14 May 1986-does Senator Button remember that date?-over 4 1/2 years ago, who warned that Australia was on the road to becoming a banana republic. That is what he warned us 4 1/2 years ago. Our foreign debt is huge and growing day by day by any standard. In June 1986-just one month after the famous banana republic statement-Australia's gross foreign debt was $92 billion. Today our debt is heading towards $160 billion.

During the election campaign Mr Keating said-I know that casts doubt on the statement because we have already seen a number of promises broken by this Government-that by 1992 Australia's debt will be stabilised. If he is correct and he is able to stabilise Australia's debt, it will then be about $200 billion. It is a remarkable record. It is no wonder that Senator Short said that with these figures we are well and truly on the Argentine road. By most measurements, Australia's international position has significantly worsened, despite a substantial improvement in our terms of trade since 1986. Mr Keating's comments on the banana republic day in 1986 on the John Laws program were somewhat prophetic. I would like to read some of the comments Mr Keating made that day. He pointed out that once economic growth is slowed to under 3 per cent unemployment starts to rise again. John Laws, having heard this statement from Mr Keating, replied:
And then you have really induced a depression.
Mr Keating responded to John Laws by saying:
You have gone, you are a banana republic.

Mr Keating, in his own words, has engineered a recession and those words will come back to haunt the Labor Party as the job queues grow and as Australian workers are retrenched. Whoever thought of that tactic was the same person who thought of advising the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to pretend that he had kept his promise on child poverty. I really think the Government should think about where it gets its advisers, because I predict that the statement that Senator Button has made time and time again in this Parliament in recent days-that the Government has engineered a recession-will come back to haunt him.

Mr Keating said on banana republic day that if our growth went below 3 per cent the country would be going backwards. Today the economy is not growing at all; so it is not even under 3 per cent. The economy is actually receding. Des Moore, a former Deputy Secretary of the Commonwealth Treasury, who is now senior fellow at the Institute of Public Affairs, has pointed out that close to 30 per cent of total external receipts are now going to service external debt. This is the highest proportion since the Depression years of the 1930s and is double the level that existed as recently as 1983. No wonder Senator Sherry looks horrified. Des Moore says that after each of the two previous occasions when the proportion rose above 30 per cent, a depression followed. What was clearly regarded as a crisis in 1986 must be regarded as even more of a crisis today.

A number of other important statements have been made concerning Australia's debt problem. These have come from people who are concerned mainly with making sure that we set our own house in order: physician heal thyself before you start to worry about the problems of others. A number of eminent organisations have tried to concentrate on our debt problem to see what can be done about it. The Business Council of Australia held a debt conference earlier this year and put forward a comprehensive range of recommendations which could help Australia address its difficulties. The Institute of Public Affairs has been very active in highlighting Australia's debt problem and has been very constructive in proposing a range of solutions. It has to be said that the Government has not made any effective response to these proposals.

I conclude by addressing an interjection by Senator Zakharov the other day in relation to Australia's foreign debt problem. Senator Zakharov called out across the chamber-I do not know whether it was recorded in Hansard-that Australia's foreign debt problem was caused mainly by the private sector. I asked her whether she was talking about Alan Bond and Laurie Connell-some good friends of the Labor Party-and if she was I think it was quite a courageous thing to do. But in actual fact Senator Zakharov was quite wrong. In order to prove that she is wrong, I will rely on a statement made by the Prime Minister prior to the 1987 election. It is a very important statement and perhaps it will set the Senator Zakharovs of this world back on the right road. I will quote from it at some length. It is important that it be recorded in Hansard because, as the debate on the Government's performance continues in the weeks and months ahead, I am sure that many senators on both sides will find it very useful. This is what Mr Hawke said about the responsibility for our foreign debt:

The generator of Australia's external debt is our current account deficit. When a country has a current account deficit it spends more than it earns and, therefore, the country as a whole must borrow from the rest of the world to cover the difference. The identity of those borrowing-Australian business, governments or whoever-is irrelevant.
That is what our Prime Minister said. He went on to say:

The key, therefore, to reducing our external debt lies with the Government formulating the appropriate fiscal monetary and wages policies to allow a reduction in the deficit on the current account of the balance of payments.
Mr Hawke stated very succinctly where the responsibility lay. I could not have expressed it better myself. He continued:
There has recently emerged an encouraging downward trend in the monthly current account deficits.
This is what he said in 1987 before the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is like unemployment trending down.
—Just wait, Senator Baume. Mr Hawke went on to say in 1987:

SPEECH.PARA: These will diminish our external debt to GDP ratio before 1990.

Is it any wonder that Third World countries looking at our great record-our really disgraceful record-would treat this report with a contempt similar to the contempt with which it has been treated by the Hawke Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is considering the Government's response to the recommendations contained in the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Third World Debt: An Australian View, which was tabled in November 1989. One of the members of the Committee who was an author of that report was former Australian Democrats Deputy Leader, Michael Macklin. I know that former Senator Michael Macklin was proud to be associated with the recommendations that were made in that report. He would be disappointed, as I am, with the Government's response. I can assure Senator Baume and Senator Kemp that the Australian Democrats would not have voted for the sort of report that the Government would have submitted, judging by the response that the Government has given to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have welcomed Senator Kemp's addressing the substance of the report rather than spewing forth party political rhetoric for almost half an hour. However, let us look at some of the recommendations that the report has put forward and the Government's responses to them. One of the first recommendations, and perhaps the most important, is that the Government, through its representatives in the International Monetary Fund, should urge the IMF to prepare social impact statements in respect of companies requiring loans. This is a requirement that we would have thought was self-evident. It is, to some extent, supported by the Committee's recommendation of the United Nations Children's Fund strategy of `adjustment with a human face'. Unfortunately, these principles, although ostensibly accepted by the Government, are weakened almost in the same breath when the Government says:

Nevertheless the distribution among social groups of any austerity measures accompanying a structural adjustment-loan agreement is determined essentially by the political and social priorities of the recipient countries.

In other words, once again we have the market theory which makes the poor and disadvantaged carry the burden and makes the rich richer. The pain always seems to fall on the most vulnerable groups in these nations and it is time that Australia, through its representatives on international bodies, pressed for an assessment of that and pressed for a loans policy which takes into account the benefits accruing to the people in those countries.

It is worth remembering that, in contrast to the convention of the old international bodies, the United Nations Constitution actually addresses the well-being and the independence of peoples rather than nations. It is time we started to think in a similar way.

The other point that we believe Australia should address when it considers, in these bodies, the criteria for determining loan funds is the ecological consequences. My colleague Senator Coulter has recently introduced into the Senate a Bill to ban the import of rainforest timber logged in Third World countries. Such a ban would help to cut the demand for the timber. The IMF and other such organisations should adopt measures to limit the supply and therefore the cutting of such timber.

In our alternative Budget we have proposed to institute a rainforest protection fund to which only Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development member countries would have to contribute. On a relative gross domestic product basis Australia's contribution would amount to only approximately $60m to save the South American and South East Asian rainforests. When Senator Kemp asks me where the money is coming from and whether we are going to levy taxes, then I can tell him that yes, we are going to get it from his friends, the tax avoiders, and I would suggest that Senator--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Spindler has suggested that Senator Kemp consorts with tax avoiders and that he is their friend. I think that is a slur on Senator Kemp that is uncalled for, and I ask you to direct the honourable senator to withdraw it.
—I did not hear the remark, so there is no point of order.

—I will be very pleased to supply a copy of our alternative Budget to Senator Kemp, where he can read that there are some 26 measures, at least, which would yield well in excess of $2 billion provided those tax avoidance loopholes were closed. Unfortunately, Senator Kemp prefers to introduce a general consumption tax which would reduce the tax on Rolls-Royces and place a tax on bread and milk. This is not the Democrats' way of raising revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: I now proceed to another area that we believe should be considered in the policies in international forums and international banks when funding of Third World countries is considered. That is the form of democratic government that exists in those countries and the decision making that should be encouraged. The Government has rejected recommendation 3 of the report, which concentrates on the question of democratic policy making by the international financial institutions, but has given at least some support to greater political involvement by parliamentarians as well as the international coordination of parliamentary action. Once again, the Democrats say that what should be advanced is the democratic decision making by the people in those countries. It is rather unfortunate that this aspect is not emphasised in the Government's response.

In conclusion, we believe that Australia should lead the way in developing a new world order in which social justice, the environment and the future should be given much greater preference than the rule of the markets, which essentially are value free and which prefer to ignore human and social values.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Spindler said that I was a friend of tax avoiders. I think that is a disgraceful comment. I am surprised it came from Senator Spindler. I have nothing but contempt for tax avoiders. I think it is an outrageous comment for Senator Spindler to make, and I ask to have it withdrawn.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, you have already ruled on this point of order. It is the same point of order that was taken by Senator O'Chee and you have already ruled on it.
—I have ruled on it, Senator Kemp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read with some degree of interest the Government's response to the recommendations of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in respect of Third World debt. There are a number of recommendations in this report which I believe are totally unrealistic and which, unfortunately, should not be in the report at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I would, firstly, however, like to take the opportunity to address some of the comments that have been made by Senator Spindler, because Senator Kemp gave a very eloquent exposition on exactly what many of the problems of these Latin American countries are; that is, there has been a wholly excessive amount of government interference. What we really need in countries such as Argentina is a return to free market systems. At this point Senator Spindler interjected that Argentina was a free market country and that that was the problem. I think that Senator Spindler's interjection was something along those lines. I hasten to take issue with Senator Spindler on this point because unfortunately he is totally incorrect.

When one looks at the aggregated borrowings of Argentina to international banks, one finds that either directly or indirectly an overwhelming amount of the borrowings are in fact public sector debt. For example, three of the largest debtors in Argentina are organisations such as Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales, Entidad Binacional Yacyreta, and Direccion Nacional del Antartico-organisations that are public sector and not private sector organisations.

In addition to this, one finds when one looks at the master loan agreements that exist for Argentina that many of the borrowers that are not public sector borrowers either enjoy a public sector guarantee or come under the ambit of public sector loan agreements. For example, the guaranteed refinancing agreement was guaranteed by the Republic of Argentina. It sought to guarantee the borrowings of a number of public and private sector borrowers, but ultimately the effect of the guarantee was to increase the Republic's own public sector borrowing requirement and force it further into debt. So any comment by Senator Spindler or anybody else that Argentina is a free market economy is just not the case.

The level of intervention by the central bank in Argentina, the Banco Central de la Republica Argentina, is quite extraordinary. For example, in December 1989 inflation in Argentina had reached 200 per cent in the first 18 days of the month and the central bank's response to this problem of spiralling inflation, which is a direct consequence of enormous foreign debt, was to ring up the banks and say that from 19 December onwards the central bank would not bother to tally inflation in Argentina.

Another tactic the Argentine central bank used, to limited success, in the previous year in Argentina was to take a daily tally of inflation, and when the level of inflation reached an unsatisfactory point on any given day the central bank would ring up all the other banks and say that the next day would be a banking holiday and they would not be allowed to transact any foreign exchange transactions. These were the sorts of interventionist policies of the central bank and of the Argentine Government that mark out the Argentine economy very clearly, as Senator Kemp has so well said, as not a free market economy but an interventionist economy which is dogged by a sort of pseudo-socialist Peronism, a corporatism which has hamstrung the economy of Argentina.

I wish to turn my attention at this point to recommendations 4, 6 and 7 of the Committee's report. The Committee in recommendations 4 and 6 says that the private sector commercial banks that have lent money to Latin American and other Third World debtors should be obliged to participate in debt reduction schemes. The debt reduction schemes that are anticipated by these recommendations are schemes that arose out of the Brady plan. Having had some participation at the sharp end of implementing the Brady plan in Mexico in 1989, I suppose it would be remiss of me to let these comments go without some sort of notation to them.

The Brady plan as it was implemented in Mexico basically involved a 35 per cent write down by the commercial banks of their lendings to companies and the Government in Mexico. The banks could do this one of three ways. The first option was that the bank would be allowed to hold its paper, that is, the unsecured loans it has outstanding to Mexican entities provided it stumped up an extra 35 per cent in a new money loan. The second option was what was called an interest rate reduction bond or a par swap bond, that is, the unsecured paper owned by commercial banks would be swapped on a par basis for bonds which bore a reduced interest rate. The third and also very significant option available to the commercial banks was what was called a debt reduction bond. This involved the banks swapping their unsecured paper for secured bonds with a floating rate, as opposed to the fixed rate, of the par swap bond, the bonds having a nominal value of 65 per cent of the unsecured paper for which they had been swapped.

The ultimate consequence of the Brady plan on these commercial banks was to force them to make enormous write downs. It is no surprise that the Brady plan led to massive losses by banks, such as Chase Manhattan, Citibank, and the Bank of America, which had made only limited provisions for the loans to these Third World countries. I am sure Senator Spindler would say, `Well, so what?' and the social justice advocates of this world would say, `So what?'. The consequence of these write downs is quite horrific because, ultimately, it undermines the stability of the whole banking system not just in the United States, the United Kingdom or Europe, but all around the world because capital markets are very complex markets. They are not populated by simplistic beasts such as some people in this chamber and in the House of Representatives would have us believe. They are populated by an interconnected series of financial institutions, each lending and borrowing from the other. The collapse of any one of these financial institutions would cause an ultimate collapse, like dominoes, of other financial institutions around the world. The consequences of that would affect many ordinary innocent savers in countries such as the United States, the United Kingdom, Australia and elsewhere around the world.

It is unsatisfactory and irresponsible for anybody to argue that commercial banks, because of the fact that they are banks, should be asked to write down their debt to support Latin American countries. Certainly I accept the fact that many of these commercial banks in the 1970s and early 1980s had horrendous lending practices. Banking executives would fly down to Latin America every four months or six months, write the tickets for whatever loans they wanted, get marvellous lending spreads of 1 3/4 per cent and 1 1/2 per cent, take their commissions and go home. I suppose these lending executives never really thought about the reason for getting such an enormous spread. Why should they get a 1 3/4 per cent lending margin when elsewhere they were only getting three-quarters of a per cent or half a per cent? It is, of course, a factor of the risk.

To that extent, the commercial banks have been condemned. But the commercial banks have paid their price to date in enormous write downs of their balance sheets; they have paid their price in interest which has remained unpaid for years and years; and they have paid their price as they have seen the value of their loans shrink from 100c in the dollar to 10c in the dollar or 8c in the dollar, as is the case with loans under the guaranteed refinancing agreement in Argentina. That is the price they have paid. To expect them to make further write downs is, I believe, irresponsible and irrational.

There is a way to reduce the amount of outstanding Latin American debt and it is not by debt reduction schemes such as are contained in recommendations 4 and 6; it is by implementing debt to equity swap schemes. Debt to equity swap schemes have enormous benefits both for lenders and for the countries to which the money has been lent.

Basically, a debt to equity swap scheme works in this fashion: a bank has outstanding loans to either a private sector or public sector entity in a Latin American country and it agrees to take its money early at, say, 70 per cent of the face value of the loan and have it paid in local currency and converted into equity in an approved corporate entity within that country. Attached to the conversion of this debt to equity are specific provisions that relate to the repatriation of capital and to the payment of dividends.

These schemes have been enormously successful and they are, without doubt, going to be the principal manner in which the problem of Third World debt will be solved in the next 10 years, perhaps even faster. We will not make substantial inroads into Third World Latin American debt by the pie in the sky claims of the social justice advocates who say that the banks should merely take a write down. There has to be something in it for the banks and, more importantly, there has to be something in it for the Third World country.

The idea that banks should just write down their loans and walk away is, in the long term, detrimental for the borrower as well as for the lender because the lender has been burnt well and truly and the lender will not again provide credit willingly to those companies or countries.

I believe that there will be more borrowings by Latin American countries in the future. There will need to be more borrowings by Latin American countries in the future as they struggle to raise the living standards of their citizens. Those loans will not be available to those countries, to those companies or to those individuals if the banks have been so badly burnt that they will never come back again.

That is why I believe these recommendations are totally unrealistic, just as it is unrealistic to expect a bank to take a reduction in its interest rates to concessional levels, as is contained in recommendation 6. The consequence of that, ultimately, is that the yield on the loan shrinks below an acceptable level for the risk. The way in which financial institutions compensate for this and bring the yield into line with the risk is to discount the loan. So if we force the bank to give a concessional rate of interest, the bank then has to write down the value of its loan because the market shrinks underneath it. Ultimately it would have the same effect if we asked the bank to take a reduction in the principal amount of the debt.

One of the reasons why there is liquidity in the Third World debt market, the LDC market, at the moment is very simple. The loans are already trading at a discount to the premium and that discount leads to a yield on effective interest rates that makes the risk acceptable. To take a further reduction in interest would, as I said, lead to a reduction in the secondary market value of these loans and ultimately affect the balance sheets of the banks and the security of the deposits that ordinary people, like those of us in the Senate chamber, have made.

The final recommendation which I wish to address is recommendation 7, which says, inter alia, that there should be disincentives to capital flight such as taxation in the country of inflow. Basically this recommendation is all about parallel markets and foreign currency which exist in many countries. For example, in Argentina inflation is so rampant that nobody in his right mind saves his money in australes. Everybody saves in greenbacks. If we were to put this recommendation into effect, what we would do would be not to safeguard the wealth and prosperity of Argentineans, Venezuelans, Costa Ricans or anybody else; all we would do would be to force those people further into poverty because we would give them no secure base for their savings. I accept the fact that the foreign exchange markets-the parallel markets-that exist in these countries are a problem, but they are less of a problem than they are a boon. They give ordinary people a safe haven for their savings.

Last year, when stagflation and hyperinflation struck Argentina, the Argentine Government created a whole new class of poor people. They were not the manual labourers, they were not the farmers or the peasants; the new class of poor people that was created in Argentina was the white collar workers. They were the professional people-the doctors, the architects-all of the professional people who had no access to hard currency and who had no savings in hard currency. What I believe we must do, if we are to beat our chests and talk about our social conscience, is give the poor, oppressed, underprivileged people of these countries a chance to maintain the value of what meagre savings they have. I am sure that Senator Sherry on the other side of the chamber would take no issue with that. For those reasons, the suggestion that we should prevent people from securing the value of their savings by investing in safe countries and safe currencies is a wholly unrealistic one and one which, morally, I wish to have no association with.

These are some of the flaws in the report, and I believe that these matters should have been raised to explain the importance and the difficulty of this matter. It is not an easy matter. It is not a matter to which there is going to be an overnight solution. I believe that there will be a solution which will come as a result of market forces both within these countries and without. It will be market forces that will drive the debt to equity schemes. It will be market forces that drive the debt swap schemes such as existed and are planned in Venezuela and with which I have had some association, and I think they are on the whole good schemes. It is the market solutions which are important; it is not the solutions of the do-gooders because, however good their intentions, they fail to understand the crux of the problem, and in trying to solve the world's ills I believe that these people, in this regard, only make them worse.

I know that there are a number of other senators, including Senator Crane, who wish to debate the response of the Government to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. It would have been interesting to hear a greater contribution from the Government benches. I wish at another stage to make a contribution to this debate, so I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the supplementary Government response to the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the Reform of the Australian Audit Office and a related document entitled Australian National Audit Office-Report of an Independent Review. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The Government's initial response to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts (JCPA) report on the reform of the Australian Audit Office was tabled on 1 November 1989. The response noted that the Government had commissioned an independent review of resource issues in relation to the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) and that there were a number of issues raised by the JCPA report to which the Government was giving further consideration.

This response comments on the independent review which was conducted by Mr T. A. Sheridan, the then Auditor-General of South Australia, as well as the issues outstanding from the Government's initial response.
Sheridan Review

The JCPA inquiry into the Australian Audit Office was one of the most significant undertaken by the Committee. However, the analysis of the resource issues presented in that report left, in the Government's view, something to be desired. Consequently, whilst the Government decided at that time to provide additional funding of $2 million per annum on an ongoing basis for efficiency audits, it also commissioned a review to advise the Auditor-General and the Government on the ANAO's capacity to improve further the use of existing resources.

The majority of the findings of the independent review are properly matters for decision by the Auditor-General. The main recommendations relate to a range of matters including organisation and staffing issues. The review noted that the Auditor-General had made significant productivity improvements, of the order of 15 per cent, over the past three years.

Overall, the review concluded that initiatives already undertaken by the Auditor-General, or suggested in the review, could lead to significant additional resources, equivalent to some 60 full-time staff, becoming available for efficiency auditing over the next two years or so. These resources, in the order of $3 million per annum, could be released through the adoption of risk based auditing; gains from information technology; release of resources following completion of the ANAO's information technology project; and improved management and control of resources. Together with the $2 million per annum increase in funding for efficiency audits announced in the Government's earlier response to the JCPA report, this represents a very substantial increase in resources above the level allocated to such tasks at the time of the JCPA report, which was then estimated at $1 million.

The review proposes that, from 1991-92, the ANAO charge for financial statement audits, and retain the resultant revenue. This will encourage auditees to maintain reliable financial reporting and control systems and prepare soundly based financial statements, in order to minimise charges. Government Business Enterprises (GBEs) and a number of other entities are already charged by the ANAO for financial statement audits. The Government agrees with the review conclusion that charging should be extended for the audit of all financial statements of government undertakings, including departments of state. Such a move would be consistent with Government's policy of fostering increased efficiency in the public sector. Efficiency audits and project audits, together with assistance provided to Parliamentary committees, would continue to be funded from the ANAO's annual appropriations.
Statutory Authority Status for ANAO

The JCPA report recommended the establishment of the ANAO as a statutory authority, largely to permit the Auditor-General to determine the terms and conditions of employment of ANAO staff. All statutory authorities and GBEs are constrained by the centralised wage system and the Government's wages policies, so that there would be, at best, only limited scope for salary enhancement. Statutory authority status would, however, tend to limit the mobility rights of ANAO staff in relation to the rest of the Australian Public Service.

There are several initiatives currently in train under the structural efficiency principle which will assist the ANAO's ability to attract and retain staff. In this context, it is worth noting that an upgraded SES structure was recently approved for the ANAO.

The question of whether the ANAO is a statutory authority or not is irrelevant to the Auditor-General's independence, since, as a statutory office holder, he has the right to determine his own audit priorities and mode of operation. That has never been at issue. Nor is there any valid suggestion that the Government's wages policy, or the level of resources available to the ANAO has ever compromised the independence of the Auditor-General or the ANAO in any way.
As the reasons in favour of establishing the ANAO as a statutory authority are not compelling, the Government does not accept the JCPA's recommendation on this matter.
Mandate

In its earlier response to the JCPA report, the Government indicated its disposition to accept the JCPA's recommendation that the Auditor-General be reinstated as the external auditor of Government business enterprises and statutory marketing authorities (SMAs). Since then, the report of the independent auditor of the ANAO has expressed the view that all Commonwealth entities should be audited by the ANAO. The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has also come out strongly in support of the view of the JCPA, stating that in accordance with the principle of ministerial accountability, all Commonwealth undertakings, of whatever legal form, should be audited by the Commonwealth Auditor-General to the standards laid down in the Audit Act 1901.

It is the Government's view that all public enterprises are ultimately accountable to Parliament, and that a major vehicle for this accountability is the Auditor-General. Consequently, the Government has decided that the Auditor-General should be the sole external auditor for all Commonwealth owned or controlled entities. However, the Government has also agreed that the Minister for Finance may provide exemptions in the case of statutory marketing authorities and Government business enterprises where special circumstances dictate. The Auditor-General may appoint, as agents, private sector auditors to undertake specified audits and has already indicated his willingness to do so. Suitable transitional arrangements will be put in place where private auditors have been appointed to undertake the audits of Commonwealth owned or controlled entities. The necessary legislative amendments to implement these changes will be included in the new legislation to replace the existing Audit Act.
Conclusion

The Government greatly appreciates the very comprehensive review conducted by Mr Sheridan and his team, and acknowledges the assistance provided by the South Australian Premier, Mr Bannon, in making him available.

The changes announced in this statement underline the Government's commitment to preserve and enhance the Auditor-General's independence. They also demonstrate the determination of this Government to ensure the highest standards of public administration, together with effective accountability to both the parliament and to the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I am pleased that the Government has acknowledged that report No. 296 by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was one of its most significant. Persons with an understanding of Commonwealth public administration are aware that the Australian National Audit Office has a special place in Commonwealth financial institutional structures.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh said earlier that the Australian Audit Office is rightly regarded as one of the major instruments that can contribute to efficient, accountable public administration. Today's response to report No. 296, The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament, is the second by this Government. A further process will be required which will involve the drafting of a new Audit Act, which we understand is due to commence on 1 July 1992. It is on the content of that latter process or Act that I wish to make further comment.

In doing so I shall refer to a letter from the Department of Finance dated 30 November 1990 to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901. Two features are foreshadowed in that Act which are particularly important and which were mentioned in and highlights of report No. 296. The letter states:

It will establish a Parliamentary Audit Committee, chaired by the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Representatives, alternating each year . . . The functions of the committee will include providing advice to the Auditor-General on Parliament's audit priorities and to the Government on the level of resources made available to the Auditor-General.

That is a most significant and welcome inclusion in the future Audit Act. Secondly, it foreshadows the establishment of the Auditor-General as the sole external auditor of Commonwealth agencies and entities, including statutory marketing authorities and government business enterprises. However, the Minister for Finance will have the authority to grant an exemption to an entity from the application of that mandate. I believe that that will be exercised fairly sparingly. It is important that where there is government involvement in one of these commercial utilities or undertakings there must be some parliamentary accountability-some reporting to the Parliament. The Government, basically, has accepted the thrust of the central features of report No. 296 in bringing the Australian Audit Office and the Parliament closer together through the establishment of this Parliamentary Audit Committee, and providing a wide mandate for the Auditor-General.

A further document was tabled today known as the Sheridan report. Contrary to some commentators' views, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report and the Sheridan report are quite consistent. In fact, they are complementary. The Government recognised the under-resourcing of the Australian Audit Office by allocating an extra $2m earlier to enable an extension of the efficiency audit program. I believe that this was a wise move, given the high potential for cost saving through improved administrative practices.

The Sheridan report was a useful document. Tom Sheridan was a competent auditor, being the former Auditor-General of South Australia. However, I wonder whether the Commonwealth Treasury, for example, would like the Tasmanian Under-Treasurer-with no reflection whatsoever on his capabilities-to undertake a review of the significant department of state, the Treasury. In a sense, this is what the Department of Finance did when it recommended to the Government the appointment of Mr Tom Sheridan to review the Australian National Audit Office. He did it quite competently, but when these reviews are done it is essential that they are done by equals at least in terms of responsibility and prestige.

On the one hand, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report gave the broad strategic outline. On the other, the Sheridan report supplemented that with detail and outlines of resources. Sheridan acknowledged that the Australian National Audit Office is undergoing the most significant change in its postwar history and that its affairs have been under almost constant review for over two years. While those review processes have not always helped the Australian National Audit Office to devote the necessary management and planning effort to the internal operations of the Office or to coordinate and implement change in the most efficient way, significant improvements have been achieved, particularly in the output of staff engaged in the direct audit work where productivity increases of about 15 per cent are starting to emerge.

We pay tribute to the leadership of Mr John Taylor, the Auditor-General. I am not sure that the Parliament got the same value out of the independent auditor's efficiency report presented recently, but such an observation may well be changed when the Public Accounts Committee conducts a further inquiry into that efficiency audit. I quote from page 4 of the Government's response:
There are several initiatives currently in train under the structural efficiency principle, which will assist the Australian National Audit Office's ability to attract and retain staff.
This has been one of its major problems. It continues:
In this context, it is worth noting that an upgraded SES structure was recently approved for the ANAO.
That is not only welcome but also long overdue.

Finally, the prolonged fight for funding, independence, mandate and recognition, which really began several AuditorGenerals ago, has finally been recognised. From my position, both as a senator and as vice-chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I thank all who have contributed over the years towards this recognition and upgrading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to comment on the supplementary Government response to the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the reform of the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) and essentially to echo the remarks of my colleague Senator Watson. I am pleased to note the Government's response in relation to the mandate of the Australian National Audit Office. That is a very sensible decision. It is certainly welcome. The Auditor-General will be the sole external auditor for all Commonwealth owned or controlled entities.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the Government has also agreed that the Minister for Finance may provide exemptions in the case of statutory marketing authorities and government business enterprises (GBEs) where special circumstances dictate. I hope that the Government makes clear those special circumstances. A chink has been put in by the Government which, depending on how it is used, could permit the erosion of its decision. It is important that it be spelt out quite clearly what sort of special circumstances might dictate the exemption in the case of particular marketing authorities and GBEs by the Auditor-General.

The particular point I comment on is the one that Senator Watson alluded to. I join him in expressing my regret that the Government has decided not to accept the Public Accounts Committee's recommendation that the ANAO be established as a statutory authority. That is a retrograde decision. I am amazed at the reasons given in the Government's response for that decision. I disagree very strongly with some of the statements in the Government's response. In particular, it states:
All statutory authorities and GBEs are constrained by the centralised wage system and the Government's wages policies, so that there would be, at best, only limited scope for salary enhancement.

It is widely known that the Opposition is very strongly opposed to the whole concept of the centralised wage system. This is a classic example of why one ought to be opposed to the centralised wage system. It is essentially saying that we cannot make a very important office of government, in terms of its independence and its role in government, a statutory authority and give it the independence that virtually everybody believes it should have because it would somehow or other be contrary to the Government's centralised wage fixing system.

Have honourable senators ever heard a more stupid and unjustified reason for rejecting such an important recommendation not only by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts but also by the Auditor-General himself over recent years and the whole thrust of the report by Tom Sheridan and the other reports that have been done, including the report by Michael Sharpe, into the Audit Office. That is a totally unsatisfactory and very worrying reason for the Government's rejection of the proposal that the Audit Office be a statutory authority.

The Government's statement also says that the question of whether the Audit Office is a statutory authority is irrelevant to the Auditor-General's independence. This relates to the point that I have just made about the centralised wage system. The statement that it is irrelevant to the Auditor-General's independence flies totally in the face of the Auditor-General's comments made on several occasions, the most recent being in his foreword to this year's annual report of the Audit Office. The Auditor-General, John Taylor, said:

I am compelled, therefore, to emphasise my response to the JCPA Report No. 296 . . . which recommended that the ANAO should be established as a statutory authority and that, like Canada, the United Kingdom and New Zealand, the Auditor-General should have improved ability over staff terms and conditions, and over hiring and firing, while maintaining consistency with the Government's policies of public sector restraint.

That is a very strong statement by the Auditor-General. It is a carefully considered statement that has been backed up very strongly by the Public Accounts Committee and by the independent reviews of the Audit Office. For the Government to say blithely that the question of whether the Audit Office is a statutory authority is irrelevant to the AuditorGeneral's independence flies in the face of all those statements and the views of most people with knowledge in this area. I find that a very disappointing and worrying response indeed. The Auditor-General and the Audit Office play an essential role in the good management of the finances of all Commonwealth entities and departments.

It is a huge job. It is a job where integrity and the independence of the Office are of the greatest importance. It is undeniable that this decision by Government to reject this recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts lessens the independence that the Office would otherwise have. It is whistling in the wind to ask the Government to reconsider that recommendation. But I hope that it will have another look at it because it is a very ill-considered recommendation which seems to be based on the flimsiest of all possible reasons, namely, the question of the centralised wage system.

If we ever wanted a classic example of why the centralised wage system is causing the damage to this nation that it is, why we cannot attract the right people to the right jobs, why we cannot reward people on the basis of their productivity, why we cannot get greater mobility into our work force and why, therefore, we are becoming increasingly unproductive in a highly competitive world, which is the basic cause of the problems underlying the situation in this country at the moment, this is it. The centralised wage fixing system is at the core of all of that. Here in a very small but important way we have seen an example of that. I hope that the auditing of the accounts of the Commonwealth and all its entities will not suffer unduly as a result of that decision. I think there is every prospect that this Parliament will rue the day that the Government has made that recommendation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment briefly on report No. 296 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and the Parliament. The Australian Democrats welcome the Government's acceptance of the Committee's recommendation that the Auditor-General be reinstated as the external auditor of government business enterprises and statutory marketing authorities. The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has also supported this particular move. When we move into corporatising many government owned enterprises, such as happened recently with the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, it is extremely important that the public oversight be maintained. They are still enterprises owned by the people. I believe that the Auditor-General must be given scope, powers and resources to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: In passing, I mention my regret that the Government and the Opposition did not support my amendment to ensure that shares in the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories could not be sold, except with the approval of both Houses of Parliament. Some of those enterprises in the not too distant future will possibly cease to be enterprises that belong to the community. Nevertheless, we support in the context of this report the proposition that all government enterprises should be accountable to the Parliament via the Auditor-General.

In this context I must share Senator Short's concern about the proposal to grant to the Minister for Finance a discretion to exempt some of these enterprises. That certainly requires some clarification. The notion of special circumstances is a difficult one to apply, unless it is specifically clarified and we know the criteria that are to be employed. We do not oppose the discretion; but we believe it should be clarified and identified in some detail.

I also share Senator Short's concern that the Government has decided not to establish the Australian National Audit Office as an independent statutory authority on, what I agree, is an extremely flimsy pretext that it cannot be provided with career paths and adequate salaries to attract qualified staff due to the centralised wage system that it would then come under. I believe that many other government authorities and departments have been able to create career paths for their employees and to attract qualified staff in one way or another. It should not be beyond the wit of this authority to be constituted as an independent statutory authority and yet develop career structures that enable it to attract qualified staff.

Finally, I wish to comment briefly, with approval, on the proposal in the report to establish a parliamentary committee to oversight the activities of the Australian National Audit Office. That is the way in which to bolster its independence and autonomy and to ensure that the Auditor-General will continue to be the ally of the people and their watchdog.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and also as the author of the title of its report No. 296, The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and the Parliament. The reason that I suggested the title, and the reason that the Committee acquiesced to that suggestion, is that the office of the Auditor-General is pivotal in ensuring that there is accountability to the Parliament for the expenditure of the taxpayers' dollar, of public funds. For expenditure in the public sector it is to the Parliament that the answers must be given-not to the Executive, not to any particular committee, but to the Parliament as a whole. Therefore, the role of the Auditor-General is both pivotal and crucial.

SPEECH.PARA: I read the report entitled Supplementary Government Response to the Report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the Reform of the Australian Audit Office in conjunction with the initial response delivered by Senator Walsh and entitled The Reform of the Australian Audit Office, Ministerial Statement, which was delivered last year. I read it in conjunction with Senator Walsh's comments when he said of the report that the Government does not agree with some of the Committee's recommendations dealing with the issues of independence, the resources for the Australian National Audit Office and the Auditor-General's mandate. In fact, in that report three of the most important aspects were the independence of the Auditor-General, the resourcing of the Office and the question of mandate. The Committee concluded that independence was of paramount importance because it was only by being independent of the Executive itself and of the strictures of not finding himself sufficiently resourced that the Auditor-General could properly carry out his function.

As to the question of resourcing, we were very keen to see the establishment of a committee which would be chaired by one of the Presiding Officers-either the Speaker or the President-and the funding for the Auditor-General being included within the appropriations for the parliamentary departments. As such, there would be an independent source of funding. Senator Walsh rejected that proposition.

In looking at this supplementary response, which is based on the Sheridan report, I see that the point has not been dealt with except to say that, by putting a cost value on the reforms which the Auditor-General has already put in place, by simply being more efficient and having greater productivity, the Auditor-General can effectively render unto himself an additional $3m per annum in resources, together with the additional $2m per annum announced by Senator Walsh for the purpose of allowing a greater number of efficiency audits to be carried out. Significant in this supplementary report is the fact that the Government endorses the view that the Audit Office shall charge for financial statement audits and retain the resultant revenue. The Auditor-General shall not, however, charge for efficiency audits.

The really worrying statement in the report for me is the one that has already been mentioned by honourable senators who have spoken earlier-that is, the part of the report dealing with mandate. All the opening words of the paragraph under the title `Mandate' are quite reassuring. The report of the independent auditor cites, for instance, that not only the Public Accounts Committee but also the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration recommended that mandate be restored for all statutory marketing authorities and government business enterprises. But when one turns to page 6 of the supplementary Government response, one reads:
. . . the Government has decided that the Auditor-General should be the sole external auditor for all Commonwealth owned or controlled entities.

The first question that is raised in my mind is: what is the definition of a `controlled' entity? My mind goes back to the situation, which still remains, created by an opinion of the Attorney-General's Department that unless a majority of the directors are appointed by the Government, despite the fact that all the money for that entity is provided by the taxpayer via the Government, the Auditor-General must gain the permission of the auditee in order to conduct an efficiency audit. That was the position with the Australian Bicentennial Authority.

I am concerned about the definition of the word `controlled' and what its current meaning may be. But I am more concerned that the response points out that the Government has agreed that the Minister for Finance may provide exemptions for statutory marketing authorities and government business enterprises where so-called special circumstances dictate. There is absolutely nothing in this response to indicate what special circumstances may be considered; by whom they may be considered to be special or special enough; whether some sorts of guidelines are to be secreted away within the Department of Finance of which other people will not be aware; and whether or not those decisions are to be made in an arbitrary manner and are not to be subject to anybody's review.

My colleague Senator Watson said that he hoped that this power of the Minister for Finance would be exercised sparingly. But there is nothing in this response to indicate that that would or could be the case. The words are very encouraging. The following statement is made in the conclusion to the response:
The changes announced in this statement underline the Government's commitment to preserve and enhance the Auditor-General's independence.
I am afraid that I am not convinced when I read a sentence that begins, `However, there shall be exemptions'.

I think the Auditor-General is to be commended on the actions that he has taken with regard to the report of the Joint Public Accounts Committee and the efforts he has made to make the Office more efficient and to provide unto himself greater resources through being efficient.

The response points out that this was one of the most important reviews that the Public Accounts Committee has undertaken. As I said right at the outset, the Auditor-General is pivotal in the whole question of accountability.

My colleague Senator Short addressed the question of the Australian National Audit Office becoming a statutory authority. I think, however, it is necessary to point out that Senator Walsh, in his statement last year, said that the Government would give further consideration to that recommendation when it received the independent review which was carried out by Mr Sheridan. I can only conclude that the Government did not consider Mr Sheridan's view on that issue to be of very much use because it has decided to jettison that proposal.

On the whole, I am encouraged to see that the Government has expressed a view which is supportive of the independence of the Auditor-General. I can only hope that that sentence which begins, `However', does not turn out to be full of portent that that independence will not be real but somehow fettered.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

In speaking to this report, I would draw to the Senate's attention the various functions, as listed on page vi, of the Australian Industrial Registry. Amongst other functions, they include:

I have read that report and I would reject their contention, based on that report, that the proposed legislation to reduce the number of trade unions will still leave a considerable number of firms with a considerable number of trade unions. In fact, that will not be the case, because the amalgamation of trade unions is simply the beginning of the process. What will occur once those amalgamations have taken place is the swapping of membership, and such mighty organisations as the Australian Brushmakers Union, the Australian Rope and Cordage Workers Union, the Bakery Employees and Salesmen's Federation, the Millers and Manufacturing Grocery Employees Association of Australia, the Federated Tobacco Workers Union--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why sneer at them?

—I am not sneering at them. They did play a very valuable role in the past in the various areas that they represented, but we can no longer afford an overlapping of union coverage and the unnecessary industrial disputes that that has led to in the past.
—Enterprise unions!

—I shall get to that issue in a short period of time. In terms of enterprise unions, the Opposition would have us believe that big unions lead to industry-wide national awards and to multiple union and award coverage, with everyone being worse off. Opposition members want small enterprise unions. They want unions everywhere. They would like this report to be 100 pages long, with 100,000 trade unions. That is their option. What they want in having thousands of trade unions is making sure that the bargaining power of workers who are covered by these so-called trade unions is non-existent. That is what they are all about. They want to see miserable little trade unions scattered all over the country, thousands of them, trying to bargain on behalf of their workers and improve wages and conditions. —Talk about a load of rubbish!
—Order! There are too many interjections. Senator Sherry, could you address your remarks through the chair. The honourable senator will be heard in silence for the last minute or so of his speech.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. What Opposition members want to do is to rip away the wages and conditions that workers currently enjoy and that are protected by the trade union movement. In terms of large trade unions there are some dangers, and I acknowledge them. In reducing overlapping coverage it is important that we rationalise the research effort, the co-ordination, the training and reduce competition through unnecessary demarcation disputes. Let me give a good example, and this might interest Opposition senators who are totally ignorant of industrial relations. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

At times I have been highly critical of the Australian Research Council's grants and awards. I am interested to note that now that Australia is in a very serious economic state the awards and grants being made are to a large degree very sensible. I strongly support the great bulk of them, and I want to mention a few of them as showing the sort of work of which the Senate and the people of Australia should be proud in these grants.

For example, among the successful grants noted in the report there is one looking at DNA markers in eucalypts for plantation forestry. Under this grant, scientifically Australia would be entering into a new field of forest molecular biology, with research based on its own native resources. The prospects there are very significant. There is another one involving the genetic engineering of wheat, using embryo cultures and microprojectile vectors. This `unique interdisciplinary team' has a good chance of taking a world leadership role in this new technology of gene implantation. The effects of temperature and salinity on the viability of rainbow trout are being examined with a grant of $31,000. This is very significant because the export potential of the industry is threatened unless selection programs are successful. This research is very important to Australia. Another grant relates to factors affecting large scale production of proteins from insect cell culture, which receives $70,000 for research. The commercial potential of the technique is very large. I mention all these to show that there is a great deal of very significant research going on which could be of immense significance to the people of Australia and for the profitability of many Australian companies. Then there is another grant relating to measurement of imperfections in silos in service, which is of great interest to people on the land. Then a sum of $56,000 goes towards a modelling approach to hydrodynamics, larval dispersal and reef connectivity implications. This work at the James Cook University of North Queensland is very important indeed in terms of the Great Barrier Reef management.

It is not simply in the scientific areas that some of these grants are very worth while. In the area of the arts, for which I am shadow Minister, there is a grant, for example, for investigation and analysis of Australian autobiographies. This is an area which does not seem to have received a great deal of attention. Patronage in Australian art is another investigation being funded by a grant to the extent of $18,000. This is an historically based investigation by government and private sources covering the years from 1788 to 1982. I am glad to see that attention is being given to this area of Australian arts. In fact, I complained during the bicentennial year that not enough research was going on in this direction. The final study will provide a sound and useful basis for future government decision making in this area. I look forward to having that information there when I am making decisions as Minister for the Arts.

Then there is a grant relating to the Grainger letters. Percy Grainger was one of Australia's leading musicians and certainly an eccentric personality. Not enough has been done yet on him and the grant has been made for research in that direction. Then there is a dictionary of Australian artists dealing with nineteenth century painters, photographers and engravers. There is an art guide to places in Australia-a whole range of very useful work being done to celebrate Australia's significance as a place of the arts.

In social history there is a grant to do some work on college people-a social history of the Melbourne middle class from 1914 to 1980. This book will break new ground both in subject matter and methodology. It will do something to fill an astonishing gap in our knowledge of ourselves. Most research in this area seems to be about radical groups. Very little attention has been paid to looking to the middle class on which Australia has depended. Another relates to `Violence in Australian Sport: An Historical Perspective'. This will assess whether Australian sport today is more violent than in earlier times and will suggest possible means to combat this problem.

I would like to thank the Government for its cooperation, and I dealt with Senator Robert Ray on that matter and briefly with Senator McKiernan before that. I spoke with Senator McLean of the Australian Democrats and also Senator Harradine and Senator Vallentine.

SPEECH.PARA: The Italian community is very appreciative of the gesture of this Parliament on the fiftieth anniversary of that event.
