SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several weeks ago I had the privilege of being a member of a parliamentary delegation visiting European institutions and the parliaments of Switzerland, Belgium and France. Very early in our delegation's visit to Switzerland, I found myself sitting opposite nine senior Swiss bankers. The conversation centred on the question as to why Australia was not attracting more investment money from Swiss banks. The language was gentle but the message was very blunt: our corporate image stinks and the banking institutions in Australia have contributed to that unfortunate corporate image which we have overseas, and until such time as we can rectify that, we will not be attracting substantial sums of money for investment through Swiss banking channels.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of that discussion, one of the nine senior bankers made a totally unsolicited comment. He said that the senior Australian bankers who had been involved in enticing Australian business people and farmers into the Swiss bank loans of 1984-86 were nothing short of criminals and should be in jail. That is the expression that he used. After our discussions I had private conversations with him, and he said that he would be prepared to come to Australia to testify to that effect. We have a bank inquiry coming up fairly soon, and I am led to believe that in fact he may be visiting Australia to do exactly that. It was by sheer coincidence that, five days prior to his making this unsolicited comment, I had been standing in this chamber and presenting to the Senate quite specific examples of the techniques that had been used by Australian banks to create the processes which had evoked such a very precise and specific observation by a senior Swiss banker.

Tonight I will be continuing to put before the Senate further very precise information, which I hope to put also before the bank inquiry fairly soon. One of the cases I have referred to previously has been the case of a Mr Wilfred Taylor of Cambewarra, near Nowra, who was the principal director and shareholder of Mighty Chef Products Pty Ltd. On several occasions I have referred to the Taylor case and his dispute with the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Tonight I would like to be fairly detailed, and I will be later seeking leave to table copies of documents upon which I base some of these allegations. I have previously provided copies of these documents for perusal by both the Government and the Opposition.

In May 1986, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia granted a facility to Mighty Chef, secured by a registered first equitable mortgage over the assets and undertakings of Mighty Chef. By October 1987, Mighty Chef experienced difficulties in repaying its debt and interest to the bank. Mr Taylor then sought an influx of capital into the company. On 21 October 1987, Mr Taylor attended a meeting with Mr Keith Greenwood, the Managing Director of Armtech Ltd, and Mr Peter Poppett, the Manager of the George and Market Street branch of the Commonwealth Bank. Poppett said:
Mighty Chef urgently requires an influx of capital. I know that there are several proposals afoot. I will make the final decision as to which of the proposals is acceptable to the bank. You-
that is, Taylor-
will have no say in the matter.
Mr Taylor's account of what Poppett said is corroborated by Mr Greenwood in an affidavit sworn on 15 April 1988 as follows:

I attended a conference with Mr Taylor, Mr Poppett and Mr Levingston on 21st October 1987. Poppett used words to me to the effect that: `The bank (the first Defendant) would want periodic reductions in the principal sum on the Mighty Chef loan and would want more security. The Bank would have to be satisfied as to Armtech's security and make the decision.' Poppett used further words to the effect that: `There are a number of competing companies wanting to take-over Mighty Chef. The Bank would make the final decision as to who came in. Taylor has no say in the matter.'

In early December 1987 a finance broker arranged a meeting between Mr Taylor, a Wayne Lawrence and Poppett. Lawrence was the principal of Adelview Ltd. At the meeting Lawrence advised that he proposed to put a proposition to the Bank. At about the same time Mr Taylor introduced Mr Neil Tumbers to Poppett, and certain negotiations took place between Mr Tumbers and Poppett. Mr Tumbers was the Managing Director of United Systems Holding Pty Ltd, owned as to 25 per cent by Mr Kerry Packer.

In early December 1987 Poppett told Mr Taylor he would investigate proposals put to him by Lawrence and separately by Mr Tumbers and would let Mr Taylor know which proposal would be acceptable to the bank. In an affidavit sworn by Mr Taylor at Nowra on 26 September 1988, he swears that Poppett later said to him:
The decision as to which party is to come into your business will be made by me-
that is, Poppett-
. . . and you will abide by that decision.

That means that Poppett was going to accept responsibility for making the decision. It also means that if Poppett made the wrong decision he could be held liable for it. Mr Taylor, as plaintiff, sued the Commonwealth Bank of Australia as first defendant and Peter Poppett as second defendant. The bank's defence alleged that the decision vested with Mr Taylor. Clause 9 of the defence provides, among other things:
. . . the Second Defendant said to the Plaintiff words to the effect that the second Defendant would need to examine both proposals to determine which option would best clear the corporation's-
that is, Mighty Chef's-
. . . indebtedness to the Bank and that the Second Defendant stressed that any decision on the acceptance or otherwise of the offers rested with the Plaintiff . . .

The defence was verified by an affidavit verifying defence sworn by Poppett on 30 March 1988. Mr Taylor swore on oath that Poppett told him that he, Poppett, would make the decision. Poppett swore on oath that he told Taylor that he, Taylor, would make the decision. What that means is that Taylor and Poppett had sworn to mutually exclusive statements of fact and one of them had committed perjury.

On 17 November 1987 Mighty Chef entered into an agreement with Adelview Ltd for the acquisition by Adelview of 51 per cent of Mighty Chef. Unbeknown to Mr Taylor, the finance broker, one Warren Small, handed a copy of the agreement to the bank. Poppett knew about the agreement. The copy held by the bank has his handwritten note:
Mr Poppett, Mr Small would like you to ring him.

Further, on 18 November 1987, a copy of the agreement was sent by facsimile transmission from the bank to Martin Brown of Coopers and Lybrand. The facsimile transmission header has this handwritten note:
Mr Poppett will phone this afternoon.

This means that Poppett knew of an agreement whereby Adelview Ltd would become entitled to more than 51 per cent of the voting power of Mighty Chef. Clause F2 of the deed of equitable mortgage dated 13 May 1986 provides, among other things:

(i) The moneys hereby secured shall at the option of the Bank...immediately become payable and this mortgage shall immediately become enforceable without any demand or notice in each or any of the following events:-

(m) If any person . . . who is not at the date hereof entitled to more than 50 per cent of the voting power shall, without the consent in writing of the Bank, directly or through a nominee, become so entitled. . .

This means that on and from 17 November 1987 the decision rested not with Mr Taylor, but with Poppett and the bank. Poppett committed wilful and corrupt perjury. Although Mr Taylor signed the agreement with Lawrence, Lawrence did not perform and Taylor distrusted him. In a later conversation Poppett asked Taylor which of the two persons, Lawrence or Tumbers, he preferred and Taylor said:
I prefer Mr Tumbers because he has a successful established business and could, if required, service the liabilities to the Bank and other creditors from the revenues received from his own business.
Mr Taylor went on to say:
I am not at all happy to do business with Lawrence. I believe he is not genuine and I have reservations about his character. I believe he is dishonest and cannot be trusted.

This means that if Mr Taylor had made the decision, he would have chosen Mr Tumbers. Mr Taylor's attitude to Lawrence is corroborated by a bank diary note written by one Glen Levingston, which states, among other things:
Mr Taylor is not happy with Wayne Lawrence's offer as Taylor does not trust Lawrence . . .
This diary note was initialled by Poppett. Mr Taylor's attitude to Lawrence is further corroborated by an affidavit of Mr Tony Rigg, sworn on 5 April 1988, which states among other things:

In late November, 1987, Mr Taylor telephoned me and used words to the effect that: `I have signed an agreement with Lawrence, because of pressure from the Bank'. I said: `Are you happy with him?' Taylor replied, `No. I am not. He has not performed on the contract.' In early December, 1987, Mr Taylor telephoned me and used words to the effect that: `Neil Tumbers has put an offer to me. I am going to put the offer to the Bank. I do not trust Lawrence, I do not believe he is honest or genuine. I recommend that you do not do business with him.'

This means that if, for whatever reason, Poppett decided to accept Lawrence's offer and wanted Mr Taylor to cooperate in the takeover of Mighty Chef, he would have to convince Mr Taylor to change his attitude to Lawrence. This Poppett did by a shabby and disgraceful fraud-a fraud that condemns the Commonwealth Bank as a corrupt institution. In his affidavit Mr Taylor gives this account of what Poppett said to him:

On or about 9th December, 1987, . . . Poppett used words to the effect, `We have investigated both parties. The proposal submitted by Mr Lawrence is a good one. He and his companies are financially secure and Lawrence has shown me a letter of credit for $1 million. You are to accept the proposal from Mr Lawrence. . .' Poppett further said that, `. . . the Bank insists that you enter into arrangements with Lawrence immediately, otherwise the alternative will be that a receiver is put in at once!'
Mr Taylor's account of what Poppett said to him is corroborated by an affidavit of Mr Tumbers sworn on 8 April 1988 as follows:
In early December, 1987, I met the 2nd Defendant-
that is, Poppett-
. . . at the office of the 1st Defendant-
that is, the bank-
. . . I used words to the effect that, `What security is Wayne Lawrence offering to the Bank?' The 2nd Defendant replied with words to the effect that, `Lawrence has an irrevocable letter of credit.'

A few days after the aforesaid meeting, the 2nd Defendant telephoned me and used words to the effect that, `We (the Bank) are going with Wayne Lawrence. His was a much better offer than yours.' I used words to the effect that, `Are you (Poppett) sure Lawrence can back up his offer? I am not satisfied that he can.' The 2nd Defendant replied with words to the effect that, `We (the Bank) have looked right into Lawrence and his companies. He and his companies stack up really well. He has the security the Bank requires.' I then used words to the effect that, `How does Wilfred Taylor feel about this? He really wants to do the deal with us.' The 2nd Defendant responded with words to the effect that, `It is not up to Taylor. It is the Bank's decision.'
Mr Taylor's account is further corroborated by an affidavit of accountant Mr Prakash Masih sworn on 20 April 1988 as follows:

On 9th December, 1987, Taylor used words to the effect that, `I have just received a phone call from Poppett and he says we have to go with Lawrence. I tried to talk him out of it, but he says he has checked Lawrence and his companies out thoroughly and they are financially sound. He (Poppett) said Lawrence had produced a letter of credit for $1 million. Poppett insists that if we do not go with Lawrence, he will appoint receivers immediately.
Mr Taylor's account is further corroborated by an affidavit of Mr Tony Rigg of Nowra sworn on 5 April 1988 as follows:

On about the 9th December, 1987, Mr Taylor telephoned me and used words to the effect that, `Peter Poppett said I had to go with Adelview or he would put a receiver in. Poppett told me he looked right into both Lawrence and Tumbers and Lawrence came up better than Tumbers. He said Lawrence had produced a letter of credit for $1 million in favour of Adelview. . .
Mr Taylor relied upon the statements of fact made to him by Poppett and executed an agreement with Lawrence. Mr Masih's affidavit provides as follows:

About midday on 9th December, 1987, Lawrence came into the premises (of Mighty Chef). He said to Taylor, in my presence, words to the effect that, `No doubt Poppett has telephoned you by now and told you that the deal is to be done with us.' Taylor replied with words to the effect that, `Poppett advised me of his decision and we have prepared a draft agreement for your perusal.'

Small and Moody (an associate of Lawrence) then drafted a simplified form of agreement and handed it to Taylor and myself. I said to Lawrence and Moody, words to the effect that, `I would prefer to sign the amended agreement that we submitted to you this morning. Under your agreement you receive the shares up front for nothing. . .' Moody used further words to the effect that, `Our agreement is the only one we are prepared to sign. I am sure you would not want Mr Poppett to put the receivers in on you.'
The parties then signed the Agreement and the share transfers. . .

The statements of fact made by Poppett to Taylor were palpable falsehoods. I make that statement in reliance upon the bank's own files. I refer you, Mr President, and other senators to those files and I rely upon the indisputable documentary evidence produced by the bank, namely, a letter from the bank to Lawrence, dated 11 December 1989 and signed by Poppett himself which, after referring to the release of the bank's securities, states as follows:
The above is subject to the following:
(1) An unconditional Bank Letter of Credit for $750,000, which must be received at this office on or before Thursday 17th December, 1987 . . .

Poppett is asking for a letter of credit and yet he told both Taylor and Tumbers that he had already signed a letter of credit. That was blatant fraud. The second piece of evidence is a diary note signed by Mr Glen Levingston, an officer of the bank and assistant to Poppett, and dated 30 November 1987 which states relating to Adelview:
We are yet to verify that the company has the cash (or even the potential) to pay $600,000 to the Bank.
The third piece of evidence is a diary note signed by Mr Levingston and dated 2 December 1987 which states:
We still have no information re the financial standing of Adelview Pty Ltd.
These diary notes mean that, upon the bank's own written admission, the bank did not know the financial standing of Lawrence's company. A diary note of Mr Levingston dated 22 February 1988 states:

Whilst we do not have any idea of how Lawrence could meet a $750,000 payment (in fact, we know next to nothing about Lawrence or Adelview Ltd.) if he or his company does have the means to pay this amount to MCP (that is, Mighty Chef Products) we would be foolish not to at least take a punt on pursuing the matter for at least another month.

That diary note means that upon the bank's own written admission, after Poppett made the fraudulent misrepresentations, the bank still did not know the financial standing of Lawrence's companies. I say, and the fact is, that Poppett defrauded Mr Taylor in that he made to Mr Taylor false statements of fact, knowingly or without belief in the truth of the statements and recklessly without caring whether the statements were true or false, with the intent that the statements would be acted upon, and they were in fact acted upon by Mr Taylor. I further say, and the fact is, that Mr Poppett, by swearing the affidavit verifying defence, committed wilful and corrupt perjury as a senior officer of the Commonwealth Bank. I call upon the Attorney-General for New South Wales to forthwith take all appropriate action. I seek the indulgence of the Senate to table all the documents to which I referred in my statement.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to speak about an issue that I first raised in the Estimates Committee A hearing on 12 October 1990. The questions that I asked are recorded on page 657 of the Hansard and deal with a question that I asked of the Comptroller-General of Customs, Mr Kelly, concerning a practice which I called `triple dipping'. On that occasion I asked Mr Kelly about the self-assessment system being used. I asked whether or not it was the practice of the Australian Customs Service to charge an error made in the self-assessment system against the importer-that is, the owner, his agent or the agency of the agent concerned. As the questioning went on, as one would see from the Hansard, I received an answer that no, this practice was not carried out to the knowledge of the Comptroller.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequent to asking those questions, I inquired a little further as to this practice and I have realised that the error in my question was the use of the word `charge'. In fact, the triple dipping to which I referred works in this way: where an error is made under the self-assessment system, the Customs Service is obliged to keep a record of those people who make such an error. I believe this record is known as the error records register. Instead of the record simply showing that a statement has been made by a particular person who is either the owner or his agent, an entry is made in that register against both the owner and his agent and/or the agency concerned. This becomes particularly relevant when an application is made for a reduction in the penalty which is imposed under the system.

The fact that, in assessing the reduction of the penalty, the delegate making the decision takes into account the number of errors registered against both the owner and the agent and/or the agency means that an owner who has in no way been involved with the error that has been made by his agent, for instance, is penalised by errors that the agent may have made in cases which do not relate to that owner's business at all. This practice was in fact challenged and, indeed, dealt with more specifically in a decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) called Walker (Australia) Pty Ltd and the Comptroller-General of Customs. That decision and the reasons were published on 13 November 1990.

On 12 October I asked whether or not Mr Kelly, the Comptroller, was aware of another case that was being brought concerning this practice. In the upshot, Senator Button, being the Minister in charge, said that he did not think that the Comptroller should answer that question. I went on to say that perhaps we would get a decision fairly soon and perhaps the Comptroller could make an examination and let us know how many other such cases existed. I have not had an answer to that question.

I think it is a very important matter because, despite the fact that many others have complained about it, there is now a case which is due to be heard on 11 January 1991 called Oxford Clothing Co. and the Comptroller-General of Customs. This particular case involves only a small sum of money, namely, $300, but the people concerned with this case are so incensed that, as a matter of principle, they have taken it to the AAT. Indeed, from the reading of the judgment of Walker (Australia) Pty Ltd and the Comptroller-General of Customs, it would seem that they are relying on that case as a precedent.

One may have argued, I suppose, at one stage that on a plain reading of the Act one could record the error against more than one party, although there is now a clear decision that in fact the view of the AAT is that section 243 of the relevant Act draws a distinction between the actions of the applicant, that is, the owner in this case, and those of the agent or the applicant; that is, the owner.

Section 243u (4) (a), (c) and (d) are clearly referring to the maker of the statement in question. The statement in question must be that which led to the imposition of the penalty imposed under section 243t, which in this case would be a statement to an officer that is false in a material particular. I raise this matter because it is my feeling that at the time of asking the question on 12 October the practice was identified specifically despite the fact that I used the wrong word. However, I did take the care to go away and research the matter a little more thoroughly, and that is why I have raised this matter here this evening. I will be interested to see the outcome of the case of Oxford Clothing v. Customs on 11 January 1991.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.01 p.m.
